PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to a media release issued by Senator McLean yesterday relating to a ruling which I made concerning certain documents which Senator McLean proposed to disclose in the Senate. The media release states that `Westpac Banking Corporation has sought to influence a Presidential ruling'. While the media release does not allege that I have, in fact, been influenced in any improper way, I think I should respond to that suggestion. In my ruling yesterday I made it clear that I had received submissions from Westpac concerning the documents in question and that I had also received a submission from Senator McLean. My ruling was based on a consideration of the merits of these submissions and other advice I received. There was no influence upon me, as the media release might be taken to imply.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a memorial to those who served their country and paid the supreme sacrifice and that the material on display in the galleries is as sacred and as much of a memorial nature as the building itself. We seek your assistance in having this decision rescinded.
2. We urge you to direct the Australian War Memorial Council to reverse this decision.

Your petitioners therefore ask the Members of the Senate to disallow the regulations as tabled in Parliament empowering the Australian War Memorial Council to charge an admission fee to any section of the Memorial.

PETITION.TITLE: Visual-Hearing Impairment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That there is a lack of existing services provided specifically for those suffering from visual/hearing impairment.
Your petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should-
Urge the Government to investigate the tragic plight of Australian citizens who suffer from deafness or blindness but particularly those who suffer from a severe visual/hearing impairment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian War Memorial Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 448 and made under the Australian War Memorial Act 1980, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) registers its serious concern at the plight of farming families throughout Australia as their incomes continue to decline rapidly;

(b) notes that the Australian Valuation Office (AVO) continually values farm properties well above the valuation commonly agreed to by Local Councils, rural land agents and State Government valuers for the purposes of assessing the assets of rural people for Family Allowance Supplement, AUSTUDY and other pension and benefit payments;
(c) notes that as a direct consequence of the discrepancies between AVO and other genuine valuations:
(i) many young people are not able to continue their education,
(ii) many rural families are being forced to repay AUSTUDY payments,
(iii) other families remain ineligible for Family Allowance Supplement despite having low or negative incomes, and
(iv) many rural women separated from their husbands will be ineligible for any assistance from the Department of Social Security;

(d) calls on the Government to move to redress this situation by at least ensuring that the AVO's valuations reflect local market reality, and preferably by acknowledging that the family farm is a `tool of trade' and not a readily realisable asset; and

(e) calls on the Government to recognise the hardship presently being experienced in rural Australia by exempting the value of the family farm from the assets test for AUSTUDY, Family Allowance Supplement and other pensions and benefits.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING CORPORATION: MIDDLE EAST COVERAGE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) condemns the Federal Government for its obsessive attacks on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) over its independent coverage of the war in the Persian Gulf;

(b) condemns the Federal Government's attempts to impose its own form of censorship on the ABC by threatening to further reduce funding, on the grounds that our national broadcaster refuses to slavishly follow the `Top Gun' movie approach to war news perfected by Cable Network News (CNN);

(c) acknowledges and praises the integrity and competence exhibited by the ABC in its ability to discern truth from propaganda and the variety of half-truths passed off by the US and Iraqi military authorities as news;

(d) draws attention to recent People Meter TV audience research that indicates Australian viewers, unlike the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and President Saddam Hussein, are switching off CNN coverage, preferring Australian news presentations of events in the Gulf; and
(e) urges the Federal Government to reward the precious democratic freedom of a truly independent news service, by increasing its level of funding to guarantee the ABC's continued integrity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) recalls and endorses the seven resolutions of the United Nations General Assembly on East Timor passed between 1975 and 1982;

(b) endorses, in particular, Resolution 53/27 of 1980, which `reaffirms the inalienable right of the people of East Timor to self-determination and independence . . . [and] declares that the people of East Timor must be enabled freely to determine their own future within the framework of the United Nations';

(c) notes with dismay that, on 11 February 1991, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) said that Australia `simply can't lend ourselves to . . . the non-acceptance of the sovereign incorporation of East Timor into the Republic of Indonesia';
(d) condemns this flagrant disregard for the will of the UN, in view of the human rights violations committed by Indonesian forces against East Timorese people since occupation; and

(e) calls on the Federal Government to turn the Prime Minister's vision of a new world order of peace, security and freedom into reality, by supporting a UN supervised act of free choice by the people of East Timor following the withdrawal of Indonesian military forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) recalls and endorses Resolution 242 passed by the United Nations Security Council in 1967, which calls for Israel's withdrawal from the Occupied Territories, and the termination of all territorial claims by, and respect for the sovereignty of, all regional states;
(b) notes with grave concern that:

(i) a likely consequence of the Middle East war is that Israel's opposition to meeting its obligations under Resolution 242 will be deepened, in the expectation of United States' support as a reward for Israeli restraint in the face of unprovoked Iraqi missile attacks, and

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) recalls and endorses Article 21 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nations General Assembly in 1948, which states that the `will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government; this will shall be expressed in periodic and genuine elections which shall be by universal and general suffrage and shall be held by secret vote or by equivalent free voting procedures';
(b) recalls that several resolutions of the United Nations Security Council call for the reinstatement of the former Kuwaiti Government after Iraq withdraws from Kuwait;
(c) notes with concern that this aim contradicts the UN's endorsement of free and fair general elections, in that the former Kuwaiti Government was a feudal monarchy with no popular mandate; and

(d) calls on the Federal Government to turn the Prime Minister's vision of a new world order of peace, security and freedom into reality, by calling for a UN supervised act of free choice by the people of Kuwait on their future political system and relationship with Iraq, following the complete withdrawal of Iraqi forces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) recalls Resolution 34/22 passed by the United Nations General Assembly in 1979, and endorses its view that `the people of Kampuchea should be enabled to choose democratically their own government, without outside interference, subversion or coercion';

(b) recalls that this resolution was passed in the aftermath of a holocaust inflicted by the Khmer Rouge regime of Pol Pot on the Cambodian people at the cost of hundreds of thousands, possibly millions of innocent lives;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are a number of items coming out of this report of the Standing Committee on Procedure that will require a motion to put them before the Senate for debate. There are 10 items in all. Before I move the first one, I will make it quite clear because I think there was some misunderstanding the last time we had a Procedure Committee debate that I am not moving these motions on behalf of the Government; I am simply moving them as Manager of Government Business. When my time comes up for rotation in the chamber my colleagues will follow in doing that.

SPEECH.PARA: In no way does it suggest that a government imprimatur or a party room decision has been made on any one of these particular motions but we do need an instrument to put them before the Senate. In some cases, I am sure there would have been a pre-discussion within party rooms on some of these matters and on others there would not have been. I would also point out that we would like to expedite these matters as quickly as possible. If there is major disagreement and if there is going to be a long debate, I would very strongly argue that we send it back to the Procedure Committee and see whether we can iron it out further, rather than have a long and useless debate here. We very much seek to change these sort of procedures with a degree of unanimity around the chamber rather than a partisan vote. The first item that comes up is electronic voting. I move:
That the Senate take note of this part of the report.

I will not speak very long to this particular motion. As I recall, the Procedure Committee did not come to a final determination on electronic voting. A very competent investigation was carried out by the officers of this chamber and various alternatives were put forward, but the Procedure Committee could not come down with a conclusive view. I also note that the other place is looking at this particular matter.

The sorts of issues that come up are: do we have only electronic voting in the chamber and therefore is there much advantage to it? Are we able to record the vote throughout the building and, if so, under what safe conditions, et cetera? I think at the moment the Procedure Committee is erring a little on the side of conservatism. On the one hand I do not think it rules it out. On the other hand, it has not yet seen a system that is compelling in an appealing sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I contribute very briefly to this debate because we have discussed the subject from time to time. I remember the former Senator Puplick expressing a personal view against electronic voting. In some ways there has been concern that it might detrimentally affect the culture of this place. Like Senator Robert Ray, when I speak on these matters today, I am not formally speaking on behalf of the Opposition. We do not have a whip in these matters, but I think it can be fairly said that improvements in efficiency of the operation of the Senate is something that the Opposition applauds.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is another side to this argument. One is the cost of implementing it. We are conscious of the need in these difficult economic times for restraint and we need to demonstrate some of that restraint ourselves. But, probably even more importantly, it is really debatable as to whether there would be a significant advantage, whether there would be a significant saving in time, particularly if it is accepted that the vote should be lodged from within this chamber rather than from within the rooms, and there is a good argument for that.

Also, there is quite a strong argument, I believe, in that it brings senators together at the closing stages of a Bill, often at a time when there have been amendments and the amendments may not have been widely appreciated. It has the purpose of perhaps making senators more aware of what they are voting upon. All I am saying at the moment is that it is still a debatable position. I personally support the recommendation of the Committee that in fact it be returned to the Procedure Committee for further consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several points which Senator Hill has just raised, of course, are really complete furphies. The cost of the electronic voting would be substantially less than the costs at present, for the simple reason that at the moment when the buttons are pushed by senators, not only would the votes be automatically tallied and put up on a screen behind the President's chair somewhere for everybody to see, but also the names of the particular people who were voting would also be revealed there and could be automatically recorded into Hansard. So the voting could in fact occur over a very, very short interval of time and therefore very considerable savings would occur.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unfortunate that it seems some members in this place are not aware of the enormous power of electronic devices these days. The real reason that the Government and the Opposition are not too happy with this is that voting would have to occur with each senator sitting in his or her place. One can imagine the difficulty which the parties, with such tight control of their members, would face with their members wanting to vote for or against particular motions without actually physically dividing and crossing the floor.

The lack of understanding which members of both the Government and the Opposition show with respect to particular matters being voted upon is quite clear very often in this chamber. We in the Australian Democrats have all had the experience of members of both the Government and the Opposition coming in saying, `What are we voting on? What is this all about? Which side do we go?' One can imagine, if one had electronic voting and all senators had to sit in their own place and press a button, the confusion which would reign in this place in terms of the votes.

But, of course, the up side of that would be that every senator in this place would have to responsibly understand what it was he or she was voting on and cast a deliberate, deliberative vote, and that would be one of its principal advantages. For that reason, we would suggest that it be looked at very closely. But it is precisely-and I am putting my finger right on it here-the reason that neither the Government nor the Opposition is keen to have it. They both rely on a very tight party system in which most of their members simply behave like sheep and vote according to the one or two who determine how they will vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray has asked for a very brief debate. I could not agree with him more but that absolute rubbish we have just heard unfortunately inspired me to get to my feet. I have never heard such rubbish. If any caucusing is done, it is done in the Australian Democrats. How very rarely do they ever divide their vote. They are caucused stronger than any other group. Indeed, they organise themselves when they are in this situation of the public being divided outside and then say amongst themselves, `Okay, we can rectify this. We will have two over there and three over here'. They caucus themselves more than any other group in this place, more than any other party. Indeed, we have witnessed that they never listen to debate, as they profess to do, because their minds are made up well before they enter this place.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, as you well know, the Liberal Party of Australia senators have the opportunity on every Bill to cross the floor and vote according to their consciences, and they have done so on many, many occasions. Senator Coulter said that senators come in here and say, `What are we voting on?'. How ridiculous! The Australian Democrats do not even bother to ask. They look where their leader is and off they wander.

TALK.START.PARA: —And where the Government is.

—Yes, where the Government is, is the right side to go. Of course, occasionally when we are busy preparing speeches for others, we want to know what legislation is immediately before the chamber. Decisions have been taken in the party room on the pros and cons of legislation and, because we are of the one mind, we are criticised by the rabble down the side. I have never heard such rubbish in all my life and I am certainly opposed to electronic voting, but not for that reason.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The next issue is disclosure of in camera evidence. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following order proposed by the Committee, at pages 2 and 3 of the report, for the disclosure of in camera evidence, be adopted:

(1) That evidence taken by a committee in camera and documents ordered by a committee to be treated as evidence taken in camera may not be disclosed in a report of the committee or in a protest, reservation or dissent added to a report of the committee without the permission of the Senate or the committee.

(2) That witnesses who have given evidence in camera, if it is practicable, be informed in advance of any proposed disclosure of the evidence and be given reasonable opportuity to object to the disclosure and to ask that particular parts of the evidence not be disclosed; that a committee give careful consideration to any objection by a witness before making its decision, and also consider disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave the evidence or who are referred to in the evidence.

(3) That, in accordance with paragraph (8) of the order of the Senate of 25 February 1988 relating to the protection of witnesses, witnesses who are to give evidence in camera be advised in writing, before giving evidence, that the evidence may be disclosed by the committee or the Senate.

This is likely to generate probably a little more debate and passion than some of the other motions. To some extent there are two competing principles running side by side, both of which one would like to endorse-that is, the general principle that in camera evidence not be disclosed because, if in the end, it is realised that disclosure is likely, we can give away in camera evidence as no-one will come and give it, and a lot of committee work and its effectiveness will be debilitated. On the other hand, we have the principle involved of the rights of minorities and whether we can ever allow a majority to overrule a minority from putting forward its views. That is also a very strong principle. We have had those two principles running neck and neck throughout all this and quite often the debate overlapping and getting confused between the two principles. At the same time, overlapping all that, we have had some very partisan issues which also overlap into this whole debate. The Standing Committee on Procedure considered all this-

TALK.START.PARA: —What were those two issues?
—I think drugs in sport was one and the National Crime Authority (NCA) was the other. They are the two that filtered through to me. I was never central to either debate, Senator.
—I am interested to hear you say that drugs in sport was partisan. That was the view I got at the end of the day. Some were for it and some against.

—What I am saying, Senator, is that the lofty principles after a while became tribalised to some extent and it was very hard then to take oneself back to see where the principle lay and where the self-justification of the combatants lay. The Procedure Committee did not agree on this particular matter but thought it best to put forward a resolution, supported by some, and an alternative resolution-I think is the best way to put it-by others. That is where it stands at the moment. They are not easy issues to resolve because of competing principles et cetera.

SPEECH.PARA: I have considerable doubt where it will end up if none of these motions are carried today. I have had to indicate publicly from this side of the chamber on one or two occasions that if there is not a degree of protection for in camera evidence, no committee that we control will hear in camera evidence and if a committee hears in camera evidence that we do not control, we will not participate in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that is going to be your position in the future?

—That is a Party position adopted last year, with this qualification, until this matter was resolved in this chamber. Today it can be resolved and, naturally, whichever way it is resolved, we would then abide by that resolution, be it the one I put forward on behalf of the Committee or be it the one that Senator Hill puts forward. That at least will clarify the position and we can all go on from there with all its weaknesses.
—Are you saying that is your present position, that you will not sit on committees that you do not have the numbers to carry the-
—That was a position that was adopted. It creates some problems with one or two committees that were exempted. I will not go into those committees but they are more in the security area.

SPEECH.PARA: So, Mr Deputy President, as I say, I have not been centrally involved in these particular arguments. The principle being most pushed by the motion that I have moved is the paramountcy of protecting in camera evidence. I do acknowledge that other principles run through this, and measuring them and balancing them off is not an easy task. That is a task which I charge the Senate with this morning. I hope the debate can be approached in a more detached way maybe than some of the previous discussions around this particular issue. I hope that people do not bring up history too much and that we do not divide on the basis of `because that has been brought up we will all tribalise and go off in our own particular directions'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to start this debate off. I think it is going to be a very long one. As Senator Robert Ray said, it certainly is a very vexed question. Committees always prefer to take evidence in public on the public record. Witnesses appearing before committees are always advised that that is the preferred course. But there are times when the wishes of the witness and the interests of the committee are best served by preserving some degree of confidentiality on the evidence given. That then becomes in camera evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Witnesses have never had the right to demand that in camera evidence stays in camera or secret. On all the committees on which I have served, witnesses have always been advised by the chairman that there is no absolute control over the evidence once it has been given but that every process will be taken to try to guarantee that it remains confidential. The difficulty for a committee arises when the report has to be written. While Senate committees tend to be apolitical, they are not always apolitical and objective. But, apart from that, there is the possibility of genuine dissent amongst the members of the committee. If a member of a committee feels that he cannot agree with the majority of the report, he puts in a dissenting report. He is quite allowed to do this under the Standing Orders. That dissenting report is not subjected to investigation or approval in any way at all by the committee chairman or the rest of the committee. It is the right of the dissenting senator to make that report and to have it attached to the report of the committee.

A central part of the dissent or a supporting part of the argument which leads the senator to dissent may be based on in camera evidence. If he cannot refer to that evidence the argument looks weak; it looks hypothetical; it looks unconvincing.

I have served on committees in this Senate for 13 years. I have never been in the position where I had to use in camera evidence to support a dissenting report. In fact, I have been party to very few dissenting reports on the committees on which I have served. But I can see that it is a reality and the problem for the Senate is to overcome this difficulty when evidence is given. While the majority of the committee may not accept that evidence as being germane to the conclusions of the committee, there is a very real case for that dissenting member to have the right to use that information.

It is more than the right of the committee to have a report on the table that reflects both the majority and minority point of view; it is the right of the Parliament to gain information which is an absolutely fundamental issue in our democratic system. This Parliament is the highest court in the land.

About the only point in Senator Ray's opening remarks that I would differ with is the claim he made that we ought to give away in camera evidence. That simply is not possible because many of the terms of appointment under which the more important committees and the major committees of this Parliament and this Senate are set up contain words which in effect allow the committee to summon witnesses and documents to appear before it. Translated into plain English, it means that those committees which have this power as the term of their appointment have the right to call before them any witness, whether it is a public servant or a private individual and compel that person to give evidence. If that power of compulsion is involved it then becomes illogical for us to say in the lesser case, where administratively it is convenient, `We cannot have in camera evidence'.

I support the basic contention that we should not use in camera evidence except where it is really necessary. At the end of the day, although we caution the witnesses that the committee may choose to publish in camera evidence, there is another practical problem involved in maintaining secrecy; that is, simply the fact that the evidence given is always printed in Hansard. We all have staff in our offices, and we all have visitors. Hansards arrive in our offices from committees and they have `In Camera Evidence' or some declaration on the front cover which indicates that they are confidential. When one has been around for a number of years, there will be a heap of these on the shelves and, with the best will in the world, it is very hard to maintain security and confidentiality. The possibility that in camera evidence can leak out is very real. In my personal experience, the only way that can be avoided-this is the case on one committee I am on, the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation-is to have a safe and lock up the material. That is certainly not the general practice throughout the Parliament, and I do not believe it is a practical way to go.

I support the view of my colleagues on the Procedure Committee. I must say that the vote was won by the narrowest of margins; it was won by the traditional margin of the Government having one vote more than the other members on the Committee. The view of those who dissented with the Procedure Committee report is incorporated on page 4. It states:

A dissenting Senator who wishes to refer to in camera evidence should advise the committee of the evidence concerned, and all reasonable effort should be made by the committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of the evidence for that purpose. If agreement is not reached, the dissenting Senator may refer to the in camera evidence in the dissent only to the extent necessary to support the reasoning of the dissent.

It is some months since we debated this in the Procedure Committee meeting, and on reflection I am more convinced that that is the reasonable approach this chamber should take. We should take every step we can on committees to restrict the amount of in camera evidence collected, but where it is collected and there is a genuine dissent, then I believe it is impossible to deny the dissenting member of the committee access to that information because it forms an essential part of his argument. Furthermore, it strikes at the fundamental principle of the right of the Parliament and for the Parliament's substitute, the people of Australia, to know, through the medium of committee inquiries, what is going on in the country with the issues that are so important that they are before the committee for investigation. On those grounds, I believe that the Senate has no option but to support the view that is incorporated on page 4 of the Procedure Committee report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also grateful to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) for outlining the two competing principles so clearly at the beginning of this debate. I think there would be no lack of agreement in this chamber that these are important competing principles. The right of honourable senators to have a dissenting view and to participate in debate in this chamber, putting forward this dissenting view is one. The other is that we must, to the extent possible, protect the confidentiality of information provided by witnesses, either oral evidence or in writing.
—That is when it should not be confidential. There are occasions when confidential information is given which does not deserve the status of being confidential.

—I will come to that later. If evidence is given in camera, there seems to be a prima facie expectation by the witness that the evidence will remain in camera. It is therefore important at every meeting-I believe that this has not been done at every committee meeting-to inform witnesses that despite the fact that their evidence is being taken in camera, they run the risk that it may subsequently be disclosed should the need arise.

SPEECH.PARA: During the Procedure Committee hearing, the Australian Democrats' representative voted with the Opposition parties against the concept that was put forward by the Minister today which, in effect, says that the Government may at any stage ensure that a dissenting view is not put if it is based on in camera evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a total misrepresentation.
—The relevant sentence reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That evidence taken by a committee in camera and documents ordered by a committee to be treated as evidence taken in camera may not be disclosed in a report of the committee or in a protest, reservation or dissent added to a report of the committee without the permission of the Senate or the committee.

The reality is that the Government commands the majority on the committee. Therefore, in a situation where we are dealing with a committee report, Executive Government may ensure that the dissenting report is not disclosed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says, `or the Senate'. Have a look at it.
—I have had a look at it.
—The Government does not control the Senate. So you have a let out.

—Indeed, but in the first instance the Government can stop it at the committee level. The Democrats' position remains-we will not allow the Government to adopt that particular position. We believe that the alternative version being put forward by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) is the preferable one; that is, all reasonable effort should be made by the committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of evidence for that purpose. Further, that witnesses, having given evidence in camera, should be advised of the proposal to disclose such evidence and should be given every opportunity to put their case for the committee to consider before final agreement is worked out.

SPEECH.PARA: No doubt, in some areas there are matters which should be kept confidential. I refer to the secrecy provisions of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority which have given rise to a lot of comment both within the Committee and in public in recent months. It is quite clear that if the National Crime Authority Committee is to continue its work, then the secrecy provisions must be lifted. At the same time, it is also clear that in this way some of the information could reach the public and could be detrimental to the administration of justice in the country and to the rights of individuals. The way out is to amend the legislation and to ensure that certain types of information, which in this way could be detrimental to either individuals or the administration of justice, are kept confidential by law rather than by the decision of the Executive Government in committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I strongly support the motion moved by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). I object to the whole concept of in camera evidence because I think there is a problem receiving it. What is the use of getting in camera evidence if that evidence cannot be used? That is one of the problems that we have. If we hear evidence in camera, how can we put it out of our minds and not let it colour our thinking?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crichton-Browne referred to his judgment that certain evidence taken in camera does not deserve to be in camera. What a ridiculous position to take. If the committee makes a decision that evidence should be taken in camera, that is the decision of the committee. One can argue in theory that the evidence does not belong to an individual senator who is a member of the committee, but belongs to the committee and, through the committee, to the Senate, so it ought to be the committee or the Senate which makes a decision about the use of the information.

I have been on committees and I have chaired committees in the past when evidence has been taken in camera, and I am totally convinced by that experience that taking evidence in camera is more trouble than it is worth. Senator Reid is reported in the Procedure Committee report as suggesting that she would like the Senate to consider the question of requiring a witness's consent before publishing in camera evidence. I understand that position. However, at the same time she is one of those reported as supporting the alternative proposal, which allows the committee to go ahead and publish evidence after the witnesses have had a chance to give their opinion about the release of evidence they have given in camera.

In answer to Senator Spindler, the proposal moved by the Minister includes the option of the committee or the Senate giving permission for evidence to be released so that, if one has a situation where the majority on the committee acts unreasonably, the minority on the committee can always come in here, raise it in the Senate and overcome the fact that the numbers in the Senate are not reflected in the numbers on the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —But then it is disclosed in the chamber in any case.

—It is not a matter of disclosing the evidence in the chamber, but I presume that, if the minority on the committee has a problem with the majority making a decision that in camera evidence should remain in camera and not be published as part of a dissenting report and if one managed to convince the majority of the Senate, that evidence can then be released in the dissenting report. It does not have to be actually talked about in the chamber. We are not getting into a situation like that we nearly got into last night. I think we just have to accept the situation that the committee structure is as it is; that is, for all the time that committees have existed, government has had an effective majority on the committees but that the committee can be overridden by a decision of the Senate.
—On what basis is the Senate going to make a decision if they do not know what is in camera?
—Because honourable senators convince their colleagues accordingly or they adopt some--
—So you release in camera evidence selectively to your colleagues, contrary to Standing Orders?
—I would hope not. I am talking about principles here.
—You explain it to me.
—Order! Senate Coates has the floor.
—Senate Crichton-Browne has provoked me. He is one of the main problems causing us to deal with this matter at all.
—You are a problem in the committee system.

—Yes, I am a problem. I will wear that accusation with honour, coming from Senator MacGibbon. Senator Crichton-Browne produced a minority report on the Kakadu inquiry. In that instance not only did he go ahead and publish evidence that had the status of being in camera; he also did not even provide the committee with an opportunity to argue against him or go to the extent of consulting the witnesses concerned. At least the alternative proposal, which I presume Senator Hill will move, would now provide some sort of protection in that it suggests that a dissenting senator who wishes to refer to in camera evidence should advise the committee, that all reasonable efforts should be made to reach agreement and that witnesses should, as far as practicable, be informed in advance and given reasonable opportunity to object to the disclosure. If we adopted that, it would at least prevent the sort of action that Senator Crichton-Browne took a couple of years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise that I would take the view-and I presume the Opposition in all its strictness about these things would also take the view-that the evidence is the property of the committee and, through the committee, of the Senate, and is not the property of an individual member of the committee to make a unilateral decision to reveal merely because, in the terms Senator Crichton-Browne used, he does not agree in the first place that the evidence deserved to be in camera-those were his words-or that the evidence is so compelling that it must be used in support of a dissenting report. I emphasise that the proposal which has been moved argues that permission of the committee or the Senate ought to be required. The main point is that, unless that provision is adopted, there ought to be no more taking of in camera evidence because I think it is unreasonable to those who give such evidence that they have no assurance that even the whole committee will do anything to protect that evidence. I strongly support the option moved by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Government's position in so far as it has been put by Senator Robert Ray.
—We don't have a position.

—I withdraw that. The Minister for Defence is quite right. I will not even try to get out of that one. This is a free vote. I support the position as put by Senator Ray. I do so for a couple of reasons which I would like to put on the record. Prima facie, the processes by which we operate in society are those of open government and open courts. If a witness gives evidence in court, that evidence is taken in public. Public galleries are provided to enable the public to see what is going on and to listen to what is said. In the debate today we have a gallery with some people in it. Having heard the brilliant speeches made so far, I think it is a pity that more people are not in the gallery to hear them. However, there is a gallery open to the public so that people can see what is going on here and take account of it.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot think of any situation where witnesses as a rule are heard in camera. The Executive conducts its proceedings in camera, but that is where it considers things and no witnesses are called. Why should we not accept as a primary proposition that whatever evidence is called should be heard in the open? If one is sitting on a committee and one is to use evidence to support a proposition-no matter what the proposition might be and what evidence would support tentatively the conclusions one might have-one should draw that evidence from the witnesses.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do about national security?

—If senators do not want national security endangered and think their questioning might endanger national security, they should not ask those questions unless they think that the prejudicing of national security is less a force than what they want to reveal in their judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: In that case, if the committee wants to put that proposition before the public, if it wants to talk about national security on the basis of evidence that it wants to obtain, it should obtain that evidence in the open. It seems absurd, as Senator Coates has said, that the Opposition wants to make these statements. We had a great illustration last night when Senator McLean, I would have thought, in what he was doing, was supporting the proposition that some of us are now opposing-those of us who do oppose it; I am supporting it. One could say, `Look, there is a balance to be struck and we forbid you, as a senator, to do what you want. We say that the Senate should, in those circumstances, override the individual'. As Senator Coates has said, that is what this proposition does.

It seems to me to be wanting to have one's cake and eat it at the same time to say, `I want to take evidence in camera away from the proper scrutiny of the public; away from the proper scrutiny of the press', and then to keep that evidence hidden but write a judgment or a submission based on it to be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —It could be very important evidence to a defence inquiry. What would you do about it?

—If it is an important inquiry which has to be made public, then we should not take that evidence. We have to have clearly in our minds the proposition that the reason we are taking evidence, whether it is in camera or not, is to support some submission, some proposition, that we want to put and make public. If we want to take evidence for an inquiry, for a submission, that we have to make public, then we should take that evidence in public. If we want to have a secret inquiry and deliver a secret proposition to someone, I can follow what the honourable senator says, but I would have thought it was terribly dangerous to go into in camera evidence for a start. Without putting too fine a point on it, it has a star chamber quality about it, where people give evidence in secret and action is suddenly taken in public with the statement that it is based on evidence which we have taken in camera. That is a dangerous proposition for the sort of society we want to live in.
—You would not get that evidence unless it was given to you in camera.

—That is exactly why I say that it has a star chamber quality about it. We could be saying to the people, `We will not get this evidence unless we induce it out of you by promising that it will be taken in camera, that it will be kept away from the public gaze. Having induced it, drawn it out, by this mechanism, by this device, we could then throw it open to the public. Why not tell the person, `We are going to use this evidence and you must give it.'? If the committee thinks it is proper, then it ought to insist on it rather than letting the witness give it on the false assumption that it is not going to be made public and then make it public. The courts do this every day. Many people do not want to give evidence. The courts insist they give it in public. If a committee thinks that it is proper that evidence be given, it should insist that it be given in the public arena. If we do not, as senators, have enough nous, enough ability, to get the evidence in a legitimate and proper way, then it behoves us to raise our game and not to lurk, as it were, in the secrecy of some closed chamber to get evidence out of people which is then revealed to the public gaze, to their detriment-whether by making them open to investigation by ridiculing their character, by bringing their character to disrepute, or even by embarrassing them. Why should we make them suffer all that?
—You would regard classified information in the same way if it was a defence inquiry, would you?

—I can follow what the honourable senator is saying. It seems to me that she is saying, `We ought to keep it quiet because it is a defence inquiry but, once having got it, we can then open it open to the public'. If a committee is not going to throw evidence open to the public, I do not know why it would want to get the evidence in the first place. If it is so important that evidence be kept secret and not revealed to the public-this is what we were saying to Senator McLean last night-then we ought to say so and not use it. It would be a bit like our saying to him last night, `We are not going to let you do this', but get his documents and then go out and reveal them in public ourselves. It seems to me to be a contradiction in terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition before us, quite clearly, goes along the same principles as we went along last night. One honourable senator wanted to do something; the rest of the Senate said no. That is what we all accepted last night, except for the Australian Democrats. But, with great respect to them, they are quite consistent on these matters. They are sometimes wrong, but at least they are consistent.

It seems to me that, unless we support the proposition that is put forward here, we are proceeding on principles which are very akin to the ones that we denied last night. To be consistent with that, it seems to me that we have to support this proposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put the view that is followed by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of this Parliament. That is a view that was enshrined in the statute in 1951, with certain amendments in 1976. That view, in relation to in camera evidence, has worked very satisfactorily over the years. I put that view to the Senate. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) . . . the Committee shall take all evidence in public.

(2) The Committee may, and at the request of the witness giving the evidence shall, take in private evidence, whether oral or documentary, which, in the opinion of the Committee, relates to a secret or confidential matter.
(3) Where, at the request of a witness, evidence is taken by the Committee in private-
(a) the Committee or a member shall not, without the consent in writing of the witness; and

(b) a person other than a member shall not, without the consent in writing of the witness and the authority of the Committee under sub-section (5) of this section, disclose or publish the whole or a part of the evidence (other than evidence which has already been lawfully published).
(4) Where evidence is taken by the Committee in private otherwise than-
I emphasise that-

at the request of a witness, a person (including a member of the Committee) shall not, without the authority (in writing signed by the Chairman) of the Committee under the next succeeding sub-section, disclose or publish the whole or part of that evidence (other than evidence which has already been lawfully published).

(5) The Committee may, in its discretion, disclose or publish, or authorize the disclosure or publication of, evidence taken in private, but this subsection does not operate so as to affect the necessity for the consent of a witness under sub-section (3) of this section.
Finally, it states:
(6) This section has effect notwithstanding provisions of section two of the Parliamentary Papers Act 1908-1946 .

I believe that those provisions have acted quite satisfactorily. In camera evidence is not regularly taken by the Committee, but when it is taken it is done with a great deal of discretion. We have a preference-it is a joint committee of both Houses, of all parties-that all evidence, where possible, shall be taken in public.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Along with Senator Spindler, I am thankful that Senator Robert Ray's contribution at the commencement of this debate pointed out that the two competing principles we are looking at are, on the one hand, the protection of in camera evidence and the willingness of people to come forward and give that evidence and, on the other hand, the rights of minorities. I would like to add to that by putting two points. Firstly, it may well be the case that the Parliament relies on some people coming forward, privately ringing up a committee secretary or one of the committee members and saying, `I have some information your Committee might like to have. It is very sensitive information and I would like to give it in camera'.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is an extensive misuse of in camera evidence, it is possible that those sorts of people will not come forward. I can see that. In any event it is not my view that there has been a misuse of in camera evidence, so I do not think that we can look at the history and say that this Parliament or this chamber has led the community to believe that Parliament cannot be trusted. Sure, there have been occasions when in camera evidence has been released. Sure, there have been some that I would not agree with and there would be some that those opposite would not agreed with. But I do not think that by and large the Australian community has formed the view that Parliament cannot be trusted with the information given to it.

I do not see a need-nobody has raised it with me-for greater protection of in camera evidence in the first place. No-one has made a case for misuse of in camera evidence. I can think of examples that some might like to use. I would be happy to have more extensive debate with them on those matters on another day. I simply make the point that there is not a view in the community that Parliament cannot be trusted. That case has not been made.

I would like to extend the other principle mentioned by Senator Robert Ray about the rights of minorities being protected and say that, while that is one element of the other side of the case, the element that is missing, if it is phrased simply as `We have to protect the rights of minorities to speak', is that we have to protect the role of Parliament controlling the Executive. That is really what gets cut off if the Executive is given the power to control what information Parliament has. I see that as part of my job. We are all elected here by the same quota in our respective States and we are all elected to contribute to watching what the Executive is doing and calling it to answer for its actions, either in the past or intended expenditures in the future. That is the role that we all have here.

What complicates this is that we do not have a system such as that in the United States of America where the Executive is outside Parliament. Some in here are members of the Executive and they do not serve on these committees. But the sad fact is that more and more with the two and one-tenth party system, more and more members of parliament who are members of the party which holds government feel obliged to follow the wishes of their Executive. It certainly happens on the other side of Parliament more than it does on this side of Parliament, but I do not pretend that it does not happen on this side. There is a very strong expectation and substantial pressure on the members of the party in government to support what their government, the Executive, wants to do.

Parliament sets up these committees. We already give the party that has government in the lower House the majority on those committees. I would have thought that that was already a pretty good slice given to those who by and large would support the Executive. A case has not been made out to reduce further the powers available to those who oppose the Executive-whether they be members of the party in government, the party in opposition, the Australian Democrats or the Independents-or to further neuter the role that parliamentarians can play in scrutinising the Executive. It is not just a simple case of protecting in camera evidence and the rights of minorities. This is just another chink in the armour of Parliament; another protecting wall around the Executive.

The case has been put by speakers I think on both sides that there should by and large be a preference to hear all evidence in public. I agree with that. There should be very rare exceptions to this when this Parliament shifts under what one of Senator Crowley's colleagues in the lower House, Mr Melham, refers to as `the cover of darkness'. That is the kind of terminology that Mr Melham likes to use. But they are very rare occasions. We should think very carefully before we shut the doors and say to the public, `You are not seeing the work that your Parliament is doing'. To that extent, I agree with Senator Coates and speakers on the other side who have made that point.

However, there are a number of problems. There are some committees for whom that is simply not practicable. For example, it is simply not practicable for the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority to hold a large number of its hearings in public. We have been doing so at the moment for the evaluation of the National Crime Authority (NCA). That has been a good and productive exercise. It is not yet finished. Members of the public, journalists, academics and anybody else with a view have been invited to come forward and put their views on the operation of the NCA. And they have done that in public. That has been a good exercise for the Parliament, the Committee and, with the greatest respect for it, the Authority. However, when the Committee is engaging in its normal task, the task which it is primarily charged with, that is, overseeing the functions of the Authority, it is simply not practicable to say, `We'll have an open hearing' and every 10 minutes have someone from the Authority say, `Now I want to tell you something that relates to a matter that shouldn't be revealed to the public' and then shut the hearing down again. By and large, that Committee hears nearly all its evidence in camera.

Owing to other problems that arise from the drafting of the National Crime Authority Act, referred to by Senator Spindler earlier, previously constituted NCA committees have not always had meetings that they thought were productive. I do not think that they were told anything at some of these meetings that should not have been on the public record. But of course those meetings are held as private meetings and the evidence is treated as in camera evidence so as to protect the flow of information, such as it is, between the Authority and the Committee. If the Authority wants to say something that it prefers that the public not hear about, it can. That is a sensible way for that Committee to operate-to have all its hearings with the Authority in camera so as to protect that evidence which should be treated that way; otherwise we would be chopping and changing from one minute to the next.

Where does that put a member of the NCA Committee when a report is produced and the member wants to release some of that information, which is in a legalistic sense in camera evidence but is not evidence that, if the Committee were able to consider bit by bit, would be given the imprimatur of in camera evidence; in other words, it is totally inconsequential to the operation of the NCA or any of its witnesses or whatever? This evidence might relate simply to the administration or maladministration of that body. That evidence is in camera evidence. Under the proposals put forward by the Government a senator would have to seek permission from the government members of the National Crime Authority Committee to release that information.

Whether my view is appropriate I do not know but I have formed the view that, on one occasion had the Government members been able to read a dissenting report, they would have simply decided not to report. Without wanting to colour it too much, I say that that is the tyranny of the Executive, which has the capacity to decide that, if it does not want Parliament to know something, it will simply refuse to report. There is then no dissenting report in which, for instance, I, Senator Spindler or Senator Bell can air our views. What does a senator then do? It is a dreadful situation. The Government is suggesting that we come in here and ask the chamber whether this information can be released.

Last night we saw Senator McLean stumbling along trying to get permission from the Senate to release some information, without his being able to tell us what information he wanted released. That is exactly the situation every senator will be put in when he or she wants to release some in camera evidence. Senators will have to come to this chamber, make a case for releasing A, B or C, without telling the Senate what A, B and C are. It is an almost impossible task and a fence should not be put around senators in that way.

My case relates to the position of a senator who believes a committee has in its possession material of which Parliament should be aware and about which the committee says, `No, there is no need to tell Parliament that', or, `We do not want to tell Parliament that'. That will put senators in a very difficult position. They will have to fight an uphill battle to tell Parliament what they have found out, possibly about what the Executive is doing. The reason senators have such a difficult task is that primarily the majority on the committee is held by members of the party which forms the Executive. With the best goodwill in the world, it simply will not work. The Executive will say, `This is too embarrassing. We are not going to release this information'. It will drum up every reason under the sun as to why the information should not be released.

My friend Senator Cooney says, `Why take the evidence in camera if you then intend to make it public, tarnish people's reputations, embarrass them, and heaven knows what?'. There is a very good reason why, on limited occasions, we should take evidence in camera. A person putting forward the evidence may believe that it will put somebody's life, limb or reputation at risk. Surely when a witness comes before a Senate committee and says, `I have something to tell you but I think that it will put somebody's life, limb or reputation at risk', the committee would not refuse the opportunity of hearing that person in camera so that it can weigh up the effect of the evidence that is offered.

Taking evidence in camera allows a committee time to reflect on what the person will say. It gives the committee the opportunity of depriving a public forum to those who would come before it to unfairly malign somebody's character. In other words, it gives the committee some discretion to consider the matter and then, after proper reflection, to release the information that the Parliament needs. I say that Parliament needs to know--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not saying it. You are saying that one member is saying it.

—At the moment I am referring to the whole committee. When I say that Parliament needs to know, I do not mean that the only information that a committee should put before Parliament is that which it needs. It allows the committee to decide which information would, if released, put somebody's life, limb or reputation at risk. That is the reason normal Senate committees, other than the security related ones which should have more frequent access to in camera evidence, should take evidence in camera.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already put forward the view that I have been a part of a committee whose report was issued last year, which had attached to it a dissenting report that contained some in camera evidence. I and the other signatories to that dissenting report put up, I think quite patiently, with an enormous amount of abuse from certain members of parliament for having taken such a course. I do not want to rehash the whole matter, though I would be happy to do so if the Senate wishes. However, it does not seem germane to this debate.

I am simply saying that I do not think there is one piece of information or evidence released in the dissenting report relating to the National Crime Authority (NCA) on Operation Ark which should not or could not have been taken in public. There was nothing in there that related to an operational matter of the NCA at all. That evidence was taken in camera only because that is the way in which the Joint Standing Committee on the National Crime Authority needs to meet to function properly, and to provide the opportunity for very sensitive material to be given over. All material is heard in camera. All that report did was to show what a disastrous case of maladministration was going on in South Australia. I defy anyone to tell me why this Parliament ought not know that. It is a ridiculous situation.

I conclude by saying that senators on the other side involved in that particular NCA report were quick to jump to their feet and say what a dreadful deed had been done. I do not think that it was dreadful to tell Parliament what it ought to know. But there has been a peculiar silence since the Brisbane meeting of that Committee. At that meeting the Chairman of the Committee did something inadvertently, I believe. I attribute no bad faith to him, at least in this respect; and I do not say that to mean that I attribute bad faith in any other respect either. I simply qualify my remark to mean that it was not a blanket endorsement of Mr Lindsay. I say that to clarify my position. I am trying to do Mr Lindsay a favour by saying that I believe it was inadvertent. On a number of occasions during a public hearing-with cameras, recorders and everything else present-he proceeded to quote from some in camera evidence of the Committee. It was not evidence taken when I was on the Committee-I think it was a couple of years ago. I could not give the date; it does not matter. The evidence was taken by a previously constituted parliamentary committee on the NCA.

We had a witness before us and Mr Lindsay said, `Well, in 1900-and-blah you said blah. Let me read it to you, let me quote it'. It was colourful language, basically. Pretty well on each occasion the witness looked a bit embarrassed and said, `Well, I might not use language like that now, but the substance of what I said then is still my view', or words to that effect. The witness looked a little uncomfortable about this. I pointed out to the Secretary that my copy of this previous evidence had `In Camera' stamped all over it. I asked whether anything had happened in the meantime that made the evidence no longer in camera. My understanding is that the only time one can release in camera evidence is in a report or a dissenting report, certainly not just on an adjournment debate, at a public hearing or whatever.

Having had this pointed out, the Chairman did not raise the matter with me and, as I understand it-and I have spoken to Senator Spindler about it-he did not raise it with Senator Spindler. It was a bit difficult because the only people meeting on that occasion were myself, Senator Loosley and the Chairman-we were meeting as a sub-committee. Following the morning tea break, I was indisposed for five or six minutes. I farewelled Senator Loosley and the Chairman and said, `I am going to the bathroom. I will be back in about six minutes'. During that time this witness was called back and was told, I understand, that the Committee had decided his evidence should be made public. He was asked whether he had any objections. He said that he had no objection. So, not just the paragraphs that had been quoted by Mr Lindsay but the evidence holus bolus was then printed up and released for publication. This was something that was done inadvertently, by mistake, I believe. But if we want to talk about courtesies to committee members, no courtesy was shown. I read that the Chairman told this witness that the Committee `had decided'.

Since this hearing I have been waiting for the Chairman to explain to members of the Committee how he osmosed their views into his mind-it certainly was not by a formal meeting of the Committee, there were only four people there. That subcommittee was not charged with the responsibility of deciding whether in camera evidence would be released or not, and the release of that evidence has caused some difficulty for a number of people. I was not there when this happened-Senator Loosley might be able to explain-but I understand that at some Sydney hearings someone who got hold of this in camera evidence wanted to take it a little further.

If we want to talk about what is going to happen with in camera evidence, and how careful we have to be with it, I would like to hear from some Government members about why there has been no explanation about what happened with this particular matter in relation to the NCA Committee. It is an absolutely disastrous situation-I hesitate to say it is an appalling situation-where the Chairman of a committee says to a witness that the committee has decided something and the committee, clearly, has not decided that. I hesitate to say that it is an even more appalling situation when such a mess-up is made that the Chairman, on numerous occasions since then, has declined the opportunity to explain to the Committee what a mess-up he has made of it.

In summary, I think the occasions on which in camera evidence is taken should be very rare. For some committees it is simply not practicable to do that regularly, and I use the NCA Committee as an example.

My view is that the judgment of what should come before parliament should be made by individual senators. There should be no need to go and ask the majority. We all know that, by and large, the majority will go along with the Executive and we expect that to be the case. Executive control of the committees means that those committees will not inform parliament as properly as they should, and as properly as they now can, of what parliament ought to know.

The alternative proposed by the Procedure Committee-not by the Government-is too much of an uphill battle. To come into the chamber and get permission to release A, B and C, without being able to tell the chamber what A, B and C is, is absolutely fanciful.

I conclude by reminding honourable senators that we are all elected by the same proportion of people in our States. We are all charged with the responsibility of making decisions about when information should come before parliament and when it should not. This should not be the task of the majority of the committee at all; it is the responsibility of each honourable senator, and that is the way it should be left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the recommendation of the Standing Committee on Procedure to deal with this vexed question of in camera evidence. It is vexed because, clearly, the procedures at the moment are not working effectively. There is a degree of confusion about the manner in which committees are operating and ought to operate, and about the manner in which evidence may be released in reports to the Senate. If we look at the practical circumstance now, there is no doubt in my mind that we do require some sensible proposals for change. I believe that in the proposals before the Senate this morning, those reasonable proposals have emerged.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently, we have the circumstance in which committees do take evidence in camera, but the procedure is far from satisfactory; indeed, I go so far as to say that it is most unsatisfactory. No guarantee may be given on behalf of a committee to the witness involved that confidentiality will be respected; no guarantee can be given to the witness before the committee that the material being furnished to the committee in its deliberations, supposedly classified as in camera, will not appear at some future stage in a majority or dissenting report. That, obviously, leads to a conclusion whereby people will feel inhibited about the material which they are able to give to the committee. That really is unsatisfactory in terms of making sure that deliberations are thorough and founded on exhaustive examination of evidence.

Currently, given the fact that no guarantee may be given to a witness, the term `in camera' means absolutely nothing. There is no process guaranteeing confidentiality; there is no practical application of the term-the term has no practical effect. As a matter of fact, as a Senate, we now have the worst of all worlds. It is unfair to witnesses; it is confusing for witnesses and for committee personnel. As a matter of fact, it reduces the procedures of Senate committees-indeed, of joint committees-to something akin to farce. How can bodies take in camera evidence and then find a day, a week or a month later that the material has found its way onto the public record for whatever reason?

The proposition that has come from the Procedure Committee, as outlined by Senator Robert Ray and supported by Senator Coates and Senator Cooney, endeavours to address these dilemmas. It addresses the dilemmas in three succinct parts. I would argue to the Senate this morning that the manner in which the Procedure Committee has chosen to address matters is fair, it is reasonable and it is practical.

The first part of the recommendation addresses the need for confidentiality. I would not have thought that that was in doubt anywhere in the chamber. Earlier I think Senator Newman raised the issue of national security. It is a fair point. There are going to be occasions where there will be a need for secrecy and for the attendant responsibility for matters of grave concern affecting, say, the administration of justice, the defence forces, international obligations and, from time to time, perhaps even commercial matters in confidence. No-one doubts that from time to time there will be a need for confidentiality.
Secondly, it is fair to witnesses--

TALK.START.PARA: —Has that been a problem thus far?

—I will respond to Senator Crichton-Browne. It has been a problem to date, and I will say something about that in a moment or so. I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for the intervention, it has served to highlight the dimensions of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of current circumstances, witnesses have no clear idea of what they are able to say, and the material they are able to furnish in absolute confidence. If the Procedure Committee's recommendations are adopted witnesses will, indeed, know precisely the basis on which they are giving evidence, they will know precisely where they stand, and that is a dramatic change from the present.

As a serving member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority-and I have no wish to canvass again issues that have been raised about the NCA Committee in the chamber-I think there is no doubt that, from time to time, the Committee would be best served by ensuring that any person with material to assist the Committee in its deliberations is prepared to come forward.

The NCA Committee, as with other committees of the Parliament-the Joint Committee on the Australian Security Intelligence Organization and committees on defence and foreign affairs-by virtue of their charters and their obligations are required to deal with extraordinarily sensitive matters. We simply cannot have a situation in which witnesses may be deterred from coming forward to give evidence to the Parliament. For reasons of personal safety, witnesses may be frightened of coming forward and may be deterred from coming forward on the basis of potential retribution either in their professions, occupations, or in their personal circumstances. In that respect it is simply untenable to argue that this is a matter whereby the recommendations would serve solely to protect the interests of Executive Government.

Within the Westminster system there is a long and honourable tradition of whistle blowers, people who have identified problems in administration, and from time to time maladministration. We will not have the whistle blowers coming forward if this situation of confusion about in camera evidence is allowed to continue. It is also fair comment that the recommendations from the Procedure Committee are practical. They lay down clear and comprehensive guidelines-guidelines that are currently lacking.

The recommendations build a mechanism for the advice of witnesses prior to giving evidence. If the recommendations are adopted by the Senate today we will not have a circumstance in which in camera evidence can be disclosed in the future on whim or capriciously. The only means by which in camera evidence can be disclosed will be by agreement after a process of deliberation. If we look through the recommendations, we see that that process is exhaustive. That process will occur on the basis of a series of decisions after evaluation by the people concerned, the people who serve on the committee-not only from the Government but from the Opposition parties, the Democrats and Independents-and there is provision to involve the witnesses concerned as well.

The procedure sets down a clear means by which senators, whether from Government or Opposition, can use sensitive material in a dissenting report. That option is not closed. As a matter of fact, the option becomes available on the basis of agreement. An avenue is established for achieving the capacity to sustain an argument in a dissenting report with the use of in camera evidence. That is not something that is available to any senator by agreement at the moment. I find that procedure absolutely reasonable. Even where agreement cannot be reached, there is provision in these recommendations for advancing an argument without breaching confidence-in other words, without breaching consideration of honour, the capacity is still there to mount and sustain an argument.

I am sorry that Senator Vanstone had to leave the chamber for another commitment. She was good enough to pass me a note apologising for that. I did want to take up one or two points that she made and to take issue with them by way of the arguments. I said earlier that I was grateful for the intervention by Senator Crichton-Browne as to whether a problem exists. A problem does exist. If a problem did not exist we would not be having this debate this morning to address the circumstance. It does not require a circumstance of extensive abuse or misuse of in camera evidence. In fact, the contrary applies. As the Senate knows only too well, a single instance of misuse or abuse of in camera evidence causes a problem to develop. A single instance whereby the use of in camera evidence is challenged in the chamber causes a problem to develop. Putting the most generous interpretation on the use of in camera evidence in the Parliament to date, it is fair to say that that use of in camera evidence has been challenged at an absolute minimum.

A single instance only whereby in camera evidence is used and called into question creates a problem. The problem goes beyond the simple argument here today. It serves to jeopardise confidence in the workings of the committee system of the Parliament, the joint committees and the Senate standing committees. Frankly, that is too precious to place in jeopardy. It is not only something of which this chamber can be proud; it is something of which parliamentary democracy can be proud. In my view, it has to be guarded very jealously. That confidence in our system needs to be maintained.
