To date there is no question in my mind that the use of in camera evidence will cause some witnesses to be wary. I see that on the NCA Committee, for example. The Chairman, Mr Lindsay-I will say one or two other words about Mr Lindsay in a moment-advises witnesses of the circumstances in which they are giving evidence to the Committee and draws their attention to the fact that, while there is provision for in camera evidence to be taken, no guarantee of confidentiality may be given by the Committee. There is no doubt that that has an impact. It just causes people to be more guarded in what they say. I do not think that is particularly healthy. It is simply a matter of human nature rather than procedure.

Senator Vanstone spoke at length about Executive Government, scrutiny of Executive Government and the need to make certain that there are not problems of maladministration. I can agree with a number of things that she said. I do not see this debate as a matter of Executive Government as against the Parliament. I do not see this as a matter of partisanship or of a definition on party lines. While, in my view, it has nothing to do with partisanship, it does have everything to do with the effective working of our committee system. Given the range of obligations of the Australian Parliament, that is something that must be maintained in excellent working order. I think that the recommendations of the Procedure Committee before us today serve to enhance our capacity to achieve that objective.

The recommendations also have everything to do with establishing reasonable procedures and with guaranteeing fair play-fair not only to the Parliament and to individual senators but also fair to people who appear before committees and who participate in their deliberations. I wanted to make the point at this stage about care and responsibility. That comes back to the obligations of members of parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Individually.
—As a collective.
—Individually they become collective.

—As a collective-all of us. Again, I thank Senator Crichton-Browne for his intervention. Those obligations include care in taking evidence, care in enabling people to give in camera evidence, care in agreeing that the committee should meet in camera, and care in acknowledging that some material should be furnished only in camera-and then responsibility in using it, responsibility in ensuring that that in camera evidence is not misused, responsibility in ensuring that the guarantee of confidentiality is not broken, and responsibility in ensuring that the honour of the Parliament is not stained.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the Committee on the NCA, I was present at the meeting in Brisbane to which Senator Vanstone referred. There was a decision of the Committee to release some evidence taken a couple of years earlier. That was done with the agreement of the witness; it was done at the request of the Chair; it was done openly; and I do not believe it excites the controversy to which Senator Vanstone alluded.

A short while ago I had the opportunity of speaking briefly with Senator Watson, who raised a point earlier in the debate and privately with me about the need for consistency-and I think he is absolutely right. He drew attention to the procedures of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which are very clear, very strict and very comprehensive and, in my brief experience on that Committee and from what other people who have had a much longer period of service on the PAC have told me, are seen to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better put him on a few other committees so that he gets more experience.
—Indeed, he would be a most valuable asset on other committees of the Parliament.
—I would be glad to have him.

—So would I, perhaps in replacement for one or two others. The PAC operates effectively and well and that is not just a recent history, that is the history of some years. I understand that Senator Watson is drafting an amendment which would give practical effect to the suggestion he has made and that there would be a very strict procedure for the release of in camera evidence on the basis of agreement with the Committee and agreement with the witness. This would put matters beyond doubt and that is certainly an amendment to which the Senate ought to give particularly careful consideration given that that would define the procedure in a very comprehensive sense.

SPEECH.PARA: In summation, I do not believe that this vexed question can simply be left to individual senators or to individual witnesses. It has to be a collective responsibility of the Parliament, of every senator, of every committee and of everyone who participates in the committee process. It is a matter whereby we need to establish a deliberate and fair procedure. The Procedure Committee has outlined precisely that. It involves the witnesses, it involves senators and it involves the committees. If we adopt the recommendations that are before us, if we look to the kind of outcome that Senator Watson is suggesting, we will not need to have this debate in the future; there will be an agreed procedure, the business of the Parliament will be improved, the deliberative process of the committees will be improved and we will not have the controversy that we have had over recent times. That controversy has not served the interests of anyone, be that person an individual senator from the Government or from the Opposition, or of the Parliament itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by saying that I did not claim to be misrepresented at the time Senator Coates spoke. It is really becoming something of a habit of his and it is tedious to get up and do all of these things as they are put.
—We thought it was a habit of yours, Senator.

—I do not claim to be perfect. Senator Coates claimed, in a rather impertinent and uninformed way, that I had released in camera evidence improperly without the consent of the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure, which goes to the heart of the arrogance of the argument put by the Government, and that I had not consulted the witnesses, which again goes to the impertinence of the Government because there is no provision for either. Senator Coates cannot cope with a minority report. It is always the left wing libertarians, who claim to be the social conscience of individuals, who trample on them the first moment they dare utter independence.

SPEECH.PARA: I go for a moment to the matters which first precipitated this debate. This debate was caused by Senator Zakharov referring this item to the Procedure Committee and it flows from the inquiry of the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts into the resource potential of the Kakadu National Park. During that inquiry the Committee took evidence from the elders of the Jawoyn people. They included the senior elders-Nipper Brown, Sandy Barraway and Peter Jatbula and those who were identified as being the responsible elders. That hearing, notwithstanding the ignorance in which Senator Coates continues to bask, was not in camera. It was a private meeting to the extent that it was meant to help the witnesses, not to hide their evidence.

We were concerned to ensure that the right environment existed to allow the elders to feel relaxed, comfortable and confident in their presentation. We said to them that we would discourage the public from trampling on the hearing and that they should feel free because it would be only them and us. It was not in camera, it was not intended that their evidence should not be made public; it was intended simply to create the right environment so they should feel confident when they were giving the evidence-something that most sensitive people would understand, not the arrogant and the ignorant perhaps. That was the basis of the decision that evidence was never given in camera.

When I used part of that evidence to support my minority report there was much outrage by members of the Government, fundamentally because the majority of the report was not substantiated by the evidence but the minority report was. That caused some heartache, some embarrassment and some anxiety on the part of the Government. I did not disclose all of the evidence. I disclosed that which was relevant to the prosecution of my argument. However, on 5 June 1989 on pages 9, 10, 11 and 12 of the Hansard we can see where Senator Zakharov sought permission from the Senate to table in camera evidence-not in support of the report, because the evidence clearly has to be included with the report, but subsequent to the report. For what reason? She was seeking to argue against my minority report. In other words, she felt free and uninhibited in tabling what she herself called in camera evidence to prosecute her argument. Now we have this sanctimonious claptrap, this humbug, about in camera evidence and concern for witnesses. It is absolute rubbish.

TALK.START.PARA: —You certainly do not have any concern-we agree with that.
—If Senator Richardson can find a case where I have disclosed in camera evidence in an improper way I would be very interested to see him jump to his feet and do so.
—We may define `improperly' differently.

—I fear we will; I hope we will not. The Government is proposing that we have in camera evidence released only on the motion of the Committee or of the Senate. This simply means that there will be no capacity for a minority report because the government of the day, which will have the numbers on the Committee, will dictate what will go into the minority report. It is not an unreasonable argument that if committee members cannot substantiate their report by fact and by evidence the findings are wanting. So they should gut the report because they will be able to point to no evidence to substantiate what they are saying. That is the fundamental problem.
—It would at least be courteous to tell the Committee first.
—If Senator Coates can find something in the Standing Orders, notwithstanding his pedantic endeavours, I ask him to point it out to me.
—I didn't say Standing Orders; I said `courteous'.

—The courtesy that is extended is to notify the Chairman of one's intention to prepare a minority report, not to give the substance of it. I will tell the Senate, for Senator Coates's information, the reason that minority reports and their substance are not required to be advised to the majority. We recently had a case in respect of the National Crime Authority (NCA) where there was some in camera evidence provided in the minority report. When that became apparent to the Government members there was contemplation about withdrawing the proposal to table a report at all. That would have been done to prevent there being a minority report and the reason for doing that would be to prevent the disclosure of in camera evidence. That is the reason, if we are talking about courtesy-that the minority reports are not vetted or approved by the Government or the majority of the Committee. I think Senator Cooney is right. There is a compelling argument for having the overwhelming majority of evidence given on the public record. It ought only be in special circumstances where evidence is heard in camera.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is that there has been a growing temptation these days for committees to become more and more obsequious towards witnesses. Whenever a witness comes forward and requests to give his evidence in camera, there is a general temptation to agree to that. Once the evidence is in camera it is locked in. The problem, of course, is that there is only one way it can get out again and that is if the Committee says so. If we wanted to be half clever and we had both the numbers on the committee and were in government, and it was a contentious, controversial inquiry, we would take all the evidence in camera, and this would ensure there was no minority report.

We all know the problems of treating evidence in camera. Senator Cooney made the point about star chambers. That is the whole point. Senator Cooney is a lawyer and knows better than most that the reason the courts are open to the public is not to demonstrate that justice is being done but that it is seen to be done so that the findings, the penalties, the conclusions, the decisions and the determinations of the judiciary are exposed to public scrutiny. Now, if we are going to have committees bringing down findings, recommendations and conclusions which are not substantiated by evidence, we throw into disrepute the workings of the Senate and the various committees.

I find it remarkable that we have the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, which is concerned for the individual rights of people, suggesting that the evidence is locked up and it is only the findings that are released. In the same way, royal commissions are not held in camera by and large and almost every single royal commissioner will say from the outset that it is his intention to have as much evidence as possible on the public record-for exactly that reason.

Recently, the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, the Honourable Justice Phillips, agreed to my amendment of the National Crime Authority Act because he was concerned that the reputation of the NCA was falling into disrepute because of the veil of secrecy in which that authority was shrouded. There was no public accountability, no public scrutiny and no exposure of the workings of the Authority. Justice Phillips recognised that and he now proposes-mark this-to support the thrust of a proposal of the Australian Democrats, through Senator Spindler, that in camera evidence be released by the Committee or individual members of the Committee save where it can be demonstrated that it will interfere with an investigation or a prosecution, or where certain workings of the Authority in respect to law enforcement will be compromised. Even then, if the Authority disapproves, that question itself can be arbitrated by an independent arbitrator.

So, if Justice Phillips were in this chamber now he would be arguing against this proposal because he is proposing quite the opposite. What Justice Phillips has been proposing has been supported by the Government and by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). Yet, we now have a quite contradictory proposition put to us here today. It is not without significance-and I do not want to dwell on the NCA-to note that it was Mr Lindsay, the Chairman, seconded by Senator Loosley, who released in camera evidence of a not insensitive nature. This evidence said:
GRASSBY was proceeded with against the advice of investigating police. Police believe there was not enough to proceed at that time.
So that committee has found merit in putting previously in camera evidence on the public record.

Can I just take up the point that Senator Watson apparently is running around the chamber trying to prosecute, and a view that has also been put by Senator Coates, which is that, once a witness gives in camera evidence, the genie cannot be let out of the bottle save if the witness says so. I put, with respect, how does one know what a witness is going to say before he says it? Yet, we are giving him carte blanche approval to give in camera evidence, which is never to be released without his approval, before he gives it. For crying out loud, where have we heard that proposition put before?

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frequently.
—Where has it been put by serious and sensible people?
—Quite frequently.

—That is not true. I am staggered that Senator Button would put that to me. As a lawyer, Senator Button would know that an application for the proceedings of a court not to be disclosed is only resolved following the disclosure to the judge of the proposed evidence.
—As a lawyer, I know that is bunkum.

—Senator Button is a poor, old lawyer and he is steep on bunkum; that is all I can say. Once the evidence is in, it cannot be let out. What happens if the old witness dies? How does one ever get the evidence out again? But, because it seems to work for one committee, it is assumed it will work for every other committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Every single witness will then come along and say, `What I have got to say to you is so secretive, so sensitive and so undercover that I will only give it to you in camera. Then we say, `But what is it?'. The witness says, `I cannot tell you because it is so secretive and you will have to take my word for it'. Because all the committee members' tongues are hanging out with excitement-pant, pant-they say, `Yes, we will take your evidence in camera'. So his evidence is taken in camera and he probably confesses to 49 crimes and makes all sorts of allegations, but it is in camera and we cannot get it out because he says, `I do not want it released'. That is the proposition that is being put to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't hear it.
—But the point is how do we know what we are going hear before it is put to us?
—No in camera evidence.

—Can I say, as I said earlier on, that I support the general principle of no in camera evidence except when there are certain circumstances: it might be hearsay evidence; it might be evidence that is thought self-incriminating; or it might be evidence which is not in the better public good.
—Commercial confi- dentiality.
—It may be commercial confidential.
—I thought that would appeal to you.

—It would have as much appeal as self-incrimination or in the public good-all those things weigh in the balance. In those circumstances, after careful contemplation and reviewing the evidence that has been given to the Committee, the Committee may well come to the conclusion that it ought not be released. Any member of the Committee, who tables both his minority report and the in camera evidence, is going to be subject to the condemnation, the ridicule, and the criticism of the Senate, the public and the media if he has done the wrong thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I have not forgotten when Senator Walsh came marching into this chamber and dropped a bunch of false cheque butts, seeking to smear people both in the chamber and outside. But because one of these cheque butts, which turned out to be false, was kept in his drawer and happened to be one I had, what did the Senate do to him? It censored him. He was the first Minister of Finance to my knowledge since Federation who has been censored by the chamber for personal conduct. While it may not have dented the hide of Senator Walsh, the average person would take note of that. That is the restriction that the Senate has got on the release of in camera evidence in an improper way.

The other proposition that is put to us is that the Senate has the right to release the evidence. On my reading, that is an absurdity. How does the Senate make a judgment to release in camera evidence which it has not heard? How does it hear it? How does it hear the in camera evidence because, as we all know, that is an offence and the meaning of offence is contempt of the Senate. Standing order 308 explicitly prohibits it and it is a criminal offence.

When I interjected on Senator Coates, he said, `Will you get around and lobby your colleagues?'. What Senator Coates is suggesting is that one can be in contempt of the Senate but just do not get caught. One should sneak around the back and side doors and up the alleys, get to one's colleagues and say, `I have got this in camera evidence. I am not supposed to be releasing it because it is contrary to section 308 of the Standing Orders but have a bo-peep at this lot. When I move a motion for it to be made public just put your hand up, will you? You can't tell anybody that you have read it because I am not supposed to be showing it to you but I want you to support it.' That is the absurdity.

Senator Coates might like to tell me sometime how the Senate is in a position to make a judgment as to whether or not in camera evidence given to a committee ought to be made public. There is no possible or practical way. I might just give an example of the problems of taking in camera evidence. One of the committees of which I am a member took evidence which required some sort of action. The committee wrote to the Australian Institute of Sport saying that there were certain matters that required some inquiry on its behalf in respect of, I think, previous athletes or present scholarship holders. But by a majority vote, the committee decided that it would not release the in camera evidence even to the authorities who were expected to act upon the evidence.

Of course, quite naturally, Mr Harris, I think it was, wrote back and said, `I note your decision not to disclose to us the in camera evidence which we have requested so we can act upon it and therefore we do not propose to act'. This was at a time when we were having a great deal of difficulty getting the authorities to deal in a proper and responsible way with the conduct of certain individuals.

I put it to honourable senators that if that inquiry into drugs in sport had simply made a bland finding which said, `As a result of in camera evidence received by the committee we have drawn the conclusion that a number of athletes at the Australian Institute of Sport are using prohibited substances, banned substances, that they are on drugs; we do not propose to disclose who they are, how we found out, what the allegations were, what the assertions are; but take our word for it that there are crooks and cheats over at the Institute of Sport and that is all we will tell you because we are keeping it in camera', what a great finding that would be! That would really help the public debate. It would really help the reputations of the guys and girls who are not cheating. That would really help the reputation of the Institute, the officials and the coaches.

So it is absolutely inevitable that when a committee makes findings of that nature it at least should provide sufficient evidence to justify and support its findings. I notice that Senator Coates did not even want television cameras at the committee meetings. We now have television cameras in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. United States committees have had them for 25 years. Senator Coates did not want even that level of public scrutiny. I would have thought that the greatest safeguard for the rights of any individual is to ensure that what he says in respect of allegations is on the public record; that he is able to make his assertions and his defence to protect and preserve his reputation on the public record.

If this Parliament ever gets to the stage where it makes findings about people and their reputations but is unable to substantiate those findings because it has chosen-inadvertently perhaps-to take evidence in camera, it is going to be a very sad day. Perhaps committees will have to show a bit more discipline when taking evidence. They had better start saying that from now on, `No, we will not take the evidence in camera'. The virtue of an individual having the right to change his mind is that after reviewing all the evidence, on balance he can make a determination whether the public good is helped, whether the findings of the committee are supported, and whether the proceedings and the functioning of the Parliament are more effective as a result of the release of that in camera evidence.

I have no knowledge of any occasion on which the disclosure of any in camera evidence has caused any unfair or any unreasonable hardship to any individual or institution. We now have a situation where the Government would have itself as the censor of what ought to be released in the future. I find it a very poor way of seeking to proceed in this Parliament. As a matter of principle, we ought to seek as far as possible to have everything that we deal with on the public record and preserve only that in camera evidence which fits certain criteria.

For my part, I would leave the status quo; I would leave in place the Standing Orders as they are presently interpreted. I notice that while the Democrats are supporting the amendment that Senator Hill is proposing, Senator Spindler, if I am not misrepresenting him, in fact proposes in his private member's Bill to go beyond that to some extent. Be that as it may, it is my view that the present situation ought to prevail. But, to the extent that commonsense and consensus can be found in terms of Senator Hill's amendment, I shall without apology or qualification be supporting that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Crichton-Browne in two ways. One is that he suggested that I proposed that committee members should show in camera evidence to their colleagues in order to convince them of the need to release it. I did not say that and I would not say that. Secondly, he misrepresented my position on the televising of the drugs in sport inquiry. My position is that I support the televising of committee hearings in the system that is now available in committee rooms, with the use of discrete cameras in the walls. I opposed the televising of that drugs in sport inquiry because the procedure at the time would have involved four or five networks each with cameras intruding into and disrupting proceedings. I do not object to the system of televising hearings that is now available in some committee rooms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in this debate and I open by saying that I have heard two speeches from the Opposition, from Senator Vanstone and Senator Crichton-Browne, which I think should be given out to any student of the irrelevant argument as neither senator directed comments to the question at issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vanstone spent a lot of time talking about whether or not Parliament could be trusted with information. What a very interesting notion that is. What, indeed, was she saying that that has to do with in camera evidence to committees? What Senator Vanstone wanted to say was that, if we were not careful, we would be concluding here that Parliament could not be trusted and that we would need to give further protection to evidence. By some curious leap in the back of her head, she suggested that these proposals wanted to tighten the restraint orders on members of parliament.

I suppose that in some ways this debate comes at a very apposite time following last night's adjournment debate and the deliberations about whether or not the documents that Senator McLean wanted to table should have been tabled and whether or not the public interest outweighed sub judice practice. On balance I think there was a fair consensus to concur with the President's ruling. As I understand it, nobody wanted to dissent from that, so I take it that it was agreed.

It was interesting that both the Opposition and Government senators who spoke wanted to support, on the record, the sub judice principle rather than the public interest. Indeed, I think that is essentially what we are talking about here today. I do not disagree with Senator Vanstone that Parliament is charged to a very significant degree to look at what is the public interest. It is the receiver of information and, indeed, sometimes may be the place of last resort for those in the community who feel that their rights have been threatened or overrun.

I certainly would not in any way want to disagree with Senator Vanstone about the importance in this business of Parliament or parliamentary committees. But to leap from there to conclude that the proposed changes put forward by the Procedure Committee suggest de facto that Parliament cannot be trusted with information is just an illogical step. I do not follow Senator Vanstone's argument and she did not persuade me that there was a step of logic in it. Her argument slipped classically between one sentence and the next.

Senator Vanstone then spent a lot of time talking about the need to protect the Executive, saying that senators of the government of the day would clearly want to close ranks and protect the Executive, particularly from the disclosure of information. As I understand it-I do not claim to be completely across all the Standing Orders, but I have sought information-the Estimates committees cannot hear evidence in camera. Their proceedings are entirely open and senators can ask whatever they wish.

Estimates committees are a particularly good example of when the Executive is called before the Parliament and I know of no process or procedure by which Government senators could move to protect the Executive or to try to restrict the information provided by the Executive.

I am perfectly happy to say on the record that, by and large, the Executive needs no help at all in protecting itself. If there is something that it does not want to tell us, it is remarkably good at not telling us. If people think that is not necessarily the case, they should read the Sir Humphrey scripts and they would appreciate that there is a lot of documentation to that effect.

I also say to Senator Vanstone that, while she can possibly conclude that Government senators would want to be more protective of the Executive, sometimes Government senators are more frustrated because of information they cannot find from the Executive, precisely because they have access to that information more readily as members of the Government than do members of the Opposition. That is a standard practice. I do not know what the situation is for my colleagues; I presume it is not very different from mine. I find that, having got information on behalf of a constituent, the difficulty then is in trying to develop that into getting the further information that sees a change to the benefit of the constituent.

There are lively breaks and checks and balances, but I do not think that one could conclude, as readily as Senator Vanstone wanted to persuade us to do, that moving this way actually has to do with some kind of restriction on the Executive supported by Government senators. That is an interesting thing to be talking about in the Senate, but I do not really think it has particularly tight logical relevance to the debate in hand.

Then we heard Senator Crichton-Browne and I congratulate him on another splendid performance. Again, I have to say that logic is not the highest criterion of Senator Crichton-Browne's contributions in this place. What we had from Senator Crichton-Browne was an argument by declaration based on his own experiences in committees. I do not object to honourable senators citing their own experience by way of illustration of a point, but to conclude that that is the only way of looking at in camera evidence, by restricting his considerations to the matters of the drugs in sport inquiry, does him little credit. Senator Crichton-Browne sells himself short.

I have said before in this place that I am very much inclined to the view expressed by Senator Cooney and reiterated by Senator Crichton-Browne that, where possible, in camera evidence should not be taken; that it is really much better for the committee, for the witnesses, for public discussion and the public interest that all that evidence be on the public record.

It is also true that it is the amount of in camera evidence that creates the difficulties. So I presume that Senator Crichton-Browne and Senator Cooney are not concluding that there should be no in camera evidence at any time. I take the point that what is being argued is that it should be minimal; there is a large sentiment to that. But in the end we still have to address the question of how we weigh up the amount of in camera evidence and so on. That is the question that we are deliberating about here.

I actually had the experience of being on another committee where in camera evidence was given to us by the Australian Federal Police. It seemed to us entirely appropriate to have that evidence in camera. It seemed to us entirely proper not to refer to that evidence directly, except to use it as background information, which then was useful in questioning other witnesses. In no way did we allude to it. But it seems to me that is one of the proper ways in which in camera evidence can assist a committee.

In the end, what we are talking about is whether or not we parliamentarians or members of committees are old enough to cope with the burden of responsibility that comes as a consequence of being party to special information. I think that is the challenge we have to grapple with. On the whole, I would presume my colleagues are able to deal with that. But I also think a lot of us-certainly I am one-have had great anxiety about the rapid increase in the release of in camera evidence to the point of being concerned about what kind of weight is still being given to in camera evidence.

I regard in camera evidence as something of a very serious nature. Committees do not take in camera evidence lightly. Presumably, it is either sought or provided because of the serious nature of the content of that evidence. It can go to the individual rights of people or, as in the case of the committee I referred to earlier, it can go to matters before law and the rights of large organisations. It can be a whole variety of sorts. But I think it is not beyond honourable senators to cope with the responsibility that comes with being party to that information and then, according to these proposals, make reasonable decisions about whether or not it should be released.

Senator Crichton-Browne argued that, if in camera evidence could not be released, a dissenting report could not be written. Senator Crichton-Browne knows, as well as I do, that that is not true. A very comprehensive and adequate dissenting report could be written. It may be that the Senate committee from which he sought permission to release in camera evidence may deny him that permission, but that would not deny him the capacity to write a significant dissenting report. If he puts that up as a serious lollipop, allow me to belt it out of court. It is just a good spurious argument that I do not think is persuasive at all.

There is a presumption, in the words of Senator Crichton-Browne, that government senators of the day would want to block the release of in camera evidence-a presumption that we are all of one mind and are always likely to protect whatever is the presumed interest of the majority of the committee. I can give plenty of examples of government senators who have written dissenting reports-indeed I stand here as one of them.

Senator Crichton-Browne, going, as he does, more to the ad hominem series of arguments, has missed the opportunity to make a contribution on the logic of these issues. What the Senate is considering is the best way of dealing with in camera evidence consequent on an extravagant release of in camera evidence to the point where people began to doubt whether there is any point in using the words `in camera evidence' or providing for it at all.

If the intention of the Senate is to do away with in camera evidence altogether, let us so conclude. But nobody wants to say that. Nobody is saying that there should be no in camera evidence. Nobody wants to say that we will never again allow an opportunity for that. So what we are going to have to decide then is what we do with in camera evidence. If we accept the proposals put by Senator Cooney and Senator Crichton-Browne that we restrict as much as possible what is taken as in camera evidence, it behoves us even more than before to be clear about the status of that in camera evidence; where, when and how it can be released; and whose rights and liberties we might want to guarantee by way of protection.

It is a matter of great significance that we are asked to look at in camera evidence. I think the proposals put out by the Procedure Committee go a long way to addressing very thoughtfully the best way of dealing with the disclosure of in camera evidence and, in particular, the idea of the full committee which has taken that in camera evidence being asked to consider whether the release of it is proper. All the senators on the committee heard the evidence. They would be in the best position to understand the weight of that evidence as part of the report that might want to be given and the conclusions that may be drawn from it. That is not an unreasonable or unthoughtful consideration.

I turn to the final point I would like to make about Senator Crichton-Browne's contribution. He came in here and argued that a committee had taken in camera evidence of claims of less than elegant behaviour in the Institute of Sport; that the Director rang up and said, `Give us that evidence so we can act'; that we said, `Well, no, we don't want to give you that in camera evidence'; and that he said, `Well, then, I cannot act'. That is some measure, I would suggest, of the limitations of the Director's understanding of the issue. If we could find out about this, presumably it is open to other people in the appropriate authority to do so.

If there is now clear evidence that there were unacceptable behaviours going on at the Institute of Sport, I think it is beholden to accept that general statement and then proceed to its own inquiry, properly respecting the rights and liberties of the people at the Institute of Sport-the athletes, or whoever. It is an outrageous conclusion to reach that the Institute could proceed to act only if we released our evidence-a very false understanding I should have thought, Senator Crichton-Browne, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President. For many reasons, but in particular by way of opposing some of the, I think, insufficient arguments advanced by Opposition senators in this place, I am happy to make my comments.

In summary, I strongly endorse restricting in camera evidence to as little as is absolutely necessary. I take the case that the public record and the rights of people and the committee are best protected by all the evidence, or as much of it as possible, being on the public record. However, when it is judged or sought that we take evidence in camera, I believe we have to address the most useful, proper, constructive way of dealing with that in camera evidence so as to enable the Senate, the Parliament, to have adequate information to make appropriate conclusions and, at the same time, protect the rights of the people giving us the evidence. I believe that the Procedure Committee, in coming up with these three recommendations, goes a long way to making sure that the optimal outcome regarding in camera evidence is achieved. The Opposition's arguments, to this point, are not persuading me to think differently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After paragraph (2) insert the following paragraph:

(2A) That, where a committee is to hear evidence in camera at the request of a witness who is to give that evidence, or is to order that a document be treated as evidence taken in camera at the request of the person who is to submit the document to the committee, the evidence or document shall not be disclosed without the permission of the witness who gave the evidence or the person who submitted the document to the committee.

I apologise to the chamber for the fact that the wording of the amendment circulated was in the past tense. In order to conform more closely with my intention of having a greater uniformity of in camera evidence, and to conform more closely with the words of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in terms of its Act of Parliament which governs in camera evidence, I put my motion as submitted in the present tense.

I point out that before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts takes in camera evidence, it follows a procedure that it has followed very closely since 1951, when that Act applied. We have a preliminary conference to establish the bona fides of the witness because, first and foremost, the aim of the Committee is to ensure that the maximum amount of information is given in public.

I believe, as a senator with a free vote, that there are certain inherent weaknesses in the motion before the chamber. I believe we must seek to have a greater uniformity across the Parliament in the giving of in camera evidence. The purpose of my amendment is to seek greater uniformity and greater certainty of witnesses, because it is unfortunate if we have some rules for presenting in camera evidence to certain committees and lesser rules for others regarding tightness of obligations.

Therefore, I remind the Senate that, after many years of practice, we in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are very reluctant to accept in camera evidence. It is not taken lightly; it is taken only after prior consultation and discussion highlighting the range of issues.

I believe that this amendment will prevent irresponsibility and will ensure-it has certainly been the case with the Public Accounts Committee-that vital information, whether confidential or secret, will come forth to a committee. Without this amendment I believe the usefulness of a lot of inquiries could well be severely impeded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief because my colleagues have already expressed the reservations that I feel about moving from the status quo with regard to our Standing Orders and the conduct of Senate inquiries and other activities of the Senate. I strongly believe that the present Standing Orders are adequate and that honourable senators are sufficiently mature to be able to discuss matters of in camera evidence, firstly by restricting in camera evidence to a minimum and then by using that in camera evidence maturely and appropriately. I would resist strongly any changes to the Standing Orders that would restrict the freedom of honourable senators to speak the truth and to be able to put a view which is in the interests of this chamber and in the interests of the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: In brief, I oppose the three proposals marked (1), (2) and (3) in the report of the Procedure Committee because they shift too greatly our procedure away from the current Standing Orders and they restrict honourable senators' freedoms in a grave way. I am prepared to support the form of words set out on page 4 of the report which reads:

A dissenting Senator who wishes to refer to in camera evidence should advise the committee of the evidence concerned, and all reasonable effort should be made by the committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of the evidence for that purpose. If agreement is not reached, the dissenting Senator may refer to the in camera evidence in the dissent only to the extent necessary to support the reasoning of the dissent. Witnesses who gave the evidence in question should, if it is practicable, be informed in advance of the proposed disclosure of the evidence and should be given reasonable opportunity to object to the disclosure and to ask that particular parts of the evidence not be disclosed. The committee should give careful consideration to any objection by a witness before making its decision. Consideration should be given to disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave the evidence or who are referred to in the evidence.

The important point to be made about that paragraph is that it reinforces certain cautions which I believe are the practice of experienced senators in any event. But those words do not take away any of the current powers of honourable senators nor do they in fact concretely deny any of the Standing Orders that we have in the Senate at the moment. Rather, the advantage of these words is that they could completely resolve the matter that is before us in a way which I believe could gain the majority support of the Senate. Guidelines are set out clearly-guidelines which have been convention in the experience of many senators in recent years.

Finally, I refer to in camera evidence which may need to be considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Privilege. In recent years the Senate has referred many matters to the Privileges Committee where a person giving evidence to a committee may be alleged to have misled a Senate committee or where a person who has given evidence to a Senate committee is being persecuted or punished in some way in the community on account of giving such evidence. To maintain the freedoms of ordinary citizens in this country, we must ensure that people are free and protected in giving evidence to Senate inquiries. Also, we want to have ways of ensuring that the evidence that is given is truthful and not misleading.

In the conduct of inquiries on references that come to the Privileges Committee there have been instances where the material in question was given in camera to a Senate inquiry. It is impossible, in my mind, for the Privileges Committee to do its work if it does not have access to that in camera material. Whilst I am happy to say in this debate that the Privileges Committee has never resolved to deny itself access to in camera evidence in another inquiry, and whilst I am also happy to say that no standing committee has ever denied in camera material to the Privileges Committee on our request, this could be contemplated. This matter could be even subject to a resolution of the Privileges Committee in a particular case-a self-denying resolution that might lead the Privileges Committee to bind itself not to have access to certain in camera material.

Let such cases be considered on their merits. I want to make it very clear that, as a member of the Privileges Committee, I would be under the obligation, where there was any resolution to deny ourselves access to such in camera material, to report that to the Senate, especially if it were felt by any member of the Privileges Committee that we could not fulfil a reference that had been given to us to investigate and bring a report to the Senate. It seems useful at this time to note that particular aspect of in camera evidence as it relates to the Privileges Committee.

In summary, I urge the Senate to reject proposals (1), (2), and (3) in the report of the Procedure Committee. If the status quo is not to continue, there is, I believe, an ability for us all to conscientiously support the paragraph which I read out and which is set out on page 4 of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Robert Ray said at the outset of the debate, this is a difficult issue. The Standing Committee on Procedure was divided on its recommendation; in fact, it divided five votes to four. The motion before the Senate at the moment is that of the majority and it is to set out a slightly more strict regime in dealing with in camera evidence than the position advocated by the minority. That position, nevertheless, is to introduce further restrictions than is currently the case, or is perceived to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to today's disastrous December quarterly consumer price index rise of 2.7 per cent, half as high again as the previous December quarter, which shows that despite the fact that the economy has been in recession for over 12 months, the CPI is now running at an annual rate of 6.9 per cent. I ask: how does the Minister reconcile these facts with the statement by the Prime Minister on the Sunday program three days ago that progress on inflation `has been part of the product of this period of pain', and in which he also said, `I believe it is going to fall further'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never been given to forecasting in this place, but let me say that I believe it is going to fall further too. Let me talk about the particular circumstances of the CPI figure which was announced for the December quarter today. Of course, that figure was poorer than expected. It was 2.7 per cent for the quarter, as Senator Short points out, equating to 6.9 per cent for the year to date. In spite of that, I think market comment about the figure has not been one of great dismay, it is higher than market expectations. The CPI figures for the quarter have been very substantially affected by the rise in oil prices, largely bunched in that quarter.
—It is always something, isn't it!
—Of course there is always something. There happens to be a war in the Gulf which has affected oil prices internationally.
—Next month something else will be better.
—Oh, come on.

—Before those opposite start to groan and carry on, let me refer them to some of the comparative figures. The consumer price index figures released overnight by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development show that in the 12 months to the December quarter 1990 inflation for the OECD countries as a whole was 7.4 per cent.
—Are they in the middle of a depression?

—Yes, I think so, Senator. If the honourable senator doubts that about the United Kingdom, he should come back here tomorrow and ask me a question about its inflation rate, its unemployment rate and its current account.
—You know the answer already.

—I am told to concentrate on Australia. For years members of the Opposition concentrated on the United Kingdom. They used to say, `Why are we doing so badly compared with Margaret Thatcher's Government in Britain?' But they have dropped off all that now. It does not help. Those opposite should listen to the figures: the figure is 7.4 per cent for the OECD countries as a whole; for the United Kingdom, the figure is 9.9 per cent, a figure which we have not seen in Australia since the Opposition was in government; and for the United States, the figure is 6.2 per cent. Let me put it in that perspective, because there are a number of comparative factors which are important. The CPI figure has been affected not only by the direct oil price which everybody expected, but also by the oil price flowing through to higher household energy costs and rising air fares.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the CPI reflects increases in State taxes and charges on beer, cigarettes and tobacco. The inflation rate for the year to the December quarter, after removing the effect in petrol prices, is 5.9 per cent, slightly down on the year to the September quarter, when 6 per cent was the projected figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot remove figures like that.
—That is what the current information is if one removes the direct oil price effect.
—What is it a measure of?
—Do you want to take out all the unacceptable factors?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Senator Short finished his question by referring to a statement of the Prime Minister in which he said that inflation was trending down. I said at the start of my answer: `Yes, that is right.' It is on the basis of one quarter's figures, affected by quite extraneous circumstances, that Senator Short couches this present question. Those circumstances are extraneous and I think we can look forward to Senator Short's question at the time of the publication of the next quarter's figures.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. While recognising, as the Minister has said, that oil prices have had a significant effect on the consumer price index outcome, is it not also a fact that significant increases occurred across all categories of the index, not all of which by any means were affected in any way by the oil price situation?
—I would not say that. There are many indirect effects which affect a variety of indicators. I think the one exception to that is State charges in respect of things like tobacco and so on.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister inform the Senate what special provisions are proposed for the treatment of pensioners over 80 as far as the new deeming rules are concerned?
—I thought you did not believe in dorothy dixers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are times when they are necessary. I spoke with Senator West about this because there are occasions, Senator Alston, when one must concede error. I told the Senate Standing Committee--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I did speak with His Holiness a couple of weeks ago at a private audience, but the infallibility did not rub off. I told the Standing Committee prior to the luncheon adjournment that over-80-year-olds are not affected by the deeming rules. I should have said that the over-80s will be protected by special arrangements under the deeming rules. I think it appropriate that I read them out now.
—Oh, come on!
—I think Senator Walters ought to listen to these.
—But I told you that you were wrong.
—We told you that you were wrong yesterday.
—I was not wrong yesterday, but Senator Patterson had the opportunity to demonstrate that later.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I did; I said I was wrong in the words I used to the Committee prior to the luncheon adjournment. I was wrong in the words I used. However, firstly, let me say that in the data collection for deeming, when forms were sent out some weeks ago to those with financial arrangements which so far as we knew meant they would be affected, they were not sent to pensioners who had a warranty coded or who were on a group payment. That excluded most of the frail aged pensioners and those who are most infirm, particularly those who are in nursing homes.

ANSWER.PARA: However, it is the special administrative measures which have been taken to protect the over-80s which I wish to outline. Firstly, they will be protected from the deeming rules for cash and accounts until the Department of Social Security has contacted each pensioner individually, firstly, to explain the new rules and, secondly, to assist the pensioner to reorganise his or her affairs to earn extra interest. Until that follow-up action is taken, pensioners will not have their pensions suspended because of non-return of the data collection form and will not have their pensions reduced under the deeming rules on cash and accounts. Therefore, the administrative arrangements have it that over-80s will be protected and will not have their pensions reduced after 1 March, even if some of them have not complied with the deeming rules. That is what I did not say to the Committee and what I wanted to make clear to the Senate now. Special arrangements do apply for the over-80s and that will mean that no persons in that category who do not comply immediately will have their pension reduced unless and until they have been contacted individually by the Department and their affairs have been cleared up and assisted by the Department.

I should also say that under the Act I have the power to exempt any person or class of persons from the provisions of deeming. Of course, I will do that should it become necessary and should it become obvious that anyone is being particularly disadvantaged as a result of it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. It arises from his news conference on 1 February 1991 and in particular the answer in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Israel is not a country that we sell arms to. It has been debarred or barred for a number of years.

I ask: when was Israel included on the banned list? What were the reasons for banning defence exports to Israel? Why were defence exports to Israel banned yet defence exports to Iraq after 1988 not banned?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like the view to be abroad that I held a press conference on this particular matter. I held a press conference on the Gulf and I was asked questions on this particular matter. The ground on which Israel and many other countries in the Middle East are barred is provision 9d of the guidelines concerning the export of military hardware, foreign policy interests being the major factor. The Government has had a policy for those reasons not to send lethal military goods and in some cases what we would term non-lethal military goods into that region, because it is a region with a major arms build-up. I suppose that it is regrettable, but the only exception to that appears to me to be the sale to that region of a small number of trainer aircraft parts by Hawker de Havilland, something that the Government cancelled subsequently as a result of the United Nations arms embargo.

ANSWER.PARA: Israel has not been particularly picked out as a country, and there is no reason why it should in the Middle East context; it is simply the region that we are talking about. As I said at the press conference, that does not preclude Israel or any other country from applying through the normal processes and then at least appealing to me as a final arbiter in these matters-and I do have responsibility for the final decision making process. I guess that, for instance, if we had been the major producer of Patriot missiles in the last few weeks and they had gone through the processes, I would have had to have a very serious think about that because that would have added very much to the self-defence of a country that is facing totally unprovoked aggression from another country. But Israel itself has not been specifically chosen in this instance; it is the general Middle East countries. As I say, I can point to one exception to that, and the Minister at the time and I-I think it involved both Ministers-did not regard it as a significant military product.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I repeat the first part of the question: when was a decision made to put Israel on the list?

—I have not made a decision to put it specifically on a list. If I have said that it was a very poor expression, but that region generally fails to meet provision 9d in the guidelines. I might add, as I have said in discussion with a couple of people, that Israel was brought into that press conference by way of interjection. I did not volunteer to pick out this or that country. Someone interjected and I answered on the spot. It was not a matter of picking out Israel in particular. It would apply equally to Jordan, Syria, et cetera.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade advise whether the meeting of the co-chairmen of the Paris conference on Cambodia, meeting in February of this year with Vietnamese representatives, was successful in moving toward a finalisation of a comprehensive settlement text for Cambodia? In view of the Prime Minister Hun Sen's statement that it will hold parliamentary elections next year if a settlement to end the civil war is not reached, can the Minister detail what role the United Nations (UN) and Australia will play in those elections if they are held?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were some useful consultations held a couple of weeks ago involving the so-called 3As-that is, Foreign Minister Alatas of Indonesia, Madame Edwige Avice, France's Minister of State for Foreign Affairs representing the two co-chairmen of the Paris Conference, accompanied by Mr Rafeeuddin Ahmed, who is the special representative of the United Nations Secretary General. They visited Hanoi from 31 January to 2 February for consultations with Vietnamese leaders on the Cambodian settlement question. The particular purpose of those consultations was to explain to Vietnam the provisions of the draft settlement text that were agreed by the Permanent Five members of the Security Council on 26 November and that were put by the Paris Conference co-chairmen to the members of the Cambodian Factions Supreme National Council, which met again in Paris on 21 and 22 December. Vietnam had not been an immediate party to those consultations but because it obviously continues to be a very influential player in the Cambodian settlement process, it was thought desirable that it be the subject to the specific consultative process; thus this meeting.

ANSWER.PARA: The outcome of the consultations, despite some mixed press reports which honourable senators no doubt would have seen was, in my judgment, on the briefing I have had, broadly positive and certainly has helped maintain momentum in the settlement process. I have to say that that process has not been leaping forward in recent months but it has been inching forward. The United Nations peace plan, based of course on the original proposal from Australia, remains in our judgment the only viable way of finally and peacefully resolving this conflict.

The Vietnamese, in these consultations, reaffirmed their acceptance of the Permanent Five framework, on which the draft settlement text is based. They expressed support for the efforts of the co-chairmen to resolve remaining issues. They also agreed, importantly, to discuss these issues further with the SOC-State of Cambodia regime in Phnom Penh.

I think that the consultations in Vietnam and elsewhere have confirmed over recent weeks that there are really now three significant unresolved issues, namely: the demobilisation provisions in the draft settlement text; associated weapons custody arrangements; and how to deal in the settlement text with the issue of non-return of genocide, and how that should be linguistically addressed. Given the necessary political will to resolve these issues, which is still evident, a comprehensive settlement is still well in sight.

As to the latter part of the question about possible elections to be held in Cambodia by the Phnom Penh Government, it is premature to say what role Australia and the UN might play if there is no settlement and those elections are proceeded with on a unilateral basis some time in 1992, as has been suggested. Certainly it is our judgment that the unilateral holding of elections will not resolve the conflict or end crucial outside assistance to the Khmer Rouge. The only thing that can do that is a comprehensive settlement, and it can do it by ensuring that China cooperates in the processes and ceases its military support to the Khmer Rouge. In our judgment, only a comprehensive settlement of the kind proposed under the UN plan will enable all Cambodians to determine their future through free and fair elections-elections, of course, conducted and organised by the UN.

All of these considerations underline the urgency of focusing every effort now on achieving a comprehensive settlement and not being distracted by other international events. Australia continues to welcome the very assiduous efforts that are being made by the Paris Conference cochairmen to resolve differences. We continue to hope that a date for the reconvening of the coordinating committee of the Paris Conference can be set as soon as possible so that the finalisation of the settlement text can be carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the circumstances surrounding the arrest, on the floor of the Ukraine Parliament, of People's Deputy Dr Stephan Khmara, even though the parliamentary motion allowing his arrest was made without a quorum being recorded as present at the time? What action has the Minister taken, or does the Minister intend to take, in relation to the illegal arrest and incarceration of Dr Khmara?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bourne for that question. It is also one which Senator Michael Baume has taken a particular interest in. Dr Khmara, a deputy of the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet, was arrested during a demonstration in Kiev on 7 November last to protest against the commemoration of the Bolshevik revolution. While there are conflicting reports on the incident which led to his arrest, I understand that the resolution which stripped him of his parliamentary immunity was passed-as Senator Bourne has said-without a quorum being present in the Ukrainian Supreme Soviet. That is obviously a matter of very great concern.

ANSWER.PARA: Following representations made to us on this matter from the Ukrainian community in December, I did instruct the Australian Embassy in Moscow to seek clarification from the Soviet authorities of the details of Mr Khmara's case and to convey to them the Australian Government's concerns to ensure that Mr Khmara's human rights are not violated. Those concerns were also raised by Australian Government representatives at bilateral consultations covering human rights issues that were held in Moscow in January. The Embassy will, I can assure honourable senators, continue to pursue his case with the Soviet authorities.

Might I say just this in conclusion: while the Australian Government does appreciate the complexity of the problems facing the Soviet Union, we do strongly urge that efforts to solve them should not be at the expense of the progress achieved in recent years in creating a very much more open society in the Soviet Union with a greater respect for human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. What progress is being made towards introducing a national approach to the implementation of restraint orders, as was recommended by the National Committee on Violence, to protect victims of domestic violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Committee on Violence in its report Violence: Directions for Australia did give considerable importance to the problem of domestic violence in our society and its devastating effects. It is a fact that many households, rather than being havens of safety, are places where domestic violence is experienced, particularly and obviously by women in our society. Among other things, the Committee recommended that to deal with this blight on our society there should be the introduction of restraint orders across jurisdictions, and that the problem of ensuring that restraint orders can be effective across jurisdictions should be treated as a priority by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General.

ANSWER.PARA: I am pleased to say that the Attorneys met early last week, on 7 February, and agreed that the protection offered by restraint orders should be available to the victims of violence who move to new States or Territories, regardless of inconsistencies in legislation in the various jurisdictions. I believe that this move will be of great benefit to and be welcomed by those who seek the protection of the courts to ensure that so far as possible they are not put in a position where their vulnerability makes them, in a perilous situation, victims of terrible violence. It was also agreed that the Commonwealth would investigate amending the Service and Execution of Process Act to implement these proposals.

The National Committee on Violence report has been very well received in the community. I believe that various ministerial councils, such as that comprising police Ministers who dealt with the question of the import of certain semiautomatic weapons, members of the community, groups and individuals are following up on this report, which I believe is already having a considerable impact on the formation and texture of our culture in combating the terrible scourge of violence. In so far as the Attorneys-General have reacted so promptly to that recommendation, they are to be commended.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Defence arises out of the Minister's inability to provide a detailed answer to my question yesterday about the $450m defence export application for which he refused permission. I acknowledge that the Minister did pass to me an answer as to when the application was received but I feel that the Minister should put that on the public record. But other questions arise to which I seek an answer because of the widespread interest in this matter. Why was an application in respect of such an important matter dealt with by telephone ring-around and not by a meeting of the Standing Committee on Defence Exports itself? When did that ring-around take place and when was the decision to refuse permission to export made?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge Senator Durack's point that the date should be put on the public record, and I intended to do that after Question Time, but I will do it now. The application was made on 10 August 1990. Senator Durack asked me whether we would regard this as sufficient to have a full meeting of the Committee. I do not regard it as sufficient. I think current procedures are correct. I do not want to set up a bureaucracy and meetings for meetings' sake. It is probably regarded by most departments as clear cut.

ANSWER.PARA: Each department was consulted during the period of September and August. There was a reconsultation with three of those departments and replies received in October and November. Advice from my office, from my senior adviser, was sought and given on 14 November 1990. It then went to the First Assistant Secretary, Industry, Policy and Operations Division on 17 December, to the Deputy Secretary, Acquisitions and Logistics on 24 December and came to my office or, more particularly-because I was on leave-it went to Minister Bilney, who wrote some notes on the whole subject for my guidance. I considered it on 30 January 1991. It was received back in the Department and formally processed on 5 February 1991. The applicant was advised on 6 February 1991.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SYNDICATED RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT TAX CONCESSION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. What is the current status of the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development in the light of the recently released exposure draft ruling by the Australian Taxation Office on syndicated research and development?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The recent draft ruling from the Taxation Office was very welcome because there has been a lot of concern and discussion over this issue for some time. In general terms, the ruling clarifies the situation with respect to syndicated research and development, and sets out the relationship between the various sectors of the legislation. We believe that it will be an effective ruling in preventing syndicate proposals that employ limited debt which seek to circumvent the provisions of the legislation and, thereby, obtain the full concession for expenditure that is, essentially, not at risk.

ANSWER.PARA: Preliminary indications are that the ruling will not have a significant impact on the willingness of investors to participate in syndication. However, it is considered that they will be more selective in terms of the type of R and D projects in which they will invest. I suspect that in the future they will not be the longer term, high risk projects, but more towards projects which have a closer possibility of commercialisation.

Overall, I consider that the ruling will go a long way towards eliminating proposals that seek to gain unintended benefits for investors through the use of limited or non recourse debt. Further, the likely shift in emphasis away from longer term R and D towards shorter term, close to market project development will, I believe, provide a significant boost to Australian industry and, therefore, increase the interests of industry in taking advantage of the syndication proposal. With the provision of syndicated R and D, and in the light of the Tax Office ruling, this stage of the R and D-that is, closer to commercialisation R and D-can be accelerated by the injection of new funds, with the result that companies are able to bring new projects on to world markets much more quickly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RESERVE BANK OF AUSTRALIA: STATE BANK OF SOUTH AUSTRALIA

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In the House of Representatives yesterday the Treasurer said `the Reserve Bank informally supervises State banks'. On 4 September last year, in the South Australian Parliament, the Premier of South Australia stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The State Bank is subject to the prudential supervision of the RBA on exactly the same basis as all other banks of the country. There is constant dialogue and information exchange, appropriately, between the State Bank and the Reserve Bank.

Given the Reserve Bank of Australia's involvement, and the statement by the Treasurer on the John Laws program on Monday, `If there is a problem, I will hear', how can he claim no knowledge prior to the end of January when the State Bank of South Australia was submitting monthly reports all through 1990?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Olsen's question yesterday, I did undertake to get some further information for him. I was proposing to give him an answer at the end of Question Time. Senator Olsen suggested yesterday that the Reserve Bank had had an officer working in the State Bank. From the way in which Senator Olsen put his question, this was based on Mr Marcus Clark's statement, as I recall it. I am informed that the Reserve Bank has not had an officer posted to the State Bank of South Australia in recent years. The State Bank of South Australia, I am instructed, has undertaken voluntarily to comply with the prudential requirements of the Reserve Bank and provides the Reserve Bank with regular returns. However, this information does not extend to details of individual loans.

ANSWER.PARA: The State Government support package announced on the weekend has the objective, amongst other things, of keeping the capital position of the State Bank of South Australia in line with the prudential requirements of the Reserve Bank. In a sense that was one of the main purposes of that injection in so far as the banking system as a whole was concerned.

Since September 1988 the Reserve Bank capital adequacy guidelines have extended to the consolidated-I stress that word-activities of banks and their subsidiaries. Since late 1989 guidelines on large exposures have also been applied on a group consolidated basis. Since the second half of 1990, information has been collected on the aggregate of non-performing loans-that is, aggregate, non-performing loans; the total portfolio of non-performing loans. I am advised that the Reserve Bank informed the Treasurer of emerging problems in the State Bank of South Australia when the magnitude of these non-performing loans was becoming apparent at the end of January.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I understood Senator Button to say that the Reserve Bank drew the emerging problem of the State Bank to the Treasurer's attention towards the end of January this year. If that is the case, and in view of Senator Button's answer that in the last two quarters of last year detailed information on non-performing loans was made available to the Reserve Bank, what is the purpose of the supervisory powers, given that the Reserve Bank apparently did not draw it to the attention of the Treasurer?

—The purpose of the Reserve Bank's activities in this matter is quite clear. Senator Olsen stated it in his question and I have stated it in my answer. I am not able to say at this stage whether the Reserve Bank acted with alacrity or insufficient alacrity. I cannot make a judgment about that. I suspect that that is probably what Senator Olsen is asking me to do. I do not know what information, and in accordance with what timetable, was made available by the State Bank to the Reserve Bank. It is an impossible question for me to answer.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. In light of recent criticism by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Defence of the coverage of the Gulf war by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, I ask the Minister for Defence whether he has contravened the spirit of sections 6 and 8 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 and the ABC's charter, which gives the ABC, not politicians, the sole responsibility for maintaining the independence, integrity, accuracy and impartiality of its news and information services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I will have to check the administrative orders. In this question I have been promoted by Senator Vallentine to being in charge of the ABC. I am grateful for the promotion. I will not speak on behalf of the Prime Minister. He has expressed his views and he will answer any such questions in the other place at the appropriate time. I must take grave exception to Senator Vallentine's accusation that I have made claims of bias against the ABC.

ANSWER.PARA: I did have a dispute-and it was here in the chamber, all honourable senators heard it-with Radio Australia. It was not over a question of bias, but over whether it would provide a service that it had provided in the previous December to Australian servicemen in the Gulf. The honourable senator has often come into this chamber and thrown around accusations and conspiracy theories. I ask her to produce an instance where I am on the public record of accusing the ABC of bias. I ask her to go through my press conferences, my statements in the Parliament and elsewhere, and highlight where I have made that accusation. I know it does not exist because I have not made it. Whatever my views may be, the ABC is not my ministerial responsibility and I would never make those public views going into someone else's portfolio.

Having said that Senator Vallentine's views are inaccurate, I can understand them because many other reporters-including those in the ABC-have said that I have attacked the ABC without once ever backing up such a statement with a substantive quote, apart from the Radio Australia episode, which was not a question of bias. I have had one dispute with the ABC over recent weeks which was basically a private one. I can make that public now. The ABC carried a report-Senator Vallentine refers to accuracy-that two Australian ships had collided in the Gulf and it ran that report uncorroborated for some hours.

As it turned out, an accusation was made that the source of this information was a Saudi Arabian taxi driver in Sydney. However, on investigation the ABC rigorously denied that. It grossly embarrassed David Hill by assuring him that that was not the source. However, on a better view, on further investigation, subsequently that was found to be the source. Nevertheless, I think the ABC manager of news, to be fair to him, gave a fairly good response. He said, `Look, we have flown 40,000 news sorties and we have had one shot down. The ABC is going to try to make sure that that sort of uncorroborated news story does not go to air again'.

I accept-and I am sure that Mr Beazley accepted-the two page apology that he received on that particular issue. That dispute was on accuracy, not on the question of bias. Senator Vallentine can ask Senator Button, the Minister representing the Prime Minister, for his views on it but she should not come into this chamber with a view that I have attacked the ABC on the question of bias.

Never one to let an opportunity go by to give a gratuitous insult now and then, the one issue that has concerned me is the amount of time the ABC has spent on analysing itself. That is my general view, and Senator Collins can rebuke me later for going into his area. I do not believe the ABC should be the news itself. I do not believe that every talkback program on the ABC-every time Senator Hill is interviewed I hear him asked these questions-should be on the question of the ABC and bias.
