People are entitled to spend some time on that, but not an inordinate amount of time. ``I have answered questions at press conferences on whether I believe the ABC is biased et cetera. Not one of the answers I gave was ever reported either on the ABC or in any newspapers, but I have been asked before and I have had to say that in the totality of the coverage it has been very hard to measure where there is balance, especially in the first couple of weeks. The ABC has been covering so many stories, so many times that it would be very difficult for some arbiter to say whether there is a balance. Later on it can look back on those programs, make an assessment and do any particular corrections that may be necessary. That process may well be under way today but, again, I reject the fact that Senator Vallentine asks me, a Minister not responsible for the ABC, questions about this. I again reject the direct statement that I have attacked the ABC for bias. It is just another typical question that Senator Vallentine brings into this chamber-poorly researched, based on conspiracy theories and knocking over straw men.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. He would be aware of the imposition of a landing surcharge at Sydney's Mascot Airport, imposed, prematurely I believe, to alleviate peak hour congestion in the absence of a desperately needed third runway. The Minister may not be aware of the impact of that decision, which has done nothing to alleviate the peak hour congestion problems. It has merely transferred the peak hour to the shoulder periods, now 7 a.m. to 8 a.m. and 5 p.m. to 6 p.m., resulting in a continuation of the extensive delays for air travellers and all that is associated with it in holding patterns and increased safety risks. In fact, I was held for 40 minutes last Friday morning.
—Order! Senator Brownhill, will you ask your question.

—Given the completion of the environmental impact statement (EIS) some months ago which supported construction of a third runway, is it true that there is a concerted campaign amongst some groups for a public inquiry canvassing the same issues dealt with in the EIS? Can the Minister advise what impact such a public inquiry might have on a construction timetable for the third runway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I will deal with the question in the two parts it was delivered in. In respect of peak period pricing, it is beyond question that Sydney Airport is the most important engine that drives the international tourist industry in this country and, to a great degree, the domestic tourist industry in this country. The importance of Sydney airport as a major agenda item in the micro-economic reform agenda of the Government cannot be overstated; it is an extremely important matter.

ANSWER.PARA: There is also no question that there is a serious congestion problem at Sydney Airport. Peak period pricing was introduced on 1 January by the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), not in isolation but as part of a whole range of measures that have been and are being progressively introduced at Sydney Airport to alleviate the congestion-and with some significant success. Simultaneous operations were introduced at the airport last year, and peak period pricing, as I said, on 1 January this year. Two rapid exit taxiways are going to be constructed this year at Sydney Airport. Very importantly, the Committee on schedule coordination is now achieving for the first time some real success in avoiding one of the major problems in congestion at the airport which is the cluster scheduling that is engaged in by the airlines. There is a great deal of cooperation now to having that relieved.

The FAC reluctantly introduced peak period pricing and, I might add, after extensive consultations with the industry and indeed myself. It has very closely restricted the actual peaks, for which there is a charge, to just one hour in the morning and one hour in the evening, with shoulders, as Senator Brownhill said. But also, as a result of sensitivities attached to this issue, the FAC is going to review that peak period pricing regime in March, that is, after barely three months of operation. I have personally made it clear and the FAC has made it clear to the affected airlines and, indeed, the travellers who use those airlines, that it will be reviewed after a relatively short period of operation to measure whether the problem raised by Senator Brownhill is a real problem.

My advice at this stage of the game is that new peaks being created on the shoulders are currently not perceived as a problem. I am not doubting for a minute that the delay Senator Brownhill referred to happened and, indeed, in individual cases these delays are still occurring. But I can assure Senator Brownhill that the statistics available to me show there has been a significant improvement in the delay problem at Sydney Airport.

Turning to the last part of the question, which is a very important one, I understand the matter was raised in the House of Representatives yesterday with my colleague, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. She quite firmly stated yesterday her view that no public inquiry could be justified, and that is also my view. I spent most of one afternoon last week in Sydney being briefed on the 1,900 submissions that have been received by Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd on the EIS. They canvass every conceivable issue that could possibly be canvassed, I might add, at the end of an extremely extensive public process. Mobile vans went around to the affected communities and it was widely advertised that they would be there. There was a wide open process to allow the maximum public input into the process.

I believe very firmly that no good public purpose would be served by any public inquiry. Considering the public inquiries that have been held under that process in the past and the time taken for them, it would effectively remove, in my view, the construction of the third runway at Sydney airport from the Government's agenda for this term of office. That, of course, is precisely what the people proposing it want to have the inquiry for but, as far as I am concerned, there is no justification for it and it would not add anything to the information that has already been received as part of the EIS process.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FLOODING IN CENTRAL AND NORTHERN QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. The Minister will be aware of the terrible effects of flooding in central and northern Queensland and the disaster relief provided under Commonwealth-State guidelines. However, is the Minister aware that under these guidelines there is no recognition of effects of continual rain damage? For example in Mackay, where there have been record rains exceeding the yearly average by 30 per cent and not equalled since earlier this century, extensive road damage and coastal erosion caused by these rains are not recognised for disaster relief, because they are not considered to be littoral flooding. Will the Government examine the need for some flexibility in providing disaster relief where there is excessive damage caused by continuous and very exceptional rainfall?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of the problems which Senator Reynolds raises, both from the television news and from information from friends who live in some of these affected areas. The measures which are administered at the present time by the Department of Finance relating to national disaster relief are also jointly administered by State governments. Senator Reynolds's specific question goes to whether rain damage would be included under these arrangements. I have been advised that various sorts of rain damage may be eligible for national disaster relief arrangements assistance, depending on the circumstances, and that the Queensland Government has issued detailed guidelines covering these circumstances-for example, providing for concessional loans to farmers with rain-damaged crops, specifying the sort of road damage to which local councils can seek assistance for repair, and matters of that kind.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, I think there has to be some sort of line drawn to distinguish exceptional events from those which individuals, State and local governments, ought to be prepared to cope with themselves. Guidelines applied by the Queensland Government have attempted to do this within broad principles set by the Minister for Finance. However, in the light of Senator Reynolds's question, I will see to it that the Minister for Finance asks his Department to consult with Queensland, specifically on the issues of rain damage to roads, and to determine whether there is a need for any change to guidelines for the existing practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Is it a fact that the initial sites selected by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) for the siting of the radar heads for the new radars at Cairns and Coolangatta have had to be altered because of environmental protests? Given the fact that there is mountainous terrain close in to the west of both fields, has there been any degradation in the air space coverage from the selection of the new sites?

—I do not have an answer to that question. Of course, it is a very serious one. I will seek an answer from the CAA immediately and advise Senator MacGibbon either later today or tomorrow in Question Time.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Defence by noting that in a media release dated 14 June 1988, the Minister's predecessor, Mr Beazley, stated that defence exports would be precluded where there is `no reasonable risk of using the equipment against the citizens of a country with a dubious civil rights record'. I further note that in 1989-90, the Minister approved the sale of Strikemaster trainer aircraft to Somalia, whose government at that time had a well-documented record of using military force to kill its unarmed civilians and had established a counter-insurgency squadron in its air force. While the application was subsequently withdrawn, this was not the Minister's decision but that of the company concerned. I ask the Minister: firstly, does he accept that, had the trainer aircraft been delivered, pilots trained in them could have used the trainer in counter-insurgency attacks such as bombing and strafing villages? Secondly, does he accept that Iraq's PC9 trainer aircraft, for which the Minister had approved the sale of engine parts before Iraq invaded Kuwait, could have been used to train Iraqi pilots to attack Kurdish villagers with chemical weapons? Thirdly, does he further acknowledge the view put by David Lague in the Australian Financial Review of 6 February that the PC9s could have been used directly in an attack role? Fourthly, does he therefore agree that the moral distinction drawn in the defence export guidelines between combat and military trainer aircraft is artificial and expedient?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Mr Beazley did not make that statement in a press release but in an attachment. The word `precluded' was not used, so I suggest that Senator McLean should go back to his source material and should not re-interpret it. That does not take away the general thrust of his question, but I am disappointed that he has started on such poor bases. In terms of an answer to the first question, that was a judgment that my predecessor had to make. He quite clearly made a judgment that would not be in line with the suggestion which Senator McLean makes.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the second question: no, I do not think Iraq's PC trainer aircraft would have been used in any direct military sense in Iraq. It stands to reason that if Iraq has oodles of Mirages, MIG29s, Badgers and the whole range, quite clearly if it were to use military equipment against its own people it would be using them and not PC trainers.

The third question asked was: do I agree with the views put by David Lague? No, I do not. I have never found his articles overendowed with research or embroidered with much strategic thinking. The clearest example of that is this morning in his analysis of the amount of expenditure in the Gulf. He certainly seems to me to apply and belong to the cynical school of journalists. No, I do not put any weight to his thinking on that.

On the final point, I have never mentioned the words `moral distinction'. Senator McLean is entitled to if he thinks that is what it is based on and that there is a moral distinction between-using the shorthand term-lethal and non-lethal goods. I think that distinction is quite a clear one in terms of our export policy. I do not say that it is based strictly on morality. The honourable senator has drawn that conclusion; I have not, so I do not think it is artificial and expedient.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade inform the Senate of the reasons for the Government's refusal to permit the Taiwanese authorities, firstly, to change the name of their trade office in Australia from the Far East Trading Company to the Taipei Trade and Cultural Office; secondly, to open a representative office in Canberra; and, thirdly, to increase the number of staff employed in Australia?
—There has been no refusal. Those matters are under consideration, as I indicated in the press release on the subject matter not so many weeks ago. That remains the case.

—Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware of consumer and farmer concerns about misleading labelling on products such as processed fruit and vegetables and, in particular, juices? What action can the Federal Government take to ensure that consumers have the information to enable them to choose to buy Australian? In particular, what action can be taken to prevent misleading labelling on packaging?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Zakharov for her question. She has indicated that she has had many inquiries in her own electoral office. I am, of course, aware of widespread concern in the community amongst farmers and consumers about the adequacy of country of origin labelling on food products.

ANSWER.PARA: I strongly believe that Australians making purchases in the marketplace have a right to be informed of the country of origin of the foodstuffs that they purchase. They can then make a subsequent judgment as to whether they wish to support Australian farmers and those involved in our orcharding and fishing industry when they make their purchase.

It should be noted that the food standards code requires that all packaged food sold in Australia be labelled with a statement of where the food was made or produced. As Senator Boswell will recall, it became apparent last year that there were a number of problems with the labelling of fruit juices. It came to my attention that some suppliers of packaged fruit juices have been labelling their goods as `Australian' when in fact some or all of the juice content has been imported. It is my strong view that this is misleading to consumers and detrimental to our local citrus industry, and I therefore requested the Australian Food Standards Committee (AFSC) to address the situation.

The AFSC recommended that where any packaged fruit juice contains an imported fruit component, it must be labelled as such. I believe that health Ministers around Australia are looking to implement that recommendation. I was also concerned that presently unpackaged foods are not required to be labelled with their country of origin, and I directed the Australian Food Standards Committee to look at this issue also.

It recommended that unpackaged imported fish, fruit, vegetables and nuts should be labelled at retail level with a statement of their country of origin or an indication that they had been imported. I believe both these recommendations are being considered by health Ministers in the States and Territories and should come into effect later this year.

The Government takes seriously any suggestion that consumers are being mislead by country of origin labelling. The Trade Practices Act makes it an offence for a firm to make a misleading representation concerning place of origin of goods. I have been so concerned about it that I have referred the issue to the Trade Practices Commission to determine whether there has been a breach of the Act, particularly in regard to mislabelling of fruit juices.

I commend Senator Zakharov for her interest in this most important issue. I assure her and all honourable senators that the Government has been active in ensuring that consumers are provided with accurate information about the country of origin of food so that they can exercise their purchasing power in support of Australian producers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I refer to the Second Annual Waterfront Reform Conference held in Sydney yesterday. Did the Minister address that conference and defend the pace of reform? By `reform', does the Minister include increased productivity? When the Minister made the speech, was he aware that there would be no cargo handling in Sydney ports today while members of the Waterside Workers Federation hold their annual picnic day? How can the Minister defend the pace of reform while provision for this holiday continues?
—That is going to the heart of the matter!

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly is going to the heart of the matter! To take the six or seven parts of that question in order: yes, I did attend the function yesterday. In fact, I advised the Senate of that yesterday during Question Time, although Senator Lewis may not have been listening. I addressed the seminar. Far from defending the pace of waterfront reform, I criticised it. I am perfectly happy to provide the honourable senator with a copy of my speech, but I might say that my extemporaneous remarks went somewhat beyond the printed script. To be precise, for the advice of the Senate, I outlined the progress that has been made in the past 12 months, which has been significant.
—That would not have taken long.
—It has been what?
—I know that honourable senators opposite cannot do it in Question Time but, if they want to have a debate about it, they should bring one on.
—Or after.

—Precisely. The reform has been significant but the process has slowed down in a way in which I anticipated it would early in the process, because I thought that the end of last year and early this year would be-and I have said it in the Senate before-the slowest--
—How many redundancies have you had?

—I would like to start with you, Senator Walters, if I could organise that. In fact, for the information of Senator Walters, 13 workers will leave the Port of Cairns on 28 February, as I announced yesterday, and somewhere between 200 and 300 waterside workers will leave National Terminals (Australia) Ltd's operations early in March.
—How many have you put on?

—I am trying to answer a question asked by one of Senator Walters's colleagues. The maximum amount of discussion and cooperation is being gained at the moment in advancing the significant enterprise agreement which has to be advanced-and that is the Conaust Ltd agreement, particularly for the ports of Sydney and Melbourne-and that is a matter currently before the Industrial Commission. So far as a picnic day in Sydney is concerned today, that--
—That is every day.
—In response to that interjection--
—Order! Senator Collins, can I suggest that you ignore the interjections?

—You can suggest it, Mr President. I must say in response to that interjection from Senator Parer that he might like to look at some of the statistics about how much work is done on the waterfront compared with other Australian industry situations because he might be surprised by the result.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as those award conditions are concerned, they are being addressed in a comprehensive re-evaluation of the waterfront industry award, which is also currently before the Industrial Commission, which is precisely where it should be.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Is the Minister telling the Senate that he would prefer to support the views of Mr Tas Bull, the General Secretary of the Waterside Workers Federation, which is having its picnic today-we do not know where the picnic is being held-who has said that the pace of waterfront reform is on track, in comparison with what has been said by the Managing Director of Conaust? I understand that that is what the Minister is saying because some agreements are near finalisation.
—Clean your ears out.

—This is very important. The Minister said that there has been a lot of progress in the last 12 months. We want to know what that progress has been. I take it that what Mr Bull is saying is that there are several agreements near finalisation, whereas the Managing Director of Conaust has said:

QUESTION.PARA: We have made such meagre progress that one has to wonder what we might salvage out of the three-year process of the in-principle agreement.
Which of those statements reflects accurately what is really happening in this area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis would do himself and the Senate a lot more credit if he would do the slightest amount of homework before he started reeling questions off the top of his head. I did not say that I was satisfied with the pace of waterfront reform. I thought I was explicit about that. From that, we would have to make the obvious conclusion that on that matter Mr Bull and I to some extent disagree.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as Mr Setchell is concerned, Mr Setchell of course is acting for his company. He does not actually represent National Terminals, which has negotiated an agreement; he is its major competitor. He works for Conaust and it has not negotiated an agreement. I just said that in the answer I gave to Senator Lewis. The fact is that there has been a substantial agreement negotiated in Sydney and Melbourne with National Terminals. As I said before, the Conaust matter has been taken to the Industrial Relations Commission by Conaust, which is a right it has under the in-principle agreement which was signed and which provides for this process. That is where the matter will no doubt be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Because Conaust, I say for the third time and the last time, chose to take it there.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 13 February, from Senator Short:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to section 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:-
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to take measures to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations and mismanagement which have wrought hardship to all Australians'.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to take measures to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations and mismanagement which have wrought hardship to all Australians.

The Opposition has deliberately brought this matter before the Senate today as a matter of urgency rather than as a matter of public importance. It is a matter of great public significance and importance, but the reason we are debating it as a matter of urgency is that the Senate will have to vote on this matter at the end of the debate. I very much hope and expect that the Australian Democrats will support the matter of urgency. If ever in Australia's history we have had a need for a government to correct its mismanagement and the miscalculations it has made for a period of many years, as a result of which each and every Australian, in whatever walk of life he or she may be in, is suffering great hardship, it is the situation that we have today.

I am very disappointed that Senator Button, representing the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) is not participating in this debate. It is not the first time that he has welshed on such a debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the first part.

—We have had similar debates on this and related matters in recent months and each and every time the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) has refused to participate. As he just said to me, one of the reasons is that he agrees with the first part of this urgency motion.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate is of great importance. If we were to have a text for today's debate it would be a quote from the Treasurer, who in 1989 said:
a recession achieves nothing in structural terms other than induced social misery and corporate weakness.

That is precisely what the policies-not only miscalculated but also deliberately contrived policies-of this Government have produced over recent years under the stewardship of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer.

We have seen these miscalculations and disastrous policies in not just the Federal Labor Government but also every State government in the nation which has been Labor controlled. Indeed, we now have the incredible situation of three State Labor governments being forced to have royal commissions into their financial activities and financial dealings because of their ineptitude, incompetence and, in some cases, corruption in management of the States' finances. The great loser in this is the average Australian taxpayer, the average person, who looks to his or her government for competence, proper management, propriety and integrity. At the Federal and State levels we have seen a denial of those basic qualities that electors expect-and rightly so-from their governments.

In recent days the Federal Treasurer has said about the South Australian case and earlier about the Victorian case that there would be no bail-out of these Labor governments by the federal taxpayer. That is simply not true. There was a major bail-out in the case of Victoria. In the last 48 hours the Treasurer has given permission for the South Australian Government to breach the agreed Loan Council borrowing guidelines to the tune of almost $1 billion, which has an automatic impact on the public sector borrowing requirement of the nation as a whole. It is a direct call on the savings of this nation-savings which have been almost obliterated by this Government's policies. This is a further call on the national savings at a time when the Government's approach should be directed to increasing our pool of national savings and increasing the ability of the private sector to avail itself of those savings. In recent times the Government's operations have been directly opposed to that.

Indeed, so dramatic has been the blow-out in the Government's fiscal policy and so much has it lost control of fiscal policy that, far from having a public sector borrowing requirement of nil for Australia this year, as was predicted in the Budget, it now appears almost certain that the blow-out of both Federal and State Budgets will mean a public sector borrowing requirement of about 2 per cent for this financial year. This is a dramatic turnaround over a period of only two to three years. Three years ago, the public sector borrowing requirement, very rightly, was in a deficit situation; in other words, national savings were not being called on.

The turnaround in the fiscal position of the Government has been enormous. Now, partly as a result of that, we have a full-blown recession-a recession which both the Treasurer and Prime Minister said two days before the last election that we would not have. Then the Treasurer said that we were to have a slowdown-that a slowdown was what was required. Then he then said, `Well, we got it wrong and in fact it is a recession. We have pulled the levers. The levers have produced a slowdown but we also used them to produce a recession and this was a recession that we had to have'. He is now trying to weasel his way out of that because the Prime Minister has tackled him on it. Because of the ongoing dispute for leadership within the Government between the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, he has now backed down from that. He said that he did not really mean to say that, he perhaps went a bit too far with his language, and that, after all, it really was a slowdown that he was trying to have. In recent days both the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have misled in a dramatic way the Australian public about the nature of the problems confronting this nation.

There has been, as I said, a major blowout in the Federal Budget. The Budget surplus for this year was estimated at Budget time to be $8.1 billion. Obviously that has gone for all time and the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis, said on 31 January that the figure would now probably come in at about $4 billion for the year. Significantly, the Treasurer and the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, have refused to support that figure. The Treasurer has said that he cannot put a figure on the actual outturn at this stage. Yesterday, the Leader of the Government in the Senate said much the same thing in response to a question that I asked him.

The facts are very clear. They are very well-exampled, listed and analysed in a report that was released two days ago by Schroders Australia Limited. Let me quote from that report, which is the most detailed analysis of the current fiscal position of the Federal Government that has been produced this year. The synopsis of that report is as follows:

The Commonwealth's 1990/91 Budget is likely to come in closer to balanced than the Commonwealth's revised $4 billion surplus estimate. A marked fall in employment over the first half of 1991 could see the Budget slip into deficit . . .

Such an outcome means a major revision of the Government's financing policy for the remainder of 1990/91. The Commonwealth will now have to issue around $7 billion of new debt to finance its Budget and meet redemptions of maturing government bonds and overseas debt.
The report then says:

The extent of the cyclical deterioration in the Commonwealth's accounts raises questions as to whether State budgets and financing requirements are coming under similar stress due to Australia's economic downturn. Certainly the starting point for next year's Commonwealth and State budgets will not seem as attractive as initial expectations for this year's outcome.

Indeed, if we look at the Government's own forward estimates for 1991-92 and compare them with the major deterioration both on the outlays and revenue sides of the Federal Budget this year, we can see that the problems of framing a 1991-92 Budget are absolutely horrendous. If we in Australia think that we have had economic hardship as a result of the current recession to date, compared with what will be the situation just a few months further down the track, what we are now facing is only a small portent of what is to come.

Even the Treasurer's chief economic adviser during the mid-1980s, Professor Barry Hughes, who is now the Professor of Economics at the University of Newcastle, has said, in the last couple of weeks, that the recession may be worse than that of 1982-83 and there is doubt as to whether there will be any recovery at all in the Australian economy in 1991. He makes the very significant point that, to the extent that there will be a recovery at all, the pattern of that economic recovery is unlikely to be the investment and export-led event that, ideally, the country requires, because investment in equipment is weak and new work in structures will have almost disappeared. That is a view that has been echoed many times by the Opposition in recent months.

The state of the Australian economy is not a result of forces outside the Government's control. The reason why we have problems in Australia today can be sheeted home only to the Federal Government. The outlook is compounded by the fact that there is a deteriorating overseas economic situation. Indeed, the forecast by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development of economic growth in the developed world for this year is a 2 per cent increase, down almost one per cent from the forecast of less than six months ago, and probably likely to be too overly optimistic anyway.

Even at 2 per cent, economic growth in the developed world would be the lowest it has been since 1982. That has implications for Australia's external position where, despite the fact that we have had a recession now for more than 12 months-this economy started to go into recession at the end of 1989-and despite all the pain that has been suffered by this economy and the people of Australia for a period approaching 18 months, there has been virtually no improvement in the balance of payments; our imports continue to rise; our exports, even more worryingly, have fallen; and our competitive position has continued to deteriorate.

When one puts those factors together with the major easing of fiscal policy that has occurred, as I have outlined in recent months, and the addition to the easing of fiscal policy caused by the blow-out in the figures of State governments, one has the seeds of a very real economic disaster.

The fact is that major expenditure and revenue reduction measures have been taken in recent months which have not yet started to impact on the economy and on the Budget. Despite that, government spending in the first six months of this year has blown out by a figure of no less than 11.5 per cent. In some areas-for example, social security expenditure-the increase in spending in the first six months of this financial year was no less than 21 per cent higher than for the same period last year. If expenditure rises by the same amount in the next six months as it did in the corresponding six months of last year, then the Budget will be out, on social security expenditure alone, by a figure in excess of $2 billion. There have been similar types of blow-outs of varying magnitudes in virtually all other areas of government expenditure.

On the revenue side, the signs of meeting the Budget forecasts are equally dim. Revenue is down for the basic reason that this economy has been so crushed by the policies of this Government, that demand has fallen like a stone. Indirect tax receipts have fallen and the increase in pay as you earn income tax payments has been reduced very severely from Budget forecasts. This is because the Government, in framing this year's Budget, got it absolutely wrong in terms of the parameters on which the Budget was based, such as the rate of growth of the economy; the export performance that was expected; the inflation rate-it is going to get that wrong; and certainly the unemployment rate is going to be way out.

All of the parameters on which the Budget was based have now been shown to be wrong, yet the Treasurer is failing, and has refused to date, to provide any revised forecasts of the economy for the remainder of this financial year and, therefore, any basis for judging what will be the situation within which the economy is working. The miscalculations and the disastrous policies of the Government have impacted on every Australian. The hurt to people has been very great. We are now facing record levels of bankruptcies of small businesses. Families, particularly those on single incomes and with young children, are finding it almost impossible to make ends meet. With the interest levels that they face, home buyers have been slugged almost to bankruptcy in trying to meet house repayments. The rural sector has been hit, not just at the farm level but right through provincial Australia, by these interest rate and associated policies. In terms of the hurt on individual Australians, Senator Brownhill will be saying much more later in this debate, as will Senator Walters.

It is interesting to note that one of the most affected groups in Australia, as a result of these disastrous policies of this Labor Government, is those people on average weekly earnings-the ordinary hardworking Australians who have often been the traditional base for Labor votes. Just look at what this Government has done to them. Senator Kemp mentioned some of these figures in the Senate during debate prior to Christmas. They are very salutary figures and worth repeating. Senator Kemp stated that the advent of the Hawke Government had seen a very dramatic fall in after-tax earnings by average weekly wage earners. He went on to say:

In 1982-83, average male weekly earnings after tax totalled-and these are in real dollars-$475 per week. Today-eight years after the original accord; eight years after all the promises of improvements in living standards to Australian workers; eight years of a Labor Government whose main interest one would have thought would have been the welfare of Australian workers-the comparative figure has fallen by $23 per week after tax. That latest figure is based on Budget forecasts.
As I say, those Budget forecasts will prove to be wrong and to be detrimental to those workers. Average wage earners in Australia have been decimated by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of public importance, so called by the Standing Orders. Under that heading the Opposition has brought on for debate a motion which is styled:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take measures, to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations and mismanagement that have wrought hardship on all Australians.

They are the Opposition's words. It has framed the motion in those terms. Given that those are the Opposition's terms, I sat here quietly for 20 minutes waiting for Senator Short, in whose name this motion appears, to say what are the measures that should be introduced now. He has not said what those measures are. He has not indicated what reforms he, as a spokesman for the Opposition on the economy, would make. If he believes his rhetoric about the parlous state of the economy-it is certainly not as good as we would like, and I will deal with that in a minute-and if he is genuinely moved by concern about it, one would have expected that the concern was not simply to be expressed as a hand-wringing exercise in criticisms of the Government but would be expressed in a constructive mode by saying what the changes would be.

Senator Short has not chosen to do that. He has chosen not to make any suggestions and not to propose any courses of action. That is not surprising to anyone who has followed the Opposition in economic debate in this country. It is not surprising because the Opposition does not have a coherent set of policies to deal with the economic management of this country. Instead, it has a political strategy aimed at attacking the short term problems of the economy and trying-as an opposition ought to, and I do not criticise it for this-to exaggerate the short term problems, talk down the possibilities of future recovery and pretend that circumstances are worse than they are.

If an opposition pretends to be a government, it must have a plan for dealing with issues of economic management. We have that plan. We are seeing that plan through despite the difficulties that we face in the short term. We certainly do not want the recession that we are in but despite those difficulties we will see Australia in recovery at the end of this year and we will see a situation in which the fundamental issues of the economy, the fundamental driving engines of improvement and reform, are carried through to make sure that Australia is positioned as best it possibly can be in the world economic scene.

It is predictable that the Opposition should, in this run up to 12 March, enter into parliamentary debate on a matter such as this. It is predictable because it knows that on 12 March this Government will be making a major statement on industry policy. We will be putting down a document setting the course and direction for reform of Australian industry into the next century. We will be doing that in March. The Opposition knows as well that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has indicated that he will be making a statement on the economy at the same time. The newspapers, particularly the financial press, the economic journals, have been full of comment about what those statements might contain.

I think it is predictable that the Opposition should move before we put down an orderly, considered initiative about the changes we propose to introduce. It is not surprising that the Opposition should raise this criticism and call for some changes in an effort to pretend that it has had some influence on the policy directions of this country. It cannot have influence if it does not have a policy. The Opposition does not have a policy, it does not have influence. The Government is going down the track of the orderly reform that it is proposing. It is also predictable that the Opposition should try to make some capital out of the recession. We in the Labor Party do not want a recession. We in the Labor Party identify with the ordinary Australian, the average battler in this country, and we understand and sympathise with the difficulties a recession imposes on him.

It is wrong to concentrate simply on what the problems are; it is right to concentrate on what the solutions are and the solutions will be outlined when we come to our statement. Meanwhile, the Opposition will do as it has done. The fundamental concerns of this Government are to improve the industry performance of this country and turn Australia into an exporter of manufactured goods on a scale and at a level much greater than in the past and to throw off the shackles of the somnolent years of McEwenism. That is something that the Fraser Government did not bother to tackle but it is what we have done through the steel plan, through the industry plan, through the progressive winding down of tariffs and through the exposure of Australian industry to international competition to give it the cold shock of having to deal in the international market and become more competitive.

As well, it is what we have done in lifting school retention rates-school retention rates increased dramatically in this country before the recession-in order to point Australia in the direction of the clever country. It is what we have done as well in massively expanding the participation rate in the work force; that is, the number of Australians between the ages of 16 and 65 who are employed.

On that point, if the participation rate in this country was the same as it was in the last years of the Fraser Government, the unemployment rate on today's figures would be 2.8 per cent. That is an indication of the expansion that we have been able to effect in the number of Australians who have jobs. It is only because the gross number of Australians who have work has increased so dramatically that the unemployment figures appeared as they have. With those remarks, might I say that one of the points of common attack upon this Government in recent weeks has been the fact-and it was referred to only fleetingly, I might say, in the remarks made by Senator Short-that the Budget surplus will not come in as predicted in the Budget Papers last year. Indeed, we had a prediction of a Budget surplus in excess of $8 billion for this budgetary year. It now appears that it will be about half that, or a bit under that figure.

The debate around this point suggests that somehow or other that is a reflection on our economic management. I want to say to that argument that at least we are now arguing in this country about a Budget surplus. When we took over from the previous Government, when the Treasurer was Mr Howard and the chief adviser on economic policy to him was Dr John Hewson, we came to the treasury bench in this country with a Budget deficit of over $9 billion. The difference in this debate is that we are talking about a surplus, and it is a significant surplus; and we have had a surplus four years in a row.

But the surplus has declined for a couple of very interesting reasons. One of them is that the Opposition chose to knock over a government Bill to sell the Australian Pipeline Authority. Had that Bill not been knocked over, the surplus would have been at Budget level. The other thing that the Opposition did was knock out the assets test on family allowances and, had it not done that, we would have been in a position of coming closer to the predicted surplus level. So if there is any argument about the failure of this Government to deliver its surplus, the first thing that should be said is that the Opposition has taken action to deny to the Government the budgetary measures that would have enabled it to do so and it has done so in a way which is quite inequitable and unfair to ordinary Australians.

I do not want to continue this line of analysis beyond making the next two points because it is not necessary to do so. But if there is a debate about the level of the surplus, then one would have to forget that there is extra expenditure on the Government because of the participation in the Gulf war and one would also have to ignore the fact that as a Government decision, but one rightly hailed across the broad sweep of the community, we engaged in buying out the September quarter wage round last year with a tax cut, which went to ordinary Australians on 1 January this year. This was a significant tax cut in real terms, which in fact increased the purchasing power of ordinary wage packets quite considerably. From those points of view, the debate about the surplus-should it be raised by the Opposition in this debate as an indicator of a failure of economic management-is a hollow debate and one that is bound to rebound on it. In any case, the fact that we have a significant surplus enables us to have a cushioning effect, particularly for those who are hit by unemployment, because we are maintaining vital training and educational expenditures despite the fall in tax receipts. I think those points need to be kept in mind.

What I want to talk about for the next few minutes is a couple of the key areas of economic activity that the Opposition glosses over and that the leader writers in newspapers sometimes gloss over because they do not understand a wider view of how the economy interacts and works. They talk about some of the aspects of poor performance, which certainly do exist and for which we would like to see some change and achievement, but which we recognise in the context of the overall performance and not in isolation from the other effects.

Let me turn to the current account. In the six months to December 1990, the current account deficit fell, as honourable senators in this place would know, by 28 per cent compared to the year earlier. Imports were down by 4.2 per cent. Perhaps Senator Short will correct himself here. In the introduction of this item it was said that imports had in fact risen whereas imports were down by 4.2 per cent. It was said as well that exports had fallen whereas exports were up by 8 per cent, with manufactured exports up by 13 per cent.

Maybe the rhetoric was not right-maybe Senator Short made a mistake when he said that imports were rising and exports were falling. If one looks at the December 1990 current account figure, the record is that imports are down and exports are up. Those figures are a healthy sign. Indeed, a table published yesterday in the Australian newspaper shows that between 1985 and 1989 manufacturing employment in Australia grew by 9 per cent-this is higher than the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) average; it is higher than the United States, higher than the Federal Republic of Germany, higher than Japan, and higher than the United Kingdom.

It shows that Australian manufacturing exports grew by 79 per cent between 1985 and 1989 compared with the OECD average of 31 per cent. We were only shaded by the United States with a growth in manufactured goods exports of 81 per cent, but we were much higher-I emphasise this point again-than Japan, which had a growth of 8 per cent, Germany 23 per cent and the United Kingdom 32 per cent. The fundamental problem in the Australian economy is that our consumption levels have been higher than our production levels. The Australian Government's economic strategy has been to dampen consumption growth and to expand our production, to make the compensatory leap and to make a further leap into export industry.

I turn now briefly to the matter of interest rates. Monetary policy has been the major discretionary weapon open to the Government to restrain economic activity. We have already run a very, very tight fiscal ship. I notice that in the speech made just a moment ago there was an inference that there is considerable room for further government cuts in expenditure. If that is the case, why does the Opposition not do as it has been invited to do consistently for some time now and itemise what social welfare programs, what part of the education budget and what part of the health budget are going to be cut so that the benefits to welfare recipients, to those in the education system and to those who rely on hospital and medical attention that are to be reduced and cut, can be identified?

Why does not the Opposition come out and tell us what it means when it says that government expenditure can be cut further? Does it want to say that in the climate of crisis in the Gulf our support for the military endeavour there ought to be reduced as well? It is about time that we had from the Opposition some indication of what it means. It cannot be judged as a viable alternative to government unless it specifies what damage it will do to the welfare and standing of ordinary Australians. On the question of further government cuts, it is about time that it was more specific than it is.

However, my point is that monetary policy has been the major discretionary weapon open to the Government because we have been frugal and restrained in government expenditure. We have targeted welfare more accurately. We have been more enlightened and innovative in the other areas of health and education. So we already have a very tight fiscal policy in action.

But in the face of all of that, it has got to be said that the cash rates have declined by 6 per cent since the beginning of 1990 and that they could conceivably decline further. Interest rates have come down significantly and they could decline further when we make some further inroads against inflation. I know this is going to bring forth, `What about today's inflation figure?'. I listened with a great deal of attention to what Senator Button said in answer to a question about that during Question Time today. I endorse what he said absolutely.

The figures at the moment are pushed up artificially because of the volatility in petrol prices, given the Gulf war, and the underlying rate of inflation is still low. In fact, the next quarter's figures will show the elimination, one would hope, of the petrol price fluctuation, which will be heading down as well. So in this climate, despite nonetheless a tight fiscal policy and a hard monetary policy, we have still brought down interest rate levels by 6 per cent, and housing and mortgage rates are now at 14 1/2 per cent.

I have briefly referred to today's consumer price index figures. In the concluding minutes that I have I want to talk about employment. This is a subject on which any Labor government is fundamentally concerned to put its merits on the line because we want to see jobs available for all those who seek employment. Over the years of this Government, the number of people in employment has increased by 1.6 million. That has been the growth in new jobs that have been created in the period of this Government. Since 1983, our employment growth has averaged 3.5 per cent annually compared to the OECD, all the advanced countries of the world, of 1.7 per cent. We averaged 3.5 per cent and they averaged 1.7 per cent. That is our performance compared to them. During the 1982 recession, unemployment rose from 6.8 per cent to 10.1 per cent in the 10 months to April 1983. Under this Government, unemployment has been reduced from 10.2 per cent to 8.1 per cent, and in our view it is still too high. The participation rate, the number of people actually in the work force, is much higher. The figure is 63.9 per cent compared to 60.4 per cent during the Fraser years. As I said earlier, if we had the same participation rate today as we had in 1983, then on our figures the unemployment rate would be 2.8 per cent.

I will conclude by talking briefly about the Australian Labor Party-Australian Council of Trade Unions wages accord, which has been significant in restraining wage growth in this country. It has enabled the Government to manage the incomes of ordinary Australians by giving tax cuts, and to manage the value of the income they then have by introducing Medicare and other services, particularly for those at the lower end of the income levels in this country. This has meant that they have been better off as a consequence-the value of the money they have has gone further.

Nonetheless, the Government has a wages policy; by contrast, the Opposition has no wages policy other than some vague idea of pushing the number of unions into the thousands by introducing enterprise unionism; re-embracing the high disputation levels of industrial disputes, in which Australians were set against Australians during the Fraser years; and turning over our massive achievement of reducing industrial disputation by 61 per cent from what used to apply during the Fraser years. The Opposition has done those things while restraining wage levels.

The Opposition comes in here and talks about how real wages have fallen. Real wages have fallen, but real household disposable income per capita-that is, the amount of money in a household-has risen. If we take the real wage measure we see that real wages have fallen, but if we take the value of money in terms of wages, taxes and benefits supplied to the community, we see that real household disposable income per capita, per individual in the household, has risen during our period of government. That is a significant achievement. It is not an achievement that is as high as we would like. We would have liked to have seen more done on that front, but we have been supporting significant and massive change in terms of industry policy to improve the wealth creation mechanisms of this country.

As I have said, we will be making a major statement on how we intend to take the next round of the course on 12 March. When we put down our industrial policy statement on 12 March, followed by an economic statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Opposition will see the measures of a progressive, forward-looking government caught by a recession that it did not want. This Government is in a position to say how it intends to effect a recovery in the second half of this year so that ordinary Australians can be better off. We can do it by managing wages policy, as we will continue to do, and we can do it by managing on all the other economic fronts I have talked about. The Opposition will have to watch this space to hear those reports on 12 March.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the following matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take measures to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations and the mismanagement which have wrought hardship to all Australians.

Like the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), I have listened in vain to Senator Short. I have failed to gain some knowledge from him on the measures that the Opposition intends to advocate in the terms of the topic that has been put forward today. I should say at the outset that the Australian Democrats will vote for the motion. We will vote for the motion not because we necessarily agree with the Opposition which is totally unable to propose alternative measures; we will vote for it because we did not agree with the policies of the Government which have brought the Australian community to this low ebb of economic activity and the social hardship which people are now experiencing. It is common ground that Australia is in a recession engineered by the Government, aided and abetted by the Opposition. The Opposition did not oppose the policy of high interest rates, and it continued to argue that farmers, home buyers and workers should be delivered to the mercies of the non-value market economy.

Deregulation is as much a religion for the Opposition as it continues to be for the Government, but whenever the Government retreats and agrees under pressure to some measures to assist exporters, farmers and small business people, the Opposition continues to say that we should stick to deregulation and we should not weaken even if the economic and social costs become horrendous. The economy is bad and this is clearly illustrated by the fact that unemployment has increased by 250,000 people since October 1989. Retail turnover declined in real terms by 3.5 per cent in November 1990 and is still trending downwards-an ominous sign for the economy as well as for those people engaged in the retail industry. Bankruptcies have skyrocketed to 3,000 in the December quarter, compared with 1,874 in the previous December quarter, a rise of 56 per cent.

The annual change in the volume of money has collapsed from the speculative binge of the late 1980s level of nearly 20 per cent down to 7 per cent. It would appear that the banks have overreacted somewhat due to their massive bad debts and they are actually rationing credit even though interest rates have dropped considerably. Lower official interest rates simply are not being fully passed on to home buyers or small businesses. In fact, the banks are now operating on historically high margins of between 3.5 and 4 per cent, more than double the accepted international average.

It is quite clear that bank deregulation, as part of the overall deregulation binge, has contributed severely to the boom as well as to the current bust. Until recently we thought that bad debts, which I believe is a better, more honest term than `non-performing loans', were largely the major contribution of the banks to this boom and bust. Last night Senator Paul McLean of the Australian Democrats documented further problems. He was prevented from doing so fully and in the sort of detail that public interest considerations demand. Unfortunately it goes further than bad debts. It would appear that the unrestrained greed that we have been exposed to by deregulation has really taken over in the banking sector and was a major contributor in the disasters that we are now facing.

Perhaps the most important social consequence of the economic recession that we are now in is the level of unemployment. In seasonally adjusted terms, the rate of unemployment rose from 5.9 per cent in December 1989 to 8.1 per cent in December 1990. It is generally agreed that the rate will continue to rise for much of the current calendar year. A sharp rise, something like a 50 per cent increase in the ratio of unemployed persons to job vacancies in the latter half of 1990, would seem to indicate that we have a long way to go before we see an upturn.

Of particular concern must be the position of young people in our society, and here we have a rapid deterioration in the youth labour market with a rate of unemployment among persons aged 15 to 19 rising from 15.1 per cent in December 1989 to 23 per cent in December last year. Similarly, if we compare that rate with the rate for another group of people who are particularly disadvantaged in our society, we see that the rate of unemployment of Aboriginal people is currently in most areas nearing-and in some in excess of-50 per cent.

To summarise, according to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, an estimated 176,000 Australians were retrenched in 1990, doubling the rate of 1989. This has had very distinctive consequences on employment in particular industries and various enterprises. The bad news continues to come in. In November Westpac, one of the banks, reduced its computer and administrative staff by 60 and the ANZ bank announced its plan to reduce its operations by 1,000 staff in 1991. The Commonwealth Bank is reported as planning to cut its recruitment by up to 2,000 over the next 12 months. The banks at least are going to ensure that they will not suffer by the bust they have contributed to. Nissan Australia has announced it will sack 750 staff and stop production for 18 days between early March and late April. Ford Australia has announced that it will cut a further 1,600 jobs from its Melbourne and Geelong plants on top of cuts already announced in late 1990. Australian Airlines is reported to be offering a redundancy package to 1,500 workers as part of a restructuring of its operations. Qantas has asked some staff to go on leave without pay and it is reported that 500 jobs are to be axed by the end of February.

These job losses are reflected in the social consequences that our society faces. The Victorian Council of Social Service report of last April, entitled Off the Street Begging and the Australian Social Security System, reports that it:
. . . estimated . . . 30 per cent of Victorian pensioners and beneficiaries were forced to request emergency relief during 1987/88 . . .
Further, it found:
. . . unemployment beneficiaries and sole parent pensioners were overrepresented among emergency relief recipients-
and no wonder. It also found:

. . . current waiting periods for pensions and benefits were causing significant hardship with around 50 Victorian individuals and families per week seeking emergency relief while waiting for unemployment benefits . . .

One of my colleagues, Senator Lees, from South Australia, last year talked at length with the Superintendent of the Brisbane City Mission, Reverend O'Connor, and he made an observation to her about the problems his organisation was facing as more and more people requested assistance. He said:

The Brisbane City Mission having served in the Valley for the past one hundred and thirty one years has now turned full cycle. Whereas in those early days we worked with convicts deported for stealing as little as a loaf of bread, we are today involved with children stealing food in order to survive.

The time has come for the Government to take action rather than abdicate responsibility and leave it up to markets dominated by foreign financiers. We need a carefully targeted policy of industry incentives combined with an equally careful partial re-regulation of the financial system to boost national savings, to contain imports and to ensure that Australia's economic policies are integrated with our environmental and social justice objectives. Private greed of the type we have seen in the last few years must never again be allowed to damage the national interest as the unrestrained overseas borrowings of the paper entrepreneurs did during the 1980s.

We need a determined effort to boost exports and reduce imports. That is one of the highest priorities in the Australian Democrats' economic package to beat this recession. This will include export incentives and measures to increase the capacity of Australian industry and primary producers to compete in overseas markets. We believe that industry should be enabled to improve productivity through measures such as accelerated depreciation allowances for major export oriented projects, one of the recommendations of the Australian Manufacturing Council. I could not suppress a smile when the Council said, on the one hand, that deregulation should be allowed to continue, mirroring somewhat the views of some commentators-certainly, to a large extent, those of the Opposition and, perhaps to a slightly lesser extent now, of the Government-that we really cannot admit our mistakes and must continue to pay at least token respect to the concept of deregulation.

An item that appeared in the Australian on 9 February quoted an Australian Chamber of Manufactures' submission as saying that deregulation needs to be `managed' to overcome these disadvantages. One cannot have it both ways. One either leaves it up to the market or one uses carefully targeted intervention to bring about the sorts of results that our economy and our society need.

Apart from measures to assist industry, such as the accelerated depreciation allowance that I mentioned, we need measures to encourage exporters to boost their efforts. Our policy would include a 5 per cent bounty on the value of new exports. Before the cry of `Where's the money coming from?' goes up, let me say that, on the basis of last year's figures of new exports of some $2.8 billion, it would be an expenditure of an additional $140m to double our new exports-surely a worthwhile investment. We believe also that the current export development schemes should be supported and increased and we regret that our amendments to the export development grants scheme legislation, which sought to do that, were not supported by either old party.

We are particularly concerned about primary producers and believe it is high time that the anti-dumping procedures, which are antiquated, slow and nearly worthless, were overhauled. We believe it absolutely necessary that the onus of proof be reversed. We believe that, if foreign countries choose to dump at our doorstep products which are clearly way below production costs on a prima facie basis, it should be up to them to prove that they are not dumping the products and that they are engaging in what might be called `fair competition'.

Let me address the major problem I believe we are facing. The Government and the Opposition seem to believe that we must deliver our farmers up to the mercy of the world markets in the hope of getting the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round of negotiations to the point where they prevail upon some of the countries in the European Community, and the United States, to reduce their massive subsidies, some of which are as high as 40 per cent, to their primary producers. It seems to the Australian Democrats that, while we are prepared to allow other countries to engage in such practices, we should help our farmers until those countries too are prepared to come to the table.

There are other measures I believe we should take-that is, in our legal and regulatory system. We should ask the Reserve Bank to supervise our financial system and to control the taking up of high loans from overseas lenders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting Senator Short in this matter of urgency today in the Senate which is:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take measures to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations . . .

And how disastrous they have been. We can have no better proof of those disastrous policy miscalculations and their consequences than the recent Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) Agricultural Outlook Conference figures. They are a litany of doom and gloom for agriculture, and one industry after another is going down the chute. Agriculture is under a lot of stress and strain. Let me range through just a few industries.

In the sugar industry, 12 months ago ABARE was predicting that world sugar prices would continue to rise throughout 1991 and they are now at their lowest level since 1988 after a 40 per cent collapse. Grape prices have fallen 50 per cent as wine sales falter, and the industry is blaming a depressed economy. In the rice industry, the Australian production costs are creating increasing difficulties for growers to compete fairly with imports.

The price of wheat is at its lowest for 60 years. Let us look at what happens to the poor old wheat farmer with a government impost of indexation of the fuel excise, for example, and the increase in fuel prices. In the forest products industry, slower economic growth in Australia is the major reason for the forecast general decline in the consumption of forest products, according to ABARE. The timber industry, for example, cannot even get a guarantee from this Government concerning access to forests in the future. In the dairy industry, prices paid to Australian producers of manufacturing milk are forecast to decline in 1990-91. We can see what high interest rates do to the dairy industry.

Now let us look at wool. The wool industry is in confusion and chaos, with debts of nearly $3 billion and rising. This year the woolgrower will get some 30 per cent of what he got a year or so ago. Let us look at the chaos that has been created in that industry by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, travelling the world and saying that the 700c reserve price scheme was immutable and would not be changed.

Our export industries are in a disastrous state and have fallen dramatically in value in the last year or two. Wheat exports have gone down from $2.6 billion to $1.8 billion. Mutton exports have gone down from $204m last year to $141m this year. We can go through the litany of our export industries. They are all down. They are down as a result of the pressures put on them by the Government which is presently in power in Canberra and rules Australia-eight years of a litany of government problems.

Those are some bare economic facts. Let me give the Senate some other results of eight years of Labor being in power in Australia. For example, 54 per cent of sheep properties have liquid assets worth less than their debt. As I have already said, their incomes will drop by 70 per cent this year. Broad acre farmers are in exactly the same position. Let me give the Senate an example of the chaos that has been created by this Government. Let us try to imagine ourselves as woolgrowers. A specialist woolgrower has no other income; he just grows wool. He shears once a year and sells once a year. He prepares his budget for his bank and his accountant based on what he knows and his expected returns. Up till last year that was not too hard to do; it was reasonably easy. But this year it has become extremely difficult-beyond the pale.

Let us say that the specialist woolgrower sells his wool every February. He sold last year with a floor price of 870c clean and an 8 per cent wool tax. He based his 1991 budget on that. Last October he was forced to revise his budget based on the 700c floor price and a tax of 25 per cent-a tax that was put on last June. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy said that it was an immutable price; that the 700c reserve price scheme would stay-it was immutable for the next two seasons. Let us look at the chaos that that created for the wool industry.

The woolgrower shore his sheep in January amidst speculation about quotas, slaughter schemes and thousands of other rumours. Let us not forget that he has no options for other income. He responsibly tried to cull his old ewes and hoped for the best. He tried to sell his wool last week and was told that the sales were off. He does not know what he will get for this year's work or when he will get it. His budget is out the back door. The kids might have to leave school. It is very good to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in the chamber to listen to this debate. I know that he is interested in this area and in the tax area.

The woolgrower has his quarterly provisional tax payments to make. He might have to pay some of his income tax as well. The quarterly payment of provisional tax, of course, was a Government initiative. The farmer is wondering how he will get his income, because there have been no wool sales. I have written to the Parliamentary Secretary asking for something to be done about those people.

Wheat growers are in a lot of trouble as well. Their incomes are down dramatically. In many cases, that is because of the fuel costs and the costs of running their properties. In my own district, I have an example of a gentleman talking about interest rates. This gentleman is Mr Keith Norman. I quote from the Land newspaper, which states:

Facing bills of $200,000 this year for interest payments, living expenses and the cost of growing his crops, and with no income since the middle of last year, he is counting on this summer's sorghum, sunflowers and corn to get him through till Christmas.

And, of course, he has just had a big flood. The point is that he is blaming the sustained interest rate rises for the problems that he is having in his industry. Interest rates have hurt all farmers. They do not just hurt the people who have overdrafts; they hurt all farmers for the simple fact that they have to put an input into producing things on their properties. Those interest rates have permeated the whole of the economy so that input costs have risen. They have not come down, although bank overdraft interest rates have come back slightly.

The Australian Labor Party-I do not quite know what it is trying to do to the rural industries-has imposed high interest rates on Australian farmers that will be there for ever and a day. As I said, they are built into the whole system now, and I cannot over-emphasise that.

Farmers can and do face adversity well. Farmers in New South Wales alone have faced fires, floods and all the other things they have had come at them, including the things that the Labor Party has thrown at them. It is affecting the towns. The machinery dealers in the towns are being affected by high interest rates. The fact, of course, is that there is now no investment allowance to give people an initiative to buy machinery anyway. Look at what the Government has done with the depreciation allowance for fencing and housing on farms. Depreciation allowances have gone from the previous 20 per cent down to 5 per cent. The whole time, business overheads-the input into running properties-have been forced up by this Government.

As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) says, the economy is in a home-grown recession; it is all the Labor Party's own work and it is bringing this country to its knees. I agree with him. Mr Keating said, `This is the recession we had to have'. I can tell the Senate that that leaves me rather cold-very cold indeed. There is a very cold feeling amongst farmers and businessmen, whose life's work has been taken away by banks and mortgage holders. It is not, after all, Mr Keating who has been adversely affected by this recession; it is the ordinary, good, law-abiding citizens of this country who have been hit left, right and centre.

Mr Kerin has said that the outlook for Australian agriculture is subdued. God help us when he decides that the situation is serious. Certainly, the Federal Government's attempts at solving the problems have been subdued. They have to date amounted to minor fiddles with tax rates and vague threats to banks to encourage them to lower home loan interest rates. Tax cuts, of course, do not mean anything to people who are not earning income at all.

When will the Government get to work and do something about real reform of the taxation system instead of titivating it round the edges and let the Australian people do with their money what they want rather than Canberra taking a bigger and tougher grab at the meagre profits that we sometimes make? I have the concurrence of Senator Cook to incorporate a document of what we would do in government and what this Government must do. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard these policy imperatives put out by Dr Hewson.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
WHAT GOVERNMENT MUST DO-POLICY IMPERATIVES
There are at least eight fundamental structural policy changes which must be implemented:
1. Taxation Reform

We must have a simpler tax system that gives incentive to Australians to work harder, earn more and save. That means less tax overall and a bias in the tax system towards saving rather than spending. Government spending must be cut significantly (we have already identified spending cuts of $3 billion) to fund lower taxes. The broad-based consumption tax advocated by the Treasurer in 1985 and supported by the Opposition should be introduced with the result that personal income tax rates can be lowered significantly, wholesale sales taxes abolished, the `black' economy taxed and taxes on business inputs removed.
2. Labour Market Reform

The Government must abandon the Accord which has eroded real incomes, propped up inflation and given the ACTU too much power. A shift away from the rigid centralised system to true enterprise bargaining will lift productivity and give the workforce and employers an incentive to reach agreement on pay and conditions which will suit the needs of the enterprise and its employees and give them a better chance of holding their jobs through the recession. In addition, voluntary unionism and secret strike ballots will give workers more self-responsibility.
3. Efficient Infrastructure

Inefficiencies in telecommunications, transport, shipping, the waterfront and power generation impose major cost disadvantages on Australian industry trying to export or compete against imports. The answer is to inject proper competition into these sectors of the economy by opening up markets to newcomers and breaking down inefficient work and management practices, reducing regulations and reducing the hold that unions have on many of these activities.
4. Reform of Government Operations

Contracting out of Government services to the private sector can bring savings of up to 20%. Meanwhile, the Commonwealth and the States must agree quickly on the appropriate distribution of taxing powers and on cutting out areas of duplication of service so that taxpayer dollars are used efficiently.
5. Privatisation

Sleepy, inefficient Government-owned monopolies must be shaken up through exposure to competition and privatisation. The Government's halfhearted approach to privatisation must change so the full benefits of privatisation-efficiency gains, better service and lower consumer costs-are realised.
6. Industry Reform

Orderly and pre-specified reductions in protection (protection shields Australian industry from the stimulus of international competition) are an integral part of an economic reform package. With a more efficient economy, protection will become less and less necessary. Without economic reforms, industry will still try to lean on the crutch of protection and pass on the costs to Australia's export industries and Australian consumers.
7. Immigration
