The Government has failed to administer immigration guidelines effectively and has undermined the integrity of our immigration programme. Standards have been lowered to achieve annual targets. It is essential that existing migration criteria be enforced and the integrity of our programme restored. In the short term, as the recession makes Australia less attractive to skilled migrants and our economy has a reduced capacity to absorb migrants, the overall level of immigration will fall. However in the longer term, increased immigration will be of substantial economic benefit. Australia should retain its commitment to family reunion and refugee programmes.
8. Environment and Development

The Government must urgently set out clear and consistent guidelines to achieve an appropriate balance between development and conservation of the environment. An essential part of this is an effective policy on resource security. Once appropriate environmental standards are set, export producing projects like Coronation Hill and Wesley Vale must be allowed to go ahead if they are commercially viable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a couple of points about labour market reform. The Labor Party needs a fair bit of reform too. In fact, it needs as much reform as anything else around here. I will give a couple of examples of the need for labour market reform. Senator Cook said that there had been a fair bit of effort and that some progress had been made. At home the Gunnedah abattoir is a great example of why we need reform. The Australian meat industry is riddled with labour rorts. Sheep are selling at about 30c a head, if it is possible to get that much. Meat inspectors are asking for wage rises of 68 per cent and expect to be paid even when they have no full time work. On top of that, their union is claiming that there ought to be more of them.

SPEECH.PARA: At the Tamworth abattoirs we have the opposite. Meat workers have an agreement with management. The result is that the abattoir is profitable for the first time in its history. The workers are being paid more than they ever have been. The management is delighted with the throughput. One would think that the unions would be happy that workers were satisfied. But no, the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union is now claiming that the men at Tamworth are earning too much and working too fast. The union is demanding increased staffing when clearly there is no need for more staff.

I will compare abattoir costs in Australia to those in other parts of the world. In Australia it costs $111 per beast just for labour costs to slaughter and pack. In the United States of America it costs $36 to do the same job. In Uruguay, one of our big competitors, it costs $56. The total cost per beast in an export plant in the United States is $88; in Australia, $193. How will we compete unless this Government does something about it?

Because of automation, there has been an 8 per cent productivity increase in the poultry industry in the last 20 years. In the cattle and sheep abattoirs there has been a 1.8 per cent productivity increase but only a 1.6 per cent real growth increase in the throughput. That is all to do with tally systems and some of the other problems associated with the work force in those abattoirs.

Until this Government bites the bullet and introduces labour market reform, taxation reform, and an efficient infrastructure, until it reforms government operations, until it does something about privatisation, and until it reforms industry, this country will not prosper the way it should. There is only one way that this country will prosper and that, of course, is to change the government of the day, but we have to wait some time for that. This urgency motion has been brought forward by Senator Short to tell this Government to get on and do something about it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter purports to be a matter of urgency, and it certainly allows one the opportunity to discuss something that is important. When one approaches something as important as this-I do not know whether it constitutes an urgent matter-it is obviously necessary that we approach it fairly, frankly and honestly.

SPEECH.PARA: Being in government while the country is in recession is economically undesirable and it has undesirable social consequences; nobody should deny that. Therefore, everybody seeking to speak in this debate has an obligation to consider the causes of that recession or the circumstances in which we find ourselves and its consequences, and to make some proposals about its solutions. If one reads the urgency motion that is what one expects the debate to be about. Senator Short failed to do that altogether. Senator Cook has dealt with that. Senator Brownhill got to it in the very last moment. He did incorporate a document, I suspect perhaps because he realised he had forgotten to make any positive suggestions. So he came along and sought to incorporate the same old tired document from the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson).

There were two points that Senator Brownhill made to which I refer, one because he is rehashing an old argument without keeping up with the facts and the other because he raised an important issue of tax, which he has indicated he has written to me about. I am not aware of the letter but I understand the issue. I will say something positive about that.

He put a lot of emphasis on the problem caused for the rural industry by high interest rates. Of course, nobody could argue that, for anybody running any business on overdraft or similar facility, the lower the interest rates the better for that person. That is beyond question. The Leader of the National Party, Mr Fischer, toured rural Australia for some time. He talked about his 10-80 solution. He said that the key thing for the Australian Government to do was to get interest rates down to 10 per cent and get the value of the Australian dollar down below 80c. Suddenly he stopped talking about it because interest rates are down. The 90-day bill rate is now down to 11.5 per cent and the value of the Australian dollar is 77c. He is now trying to find a new benchmark. He has suddenly realised that he set a benchmark that has virtually been achieved and he needs to try to find some new basis for his concern. We have to put that into some sort of perspective.

Notwithstanding that criticism and the emptiness of the rest of the contribution, I acknowledge Senator Brownhill's concern raised about quarterly provisional tax. I do not in any way apologise for the generalised policy of quarterly provisional tax. The closer that people paying provisional tax are brought to the same circumstances as Australians on pay as you earn, the better. But clearly that provisional tax always causes potential concern for people when their income, because of circumstances beyond their control, or even if it is within their control, falls dramatically during the course of the year. This has potential to cause serious consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be worse when it rises dramatically.

—But it is a much easier problem to cope with. The problem that Senator Brownhill correctly raised is when people have a tax bill assessed on a reasonable projection of income and the circumstances dramatically change. Nothing could more clearly highlight that than the wool industry. The Act clearly allows-the option is open and I encourage every woolgrower in that circumstance to take it up-that where there is circumstance--
—Sixty thousand letters?

—They do not need to write to me. The Act makes it absolutely clear that what they can and should do is approach the Australian Taxation Office to advise it-they do not have to apply-of the changed income circumstance. If many of them have already made two quarterly provisional tax payments, it may well be that they have paid their full provisional tax bill for the year on the revised income estimates. That is not for me to say. I cannot assess the income of each individual and give any such guarantee, but there is certainly a potential for it to be dramatically reduced.
—As long as they don't get hit with a penalty if they are too far out.

—Anybody can make a reasonable assessment on any objective circumstance that both the price and the tax, which is a deduction from taxable income, would significantly affect it and they should take advantage of that. I am sure many already have. I wanted to respond positively to Senator Brownhill's legitimate point.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at what has been said about the causes of this recession and the alternative analyses made by the Opposition at the time and even now, with the virtue of 20 : 20 hindsight. Let us go through what the Opposition said when various initiatives were taken by the Government and see whether the Opposition predicted or in some way foresaw what is construed as the miscalculation.

As most students of economics will acknowledge, the origins of the current international economic circumstances lie in the 1987 crash of the stock market and the loosening of interest rates that followed. The Opposition overwhelmingly agreed with that loosening of interest rates at that time-and quite properly, because that is what was done in every modern Western economy because people were concerned about the ripple effect of the stock market crash. In fact, Senator Stone predicted that it was pointless doing that because it was inevitable that a recession would follow the 1987 crash. He also, with everybody else, acknowledged that we should do what we could to accommodate the business community so that the recession would not follow.

In terms of the need to reduce demand which arose as a consequence of the loosening and the boom which followed in 1989, who argued that there was no need to reduce demand? Nobody that I know, and certainly not the Opposition. We had legitimate debate about the methods and mechanism, because the Opposition always relies on cutting fiscal policy and cutting wages. The Opposition has to rely on pressure on fiscal policy because it has no anti-inflationary policy. Furthermore, it always looks to tighten wages policy as a euphemism for reducing wages because it does not have a wages policy. That is the fundamental reason why the Opposition does not have an anti-inflation policy.

Opposition members never acknowledge that fiscal policy is already tight, the tightest ever, and that wages policy is remarkably tight. The only way in which what they talk of as a change of wages policy could allow for an easing of interest rates would have been if that policy had delivered lower wage outcomes. So Opposition members cannot stand here and express concern that wages may not have risen fast enough, as Senator Short purported to do, and then say that we should have had a tighter wages policy. They cannot do this and then oppose every wage increase that has been granted, including the $12 increase that is coming. They cannot have it both ways.

Let us talk about the timing of the loosening. One of the miscalculations, as would now be accepted, is that perhaps monetary policy was loosened too late. What happened? In January 1990 when the Government first loosened monetary policy, did the Opposition say, `You are too late. Why did you not do it earlier?'. No, Dr Hewson, the then Opposition Treasury spokesman, said that lower rates could not be sustained, that we were pushing the pace and going too fast. That was said on 23 January 1990. On 1 February he said that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was still forcing the pace. Then on 15 February he said that these reductions were a blatant political act, that we were taking this course not because underlying economic circumstances required it but because it was required politically.

In regard to the most recent easing of monetary policy, in November, the shadow Treasury spokesman, Mr Reith, said that we should not be loosening interest rates because it would only lead to higher interest rates. Again, on 18 December he expressed concern that the recovery would be too strong as a result of the interest rate cut.

Opposition members cannot be concerned about the consequences of the slow pace at which we ease monetary policy and then, each time we ease it, oppose such a course because it is thought to be too soon and will lead to a demand resurgence. Unless those opposite wish to remain a permanent Opposition, which would be delightful from my point of view, they cannot continue to have it both ways.

I acknowledge that for this or any other government, or indeed for academics, economists and commentators, economics and economic prediction are very imperfect arts. Economics is unpredictable because it is based on an assessment of human reactions. Sometimes we cannot even assess the nature of that reaction, let alone the rate, because there is feedback in the system which needs to be accommodated. There are lags and problems of obtaining appropriate information. There are conflicting pressures, as in the housing market at present. We have the upward pressure of declining interest rates and the downward pressure of concern about unemployment. So economics is an imprecise art. There are unforeseen considerations and new factors that come in to reinforce or detract-considerations such as the problems of the wool and wheat industries and international uncertainty.

That is also the case in the current timing of the prediction of the upturn. There is no doubt that the preconditions for an upturn have been created. There is no doubt that during the course of this calendar year we shall see the first signs of that. But nobody can precisely predict when that will take place; only that it certainly will.

In this enthusiasm for gloom, let us not forget that there is gain from the pain. The current account is 30 per cent better than it was in the same period 12 months ago, notwithstanding falling export prices. Compared to a year earlier, in the six months to December, imports were 4.2 per cent lower, exports were 8 per cent higher, manufactured exports were in fact 13 per cent higher and the current account deficit was 28 per cent lower. That is not a recipe for complacency that everything is resolved but it does suggest that important improvements are taking place.

On the topic of inflation, today we got a bad inflation number but the underlying inflation rate is improving. I challenge the Opposition which said today that this inflation number was totally a product of our policy and a sign of failure. Did Opposition members acknowledge three months ago, when we had a remarkably good figure, that that was totally the result of our good policy and an accurate description of the situation? Of course they did not, because they do not fall for the sin of having a logical mind and being consistent. That is not a problem that confronts them.

I also challenge Opposition members to say now that they will accept that the next two inflation figures, which I predict will be very good ones, will be products of our economic policy. They cannot have it both ways. They cannot say that a high number is our fault but that the low numbers are a coincidence. The fact is that we will have not just some beneficial consequences of the fact that recessions ease demand pressure and therefore inflation falls but fundamental changes in the underlying inflation rate have been consistently flowing through for more than 12 months.

Increasing unemployment is a very difficult issue for any government, particularly a Labor government, to confront. It is a bad economic indicator but it is also very significant for the individuals and the families who are affected. Let nobody underestimate that. That is an inevitable adverse consequence every time one has to slow down demand, particularly when circumstances tip the economy over into a recession.

We have to recognise two things. This follows on a period of record employment growth in this country. Nothing equivalent has occurred for 40 years. We are still net 1.6 million jobs better off than we were before. If the participation rate were as it was when we came to office, the unemployment rate would be 2.8 per cent. That would still be too high because there are too many individuals adversely affected and it is a concern because it is rising. But let us not deny the reality of those figures.

Let us talk about whether there will be an improvement next year. I think inevitably all the indicators will say so and all the sensible forecasters are saying so. The Westpac forecast for 1992 is that the real GDP growth percentage will be 2.8 per cent and inflation for the fiscal year 1992 will be 4 per cent, after an inflation figure of 4.5 per cent this year. So there is the potential to break the back of inflation and inflationary expectations in Australia. This will create the circumstances where the cost of capital to Australian companies will be competitive with that of other countries with which we compete and will start to make a fundamental change in the nature of Australia's economy.

We need to look at the context of the difficult circumstances in which Australia finds itself. There is a recession not only in Australia but also in the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Canada. We are following a record period of employment growth, underlying inflation is falling and there is a trend improvement in current account deficit.

We reject the alternatives of increasing prices through a consumption tax, increasing unemployment through an attack on fiscal policy, abandoning an anti-inflationary strategy and, as I said, being required to squash growth--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest inflation figure just announced for this quarter of 2.7 per cent is a tragedy for Australia. Unfortunately, it underlines the horrific mess this Government has made of our wonderful country. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) on this occasion has stopped short of referring to it as a set of wonderful, beautiful figures. This time he has blamed the Gulf war, he has blamed the States for incurring extra taxation, indeed, he will blame anything that he can put his mind to, except his own incompetence. Of course, if the Government starves the States of money then, naturally, the States will have to raise their costs.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of the inflation rate going down as Mr Hawke promised us-and we remember that last year he said that we could have a slowing down and it would be about 6 per cent-it is now running at 10.8 per cent and there is nothing to tell me that the next couple of quarters, as Senator McMullan has said, are going to be any better. Financially, there is no light at the end of the tunnel to give me such confidence, and Senator McMullan keeps talking about an underlying inflation rate of 5.6 per cent. Where he gets it from I do not know.

The unemployment figure is due out tomorrow. I wonder what that will be. This time last year Mr Hawke said that the underlying figure would be 6 per cent. He said we can have a slowdown without unemployment occurring. He expected it to be about 6 per cent-it is now 8.1 per cent and the figures come out tomorrow. Senator Richardson has already said that the numbers are rocketing. He says that the Budget estimate of 475,000 people will be wrong-it will be out of kilter.

At the moment, those two promises from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are absolutely scuttled. How tragic it is that it took until last Sunday for the Prime Minister to acknowledge that he was wrong and say, `We have got it wrong'. How tragic it is that it took Mr Keating until Monday to come out and apologise that he had caused all this pain to the Australian people. Remember his recession that we had to have-the recession he personally engineered.

How tragic it is that the Government was so insensitive, pig-headed and egotistical that it would not listen to the Opposition or take any notice of it, month after month, year after year, pleading to change course. Not only that, but the Government also ignored the advice of its only Minister for Finance with any courage until, finally, he resigned in frustration.

Finally, how tragic it is that ordinary Australians who showed faith in the Hawke Government have never been told the truth about the mismanagement that has caused the suffering and the pain of seeing their life savings and investments disappearing before their eyes.

For the Prime Minister and Mr Keating to so belatedly tell the truth, admit they were wrong and say, `I am sorry', is not good enough. Too many people have lost their life savings. Too many people have been thrown on the dole. As the previous Labor Finance Minister said, it is a result of almost wilful mismanagement of our economy by the Keating-Kelty combination.

If Mr Hawke and Mr Keating think that all will be swept under the carpet and their apologies will be accepted on 12 March when they make their economic statement, apologising to Australia for wrecking the economy, sending people broke and having families sell their homes, then they are in a fool's paradise. Why should any businessman who has indulged in impeccable business management be forced to the wall because he borrowed money at 10 per cent and did not take into account, or foresee, that the Government could increase interest rates to over double that at which he borrowed, just because the Treasurer needed a recession? How can businessmen possibly invest under such circumstances? How can they plan?

Why should 1,700 workers be sacked by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd because interest rates were so high-Mr Keating kept them so high-that the motor vehicles cannot be sold in Australia? If we cannot afford to buy them here why can we not export them? Why can we not export more vehicles to New Zealand? With interest rates as high as they are we should not have been left with this tremendous cost.

Does the Senate realise that it is cheaper to ship cars from Melbourne to Auckland on the open route via Japan, than direct from Melbourne to Auckland? It is cheaper to go halfway round the world than it is to send them direct, using our flagships. Let there be no misunderstanding, Australia is not following the world's slowdown. It has not been forced on us; it has not touched us yet. We have been well ahead of the world's slowdown. Mr Keating has engineered his own recession. Because of the world's slowdown, we will have a far deeper and longer recession than would otherwise have been the case. Mr Hawke has admitted that as world demand for our goods slows down our problems will increase.

Let me deal with just a few of the Government's policies that have created the mess we are in. As I say, there have been 1,700 sackings from Ford in Victoria; 153 from BTR Engineering (Australia) Ltd, an Albury plant; and Nissan Motor Manufacturing Company (Australia) Ltd today announced that it is sacking 750 people. Why is this happening? It is because the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, will not accept his responsibility and do something about the waterfront.

Does he realise the consequence of these massive sackings? The blue-collar workers are being thrown out and put on the dole just because he cannot get his act together. The waterside unions have got him bluffed and they will not allow foreign flagships to take over from the Australian flagships plying our coast. The work practices that have been gained through blackmail and holding up ships in ports have devastated our transport costs. The consequences are financially and socially unacceptable to those vehicle workers, yet we know that the trade union movement, particularly on the waterside, says it will not tolerate any lowering of employment or alterations of its work practices.

In its annual report for 1989 the Industries Assistance Commission stated that reform of our waterfront, coastal shipping, roads, rail and aviation industry-that is, our transport system-would boost our gross domestic product by $9 billion a year, yet nothing has been done. The Government is plainly incompetent. The Minister who promised to resign-that is, Senator Collins-if he could not make substantial changes to the waterfront within 12 months, should carry out that promise and resign now. But I guess, like the rest of the Government, if he keeps to form, in 12 months time he will end up just saying, `I am sorry, I couldn't accomplish it'.

Let us have a look at a few of the apologies that have been made by the Government. Do honourable senators remember Mr Hawke's promise that no child would live in poverty by the year 1990? Yet in March 1990 Mr Hawke acknowledged that there were still 400,000 children living in poverty. Just because Mr Keating wanted a recession, there was no money available to lift their living standards.

Mr Hawke promised to do something about street children and drugs. Large amounts of money were spent on public relations exercises, but nothing was done about the street children and the drug problem. It has all just escalated.

Remember the best health care system in the world-Medicare? We had a firm promise that Australians had been given the best health care available. It is a pity, while all these apologies and breast beatings are going on, that the Government does not apologise for the mess of its health system. Despite the Government trying to contain costs by limiting beds, the health budget continues to blow out. We have ended up with pensioners and low income earners without any pull, without knowing whom they should approach, having to compete with the well-heeled in the community for a bed in public hospitals. There are no prizes for guessing who wins and who ends up on the waiting lists. We have pensioners waiting several years to have hip replacements while those who can afford to insure themselves get their hip done immediately. Last September the new Minister for Health, Brian Howe, called for massive spending on the public sector projects such as hospitals when he said:
The public sector cannot withstand continuing application of the intellectually lazy approach of ever-tightening funding producing ever-increasing discipline and efficiencies.
In response Mr Keating said:
There is no prospect of massive increases on public spending.

Mr Keating had to have his recession. He was engineering it. Everything had to slow down. Wherever we go around Australia, the signs of the recession are very obvious for all to see. Mr Keating may well have said that he is sorry but people are selling their homes and their properties, and the family runabout and trailer are out the front-all at bargain basement prices because the family's assets have fallen through the floor. People are scared stiff as they see the unemployment notices going out. People are terrified as they see bankruptcy headlines such as, `Western Australian bankruptcies leap by 100 per cent, Victoria 65 per cent, New South Wales 62 per cent'-all because the Government could not manage the economy, all because it had to interfere in the floating of the dollar, all because it had to keep tight control on interest rates rather than using other methods.

One after another the State banks of the Labor Government have gone broke-in Victoria and Western Australia, and now South Australia. I cannot believe for one minute that Mr Keating, with all the facilities available to him, with his access to the Reserve Bank of Australia, and with his colleague the Premier of South Australia, had no knowledge of this occurring, yet the Opposition in South Australia had been asking questions for over six months. We just cannot believe the Treasurer in this instance.

The people have had enough. They no longer believe the Government. They will not accept the Prime Minister's apologies. They will not accept the Treasurer's apologies. They cannot rob the people of their savings and say, `We are sorry that we are doing this'. The people will no longer accept it. The people are saying that, if the Treasurer does not resign, the Government itself must go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a motion which has been moved by the Opposition and which criticises the Government on its handling of the economy. The motion attacks Government policy and calls for policy changes. I might say that certainly there were tight economic policies in 1988 and 1989. There were very tight monetary policies occasioned through the sale of securities, leading to increased interest rates and very tight fiscal policy when we moved away from that period of many years of Liberal Party Budget deficits to Budget surpluses where the Government was generating more revenue than it was spending.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The previous Opposition speaker was listened to very quietly. Could you give the same benefit to Senator Maguire?

—I was pointing out that fiscal policy also had tightened as we moved the Commonwealth finances away from a period of continued deficit under the Liberals to Budget surpluses for four financial years in a row.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we did not have economies policies tight as an end in themselves; rather, they were tight to improve Australia's economic performance, and particularly to close off a very rapid growth in imports-the spill over from too much spending and too little production into imported products. The interest rate weapon was basically the mechanism needed and put into operation to reduce the flow of imports so that we could fund imports from our trading partners by our export proceeds. We had to slow down economic growth to stop longer term growth in imported products which could not be funded by our export proceeds.

Despite the motion that has been moved today, there have been substantial policy changes taken by the Government over the past 12 months. This motion, it would seem, calls for changes in Government policy on the economy but, as Senator McMullan did, I might point out that since January last year there have been steady, sustained reductions in interest rates. My research shows that, in terms of official cash interest rates-the inter-bank rates-there have been five rounds of reductions since February last year. Twelve months ago the inter-bank interest rate was 18 per cent. At the end of 1990 it was not 18 per cent but 13 per cent. So there had been a 5 percentage point cut in that important economic indicator.

That reduction helped to bring down the value of the Australian dollar compared with the currencies of our trading partners. Last year the Australian dollar had been trading at about US82c. That had the impact of making imports cheaper for this country. It had the effect of making our exports more expensive and less competitive. As a result of that movement down in interest rates and also the direct intervention of the Australian Government, through the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), they were able to talk down the Australian dollar from within the US80c range to within the mid-US70c range. That certainly has helped the competitive position of a number of Australian businesses involved in the production of traded goods.

Since then we have had the introduction of a new round of wages policies known, in shorthand, as accord mark 6. That came into effect on 1 January. There were significant personal income tax reductions through that accord. The strategy of the Government has been to keep down the growth of wages costs for employers by granting increases in disposable income through increased take home pay-after tax pay. That has been a more effective way of remunerating Australian employees than having trade unions and other organisations demand large gross wage rises and those costs being past onto employers. The mechanism used here has been to reduce the wages pressure on businesses by the Government topping up wages through the agency of personal income tax cuts.

Very briefly I shall turn to some of the current economic indicators because they really expose the shallowness of this motion this afternoon, this motion that is calling for changes in policy and so forth. The reality is that in the past six months for which we have balance of payments figures-that is, the last six months of 1990-compared to the same period in 1989, the deficit on the balance of payments current account has fallen from $11.9 billion in 1989 to $8.6 billion. That is a significant improvement: a 28 per cent reduction in the current account deficit in that six-month period in 1990. Basically, that is the reason that the community has been making the sacrifices it has. That has been the reason that we have had high interest rates, that we have had a very tight fiscal policy-in order to get down the deficit on the current account in the balance of payments. I point out for Opposition members that the $8.6 billion deficit in the first half of the 1990-91 calendar year is very much on target when one looks at the Budget forecast of a deficit of $8 billion for this financial year. The figure that we have already is very well within the Budget forecast.

I am pleased to say that trade surpluses, that is, surpluses on merchandise trade, are now starting to emerge in the current account. Interest rates on securities are offered by banks with which they raise funds for further lending. For example, at the beginning of last year the interest rate on 90-day bank bills was 18.5 per cent; at the end of the year it had fallen to 12.4 per cent-a reduction of over 6 percentage points in that important interest rate. We have also had a sustained reduction in the rate of inflation. We certainly cannot use the methodology that Senator Walters used this afternoon. It used to be the province of Sir Billy Snedden and Sir Phillip Lynch, whose analysis for the economy was very much in terms of taking one quarter's consumer price index and multiplying it by four. I think that is how Senator Walters got her claim today of the 10.8 per cent inflation rate in this country. That particular process is not legitimate and was exposed as such many years ago. I think that is how Senator Walters got that figure; I cannot work it out otherwise.

It is important to note that while this motion calls for changes in economic policies, monetary policy was relaxed significantly during 1990, fiscal policy has been relaxed significantly, and there has been a new wages policy and a new tax policy given effect through the sixth version of the Accord. So there have been very profound changes in the policy settings of the macro-economic variables already. I think the important thing to bear in mind is that most of these variables have long lead times following them.

We cannot say on a particular day that we will change an economic variable and therefore tomorrow the effect will be felt in the Australian economy. It does not work like that. We are facing very long lead times and we always have. For a number of economic variables, such as interest rates, the effect of a reduction may not be felt in the real level of production or investment for many months after the actual change has occurred. The Government is saying that it has put into place a number of policy changes already and basically we are now in the interval in which those policies begin to work.

We simply cannot say that because a policy was changed very recently the effect will be felt immediately. It will not and it is very important for the Opposition to be patient and not to call for immediate indications that policies are changing when some of the parameters have been altered only very recently.

As well as the policy changes I have outlined, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) will be making a statement on 12 March to Parliament and it will be a major statement looking at a number of major economic policy measures. In May the Government will be awarding a $12 wage rise to Australian employees under the Accord. While the Opposition has moved this motion today, talking about hardship, it opposes this particular wage rise. Certainly, I would be interested to find out whether that is the position today, but my understanding is that when that package of tax cuts and wages was announced late last year the Opposition was opposed to the $12 wage rise. So let us get that on the record if it is the case.

I have pointed to some very fundamental improvements that have been put in place in terms of the policy settings for the Australian economy. Some very positive trends are now occurring in the economy, but we have to ensure that we do not listen to those people who are trying to talk the economy down and there are plenty of those. We certainly must not listen to the doom and gloom merchants opposite and in the community.

I refer to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser on 6 November last with the headline-this is an interesting headline because we can actually catch people out when they make categorical comments- `Business tips 10 per cent jobless by Christmas'. The South Australian Employers Federation was quoted explicitly as saying that there would be a 10 per cent unemployment rate before Christmas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't say which year, did it?

—No, it did not. I read the newspaper and I assumed it was talking about 1990. Of course, I researched the figures. I had a look at the unemployment figures and I could not find any double digit figures. I found some in 1982 and 1983, when Mr Fraser was the Prime Minister, but I could not find any double digit unemployment figures in Australia before Christmas last year. All of those figures are on the public record now.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the Liberals. What would they do? They have moved this motion today calling on us to change policy settings. What would the Liberals do if they ever got into power? Its track record shows that in 1982 it throttled the economy. It strangled the economy, it drove it into the ground and we saw double digit inflation and double digit unemployment. That is the great double that the Liberals bequeathed to the Australian people.

I suppose we could look at how the Liberal Party policies would work in effect by looking at the performance of the Tories in the United Kingdom. After all, the Liberals have worshipped on the knees Mrs Thatcher and her acolytes in the form of Mr Major. If we want to see what Liberal policies would be in practice, all we have to do is look at the United Kingdom and its record of 9.9 per cent inflation. The Australian inflation rate is nowhere near 9.9 per cent. It has a massive balance of payments problem, a massive current account problem and soaring interest rates. During last year interest rates in the United Kingdom doubled. In Australia, interest rates last year came down by five or six percentage points. They did not double as they did in the United Kingdom.

We have Dr Hewson saying that he is going to solve Australia's economic problems by cutting government spending. Then we find that the Liberals are a bunch of hypocrites, they are all totally inconsistent. We bring in legislation to tighten up the assets test on family allowances and they vote against it. There is a classic case of where we were trying to cut Government spending and they all voted against it. Then we said we would look at ways and means of disposing of the gas pipeline from Moomba in South Australia to Sydney. It was a good way of boosting the funds available to the Government and these people voted against it.

The biggest one of the lot is the consumption tax. These are the people who are going to, as they say, restore the fortunes of the Australian economy by bringing in a consumption tax. They are dressing up self-interest as an economic virtue. That is what it is all about-big tax cuts for the wealthy, no doubt. Let us have a look at it. They say we have got to have a consumption tax because it will help fix the current account deficit. The United Kingdom has got both. It has got the great double-a broad-based consumption tax and a massive balance of payments deficit. There we are-these silly ideas that the Liberal Party puts around, these panaceas about fixing the economy in one fell swoop.

Let us have a look at the consumption tax because it is evident that a consumption tax would have definite effects. It would make some products more expensive and cheapen others. That is the reality. That is what would happen if the Liberals ever got into power. At the present time, luxury cars, for example, are taxed at a 50 per cent sales tax rate in this country. Under the Liberal Party's consumption tax, by abolishing that tax, and Dr Hewson made it quite clear at the Sydney motor show in November that he would abolish that luxury car tax, luxury limousines would be taxed at 15 to 18 per cent. That is the reality, so luxury cars would come down in price under these people.

My calculations show that a vehicle currently retailing for $97,000 would be reduced in price by a massive $20,000 to $77,000 under these people. These are the people who want a Rolls-Royce led recovery in Australia. These are the limousine Liberals who are totally out of touch with the ordinary people of this country. They want to put up the price of bread, fruit and vegetables, meat, clothing, children's shoes and they want to make luxury cars, diamonds, jewellery, furs, cosmetics, gold watches and other luxury goods cheaper in this country. That is what they are up to. That is how they claim they will solve the economy's problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that it is not my intention to vote for the motion. I say that a little bit diffidently because Senator Short and some of his colleagues have certainly raised issues which are very crucial to the future of Australia and are giving a great deal of concern. I, myself, being a representative of Tasmania in this place, have frequently found that my constituents are regularly expressing concern about the fall in standards of living; that it is harder now to make ends meet. Many families need two and sometimes three incomes to just make ends meet-paying off the mortgage and other things. I have available now a whole range of statistics which indicate that the ordinary family is far worse off now than for many years. That is the area that we have to look at.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not able to support the motion, although I agree that it was important that it was brought on. The motion says:
The need for the Government to take measures to correct the consequences of its disastrous policy miscalculations and mismanagement . . .

It is unfortunate but one cannot buy a pig in a poke. I do not know what measures are implied in this particular motion and therefore, on that ground, unless they are spelt out in the motion, it is not my intention to support it although, as I say, I agree with its thrust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply-I think I have got two minutes just to sum up. I welcome the debate that has taken place, and particularly the support that we are going to get from the Australian Democrats. This debate has exposed quite dramatically the hypocrisy of the Government's statements over a lengthy period of time now in terms of the state of the economy and the management of the economy. We have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers-but those two in particular-continue to dissemble on the real state of the economy. It is about time that the Government came clean with the Australian public on the extent of the deterioration that has occurred in the economy and on the extent of the deterioration in the budgetary position, which is a quite dramatic deterioration and which is going to lead this year to a call by the Government and the public sector on the savings of this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a desperately serious situation. We are hearing, as we have heard, that things will get all right. It is a bit like the call that things are going to turn up. They have been going to turn up for year after year. It has been going on and on. The Government is placing a great deal of stress on the industry statement on 12 March. We are also going to watch that industry statement very carefully indeed, because that is going to provide the last possible chance for this Government-and I believe it is too late for it-to show any form of economic credibility and integrity at all.

It is absolutely unbelievable that Government Ministers can come into this chamber today and say to the Australian people, `Be patient, all the pain and the suffering will pay off. It will all be revealed'. These people have been in Government for eight years. They have been ruining the country for eight years. They have been telling us for eight years that things are going to get better. We have, on this side of politics, the policies to restore growth and employment. If we see, in the industry statement on 12 March, policies which adopt a responsible approach to: fiscal management; tax reform; wages policy which enables employers and employees to negotiate freely and flexibly their terms and conditions of employment; a full-blooded and open process of privatisation of the Government business enterprises of this country; and tackling micro-economic reform in a meaningful way, we will believe it. But it is not going to happen.
