SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a series of answers given by Senator McMullan to questions by Senator Watson. I understand that the Whips have conferred on this. While this ought to have been done straight after Question Time, this is the next available opportunity for it to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (FOREIGN INCOME) BILL
RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS ON NOTICE PRESENTED BY SENATOR WATSON TO THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATIVE AFFAIRS ON 13 DECEMBER 1990
CLAUSE 9-PROPOSED SECTION 47a
Deemed dividends and foreign tax credits

Senator Watson has queried the denial of foreign tax credits or exemptions if deemed dividends are not disclosed in a tax return, even though the credits and exemptions will be allowed if the deemed dividends are disclosed.

It should first be noted that proposed section 47a is an anti-avoidance provision that treats certain non-arm's length transactions of a CFC as equivalent to the payment of dividends. The types of transactions are clearly spelt out in the legislation. Whether a particular transaction is on arm's length terms is determined objectively on the facts relating to the transaction, not by the reference to any discretionary power. Thus, at the time of making the return, the taxpayer will be aware of the circumstances relating to these transactions.

In cases where taxpayers are uncertain whether the section applies they have an opportunity, when lodging tax returns, to disclose transactions and seek a ruling from the Commissioner. Moreover, taxpayers have rights of objection and appeal against a decision to treat a transaction as a dividend.

Where the payment by a CFC of a deemed dividend is not disclosed by the taxpayer, subsequent actual dividends paid may be taken to have qualified for exemptions and credits for which they would not qualify had the deemed dividend been taken into account. If the deemed dividend is discovered on audit-perhaps a number of years after the event-it would be difficult to recalculate previous assessments to match the relevant dividends with the appropriate credits. Given the anti-avoidance nature of the provision, the Government considers that the denial of exemptions and credits for deemed dividends that are not disclosed is, in general, appropriate.

However, to cover the rare cases where taxpayers need more time to establish the facts, the Government recognises that it is appropriate to allow a reasonable period after the lodgment of a tax return for disclosure of the receipt of a deemed dividend. An amendment contained in the Taxation Laws Amendment (No. 6) Bill 1990 will allow foreign tax credits and exemptions provided the recipient of the deemed dividend discloses its receipt within one year of the end of the relevant year of income.
Calculation of the profits of a CFC out of which deemed dividends could be paid

Senator Watson has requested clarification on the manner in which ``profits'' must be calculated in applying proposed section 47a. I have assumed that the reference in the Senator's question to the subsection 47a (10) was intended to be a reference to proposed subsection 47a (15).

Proposed subsection 47a (15) provides that, in determining whether a company has profits at a particular time, it is to be assumed that the accounts of the company have been drawn up immediately before that time.

Where the CFC has in fact drawn up accounts up to the time the disguised distribution was made, the relevant profits will be the profits as disclosed by the accounts. This is, of course, based on the assumption that the accounts have been drawn up on commercially accepted principles of accounting.

Where the CFC has no accumulated profits from previous years, or exhausts those profits, it will be necessary to determine whether a profit exists at the time the benefit under consideration is provided. Where accounts were not made up at this time, it is intended that the CFC would compute its profits at that time. It is expected that the CFC will be generally aware of the level of profits and, unless the benefit provided amounted to a substantial portion of those profits, there will be no difficulty in determining that the amount is out of profits.
However, if it is not clear that the amount of the benefit is out of profits, such accounts will need to be drawn up.
As I have already mentioned, this result is entirely preventable if the CFC does not disguise distributions of profits.
Potential for double taxation under proposed section 47a

Senator Watson has raised several issues regarding the potential for double taxation under proposed section 47a. Before dealing with these issues in detail, I would like to make some general comments. I have said elsewhere that one of the purposes of this legislation is to prevent avoidance of tax through the use of tax havens and that another is to ensure that income is not taxed twice. The second of these objectives has led to increased complexity of the legislation- for example, the attribution account system and the various adjustments for the capital gain provisions.

However, the Government has not dealt with issues of double taxation that arise from section 47a. This is the intended deterrent effect of the section which is essentially an anti-avoidance provision. I stress that any double taxation that may arise consequent to the application of section 47a can be avoided by ensuring that the CFC does not make disguised distributions to its shareholders.
Having said this, the double taxation is not as widespread as is made out. I will now deal with the specific issues raised by Senator Watson.
Potential for double taxation where actual dividend is paid after deemed dividends
Senator Watson has raised the possibility of double taxation where a deemed dividend is taken to have been paid by a company and an actual dividend is paid subsequently by that company.

Where a CFC has distributed a part of its profits as a disguised dividend and the amount has been deemed to be a dividend, that amount would not normally again be distributed. It is gone. If a dividend were subsequently paid, it would generally, in fact, be a distribution of other profits and rightly taxed.
Although double taxation could occur in certain circumstances, this result could be avoided by ensuring that the CFC does not make disguised distributions.
Possibility of double taxation by inclusion of deemed dividend and attribution of company profits

Senator Watson states that double taxation could arise in cases where a deemed dividend paid by the CFC is included in the assessable income of taxpayer and the CFC's income (including the profit out of which the deemed dividend is paid) is also attributed to the taxpayer.

Where a CFC resident in an unlisted country derives a profit, the profit may be attributed to the Australian residents with an interest in the CFC. If the CFC makes those profits available to the Australian residents otherwise than by the payment of a dividend the amount may be deemed to be a dividend. If the profits that would otherwise be attributed are distributed in that same year, the attributable income will be reduced by the amount of the deemed dividend. If instead the deemed dividend occurs after the year for which attribution occurs, the dividend will be exempt to the extent of that previous attribution. Therefore, double taxation will not arise in this case.
Possibility of double taxation for ``down-stream'' dividends
The Senator has also suggested double taxation could arise in relation to down-stream deemed dividends where the recipient pays a dividend back to its parent.

Double taxation would not usually arise in such cases. Where a parent company resident in an unlisted country provides a benefit to its subsidiary resident in a listed country, the amount may be deemed to be a dividend. That amount may then be attributed to the residents of Australia with an interest in the listed country CFC receiving the deemed dividend. If the CFC in the listed country were then to pay the amount back to its parent as a genuine dividend, the amount would be exempt being a non-portfolio dividend received from a company resident in a listed country. Further, if the dividend flowed through to the Australian corporate shareholders, the amount would be exempt. Therefore, no double taxation would arise in such cases.

However, double taxation could arise in some rare cases-for example, if the dividend eventually flowed through to a resident individual who is a shareholder in a foreign company-double taxation may arise. As previously stated, this result can be avoided by ensuring that the CFC does not attempt to disguise distributions of profits.
The definition of ``distribution payment''
Senator Watson has sought clarification for certain drafting issues in relation to the definition of the term ``distribution payment''.

The term ``distribution payment'' does not require separate definition as it is specifically referred to in each of the subsections that deals with a particular category of benefits provided by one entity to another.
CLAUSE 18-PROPOSED TRANSFEROR TRUST MEASURES
Section 102aab-Discretionary trust estates

Proposed paragraph (c) of the definition of a ``discretionary trust estate'' treats a trust as a discretionary trust estate where one of the beneficiaries is itself a discretionary trust estate. The Senator has stated that Australian residents who are direct beneficiaries in a non-discretionary trust may be unaware of the beneficial interest held by a discretionary trust and would therefore be unable to comply with the transferor tax measures.

The Government does not accept Senator Watson's proposition. The inclusion of paragraph (c) is a necessary anti-avoidance mechanism. It will prevent the foreign source income measures being avoided by interposing a non-discretionary trust estate between the taxpayer and the discretionary trust.

Beneficiaries of a private non-discretionary trust who were also transferors in respect of that trust could be expected to know who the other beneficiaries are-usually family members or entities controlled by them. Moreover, transfers at market value to purchase units in, for example, a public unit trust will be exempted from the transferor tax measures. Hence, the average investor in units of a public unit trust would be outside the scope of the transferor tax measures.
In this context, the Government considers it preferable to retain the definition of a discretionary trust as presently provided in the Bill.
Proposed section 102aag-Control rule for a trust estate includes associates

Proposed section 102aag sets out the circumstances in which an entity is to be taken to control a trust estate. For this purpose, control of the trust estate by an associate of the entity is treated as control by the entity. Senator Watson has submitted that a taxpayer should not be deemed to control an associate except where the taxpayer actually controls that associate.

However, the approach of treating a person and a person's associates as one is an essential anti-avoidance measure. The approach taken in the Bill is an established approach in the Income Tax Assessment Act and the form of the definition of associates is broadly equivalent to that already in the Act-for example, in the thin capitalisation rules and the capital gains provisions.
Proposed section 102aan-Winding up of non-resident trust estates - tax rebates

Senator Watson proposes that the law should be amended to provide that the anti-avoidance provisions of Part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act would not apply where a taxpayer winds up a non-resident trust to obtain the concessional rate of tax of 10 per cent.
The same matter that the Senator raises in this question was dealt with in the Committee in response to a question from Senator Spindler and I refer him to the comments made there.
Proposed section 102aazg-Record keeping for trust transferors

Senator Watson suggests that, notwithstanding the intention expressed in the explanatory memorandum, taxpayers who are in partnership may destroy records after five years, whereas individuals or corporations may not (except to the extent that they are in partnership with other persons).

Proposed section 102aazg specifically provides that a person who is an attributable taxpayer in relation to a particular trust estate must keep records containing particulars of and the basis of calculation of the amounts included in the assessable income of person under proposed section 102aazd in relation to that trust estate. Such a person may not otherwise have been required to keep records.

While subsection 262a (1) to (3) require only a person who is carrying on a business to keep records, subsections (4) and (5) of that section have a general application and apply to a person who has possession of any records kept or obtained under or for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Those subsections will therefore apply for the purposes of proposed section 102aazg.
It is necessary to specifically apply subsections 262a (4) and (5) to partnerships because, other than for the purposes of the accruals tax measures, a partnership is not a person.
Subsection 102aazg extends the record keeping requirements to a partnership as if the partnership were a person.

Consequently, there is a requirement for a person subject to the provisions of 102aazd to keep records for five years, which is entirely consistent with the existing requirements of the Assessment Act.

The Senator also noted that proposed subsection 102aazg (4) sets out the circumstances in which there is no obligation to keep records. He suggests that that subsection is deficient in that a taxpayer is not relieved of the obligation to keep records where information is lost, destroyed or not kept et cetera, through no fault of the taxpayer.

The statutory defences provided in 102aazg are quite broad. They will enable a record keeper who has made reasonable effort to comply to avoid prosecution. The statutory defences proposed by the Senator would enable those who had not acted reasonably in relation to their record keeping obligations to hide behind the actions of others, who will often be associates of the record keeper. Accordingly, the Government does not accept the Senator's proposal.
CLAUSE 49-CFC MEASURES
Proposed section 317-Designated Concession Income
Senator Watson states that it ``remains to be seen what will be made'' of the following words in draft regulation CCC:
``Form of tax benefit''; and
``Particular tax concession''.
The matters raised by the Senator will be taken into account in the preparation of the final regulations.
Proposed section 324-``subject to tax''
Senator Watson has raised the matter of carry forward losses in relation to the ``subject to tax'' test.

Carry forward losses may be taken into account in determining whether income or profits are subject to tax. Thus, the subject to tax test may be satisfied notwithstanding that prior years' losses, and normal expenses incurred in gaining income or profits, have the effect that no tax is required to be paid in a particular accounting period.

It should be noted that the requirement that ``foreign tax is payable'', as comprehended by proposed section 324, is not to be read as a requirement that ``foreign tax must be actually paid''. This matter is discussed in the explanatory memorandum.
In view of the foregoing, it is not necessary to prescribe regulations to cater for carry forward losses.
Proposed section 433-Tainted Income Ratio

Senator Watson has suggested that the denominator of the tainted income ratio for listed country CFCs be altered to read ``gross income''- that is, the same denominator as for the tainted income ratio applying to CFCs resident in unlisted countries.

In relation to a listed country, certain income or profits are potentially subject to attribution only if they are eligible designated concession income and the CFC fails the active income test. Thus, each of the tainted income ratios is consistent in that the tainted component, which is potentially subject to attribution, is compared with the gross component to which the tainted component relates.

Furthermore, the law provides an exemption where the CFC is a resident of a listed country and the total amount of eligible designated concession income and income or profits from sources outside the listed country which are not subject to tax in a listed country does not exceed the lesser of $50,000 or five per cent of the gross income.
Proposed section 319-Statutory account period of a company-adoption of a substituted period
Senator Watson suggests that it is appropriate to allow a company to adopt another accounting period other than that period in which it must report to shareholders.

The intent of proposed section 319 is to ensure that foreign companies have a 12 month accounting period for accruals purposes. Given that some CFCs do not have accounting periods or regular reporting periods it was reasonable to statutorily impose a 1 July to 30 June accounting period unless a foreign company regularly used another period. Subsection (3) enables a foreign company to elect an accounting period other than one ending 30 June if certain criteria are met. These criteria restrict adoption of a particular statutory accounting period to the accounting requirements of the company. To allow for the adoption of any accounting period for any, or no particular, reason would encourage tax deferral in certain circumstances.
Proposed section 322-Meaning of ``entitled to acquire''
Senator Watson has suggested that the meaning of ``entitled to acquire'' be modified. This matter is currently under consideration by the Government.
Proposed section 340-Whether the control test should be more than 50% or 50% or more
The Senator has suggested that the threshold test for control purposes be altered to read ``more than 50%'' in lieu of ``not less than 50%''.

The Government has adopted this approach in order to subject joint venturers to the control rule-that is, two parties not necessarily residents of the same country with equal interests in a non-resident company. Given the avoidance possibilities, and consistent with the de facto control test, the Government is of the view that it is appropriate to define control in terms of holding an interest of 50% or more in a non-resident company.
New Zealand has also adopted this approach.
Proposed section 384-Additional assumptions for unlisted country CFC
Senator Watson has suggested that there is a need for clarification of the continued operation of Division 13 and sections 384.

As background, the attributable income of a CFC is calculated as the amount that would have been the taxable income on the assumption, amongst other things, that the CFC were a resident of Australia. In calculating this notional taxable income Division 13 of the Act, the general anti-avoidance provision that prevents the shifting of profits by transfer pricing, may be applied. It is further assumed that the attributable income is calculated on the basis that the CFC had only certain ``income or other amounts''-broadly, tainted income and certain trust income.

Senator Watson has raised two drafting matters. First, he submitted that a notional amount calculated under Division 13 cannot be said to fall within the expression ``income or other amounts'', although it is recognised that this is the intention of the legislation as evidenced by the explanatory memorandum. This matter was raised in the course of preparing the legislation and it is my advice that the legislation operates as intended. Secondly, the Senator submits that a notional amount cannot be categorised as tainted income, since this definition is phrased in terms of actual amounts and not notional amounts. Again, my advice is that, given the purpose of the section, this is incorrect.

The Senator further submits, as a matter of policy, that the application of Division 13 is not warranted in certain circumstances. Specifically, it is suggested that application of Division 13 be modified for the calculation of the attributable income to ensure that it applies only to non-arm's length loans made after the commencement of the CFC measures. The rationale for the suggested grandfathering is that the arrangements could not have been entered for the purpose of avoiding Australian tax and that CFCs cannot readily rearrange the loans to prevent the application of Division 13.

The difficulty of CFCs rearranging their inter-company loans to ensure that the operation of Division 13 is not triggered appears to be overstated. Discussions with practitioners as a result of inquiries directed to the Tax Office indicate that significant restructuring of inter-company loans is now occurring. Further, the reasoning advanced could equally be applied to every investment or activity undertaken, or to any structure set-up, prior to the commencement of the CFC measures, unless there was a clear indication of a tax avoidance motive. Provision of grandfathering on this basis alone would lead to a significant weakening of the measures and would allow taxpayers currently engaged in minimisation of tax through CFCs to continue to do so indefinitely. Therefore, any provision of grandfathering in this context would require evidence of real inequity rather than difficulty or inconvenience.
However, the general operation of Division 13 in the calculation of attributable income will be subject to an on-going review to ensure that it will not operate in inappropriate circumstances.

The attributable income of a CFC resident in an unlisted country is to be calculated under the further assumption that the only income or other amounts derived by the CFC are those amounts that fall within certain categories-that is, tainted income, trust income and certain partnership income. The Senator seems to be suggesting that an amount may fall within more than one category. This is correct. However, the conclusion that double counting can therefore occur is not accepted. The assumption is structured so that the quantification of the amount is separate from the identification of the amounts that may be taken into account. Therefore, although an amount may fall within more than one category, it results in only one amount being included in the calculation of the attributable income.
Proposed section 385-Additional assumptions for calculating the attributable income of a CFC in a listed country

The issues raised by Senator Watson in respect of the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC resident in a listed country are predominantly the same as those raised for the calculation for a CFC resident in an unlisted country and the same comments apply. The only additional issue raised is that section 385 should have certain words inserted. This was a matter that arose after the release of the draft Bill in June and was addressed prior to the introduction of the Bill into the Parliament.
Proposed section 387-Reduction of attributable income because of interim dividends

Senator Watson has raised certain issues in relation to the operation of this section. By way of background, a CFC may pay a dividend out of its current year's profits. Where this occurs, in the absence of any relief, the dividend may be taxed as well as the underlying profits from which it is paid being included in attributable income. This double taxation is prevented by the reduction of the attributable income of a CFC by the amount of a dividend that can reasonably be said to relate to the profits that would otherwise be included in attributable income. Senator Watson suggests that the operation of the provision should be clarified.

First, Senator Watson submits that, where a dividend is paid part way through the year of income, it is not clear whether an amount can be said to relate to attributable income derived after that date, or whether the dividend must relate to an amount already derived by the CFC. Problems only arise if the former view is taken. My advice is that, in this context, an amount can reasonably be said to relate to attributable income whether or not the attributable income has yet be derived.

It should be noted that the reduction will be taken to relate to amounts derived in the current year only where all previous years' profits have been distributed-that is, profits are taken to have been distributed yearly on a first-in-first-out basis. This is clearly stated in the Explanatory Memorandum. The Government does not agree with Senator Watson's suggestion that the taxpayer will have difficulty in determining whether or not all of the previous year's profits of the CFC have been distributed.
Consequently, the Government sees no reason for further legislative clarification of the provision at this stage.
Proposed section 388-Interaction with double tax agreements
Senator Watson has suggested that proposed section 388 effectively nullifies parts of Australia's international agreements.

This is neither the Government's intention, nor is it the effect of section 388, to override any provision of any international agreement. Section 388 is only relevant for the purposes of calculating the attributable income of a CFC for the purposes of proposed division 7 of Part X of the Act. This is not a matter to which the double tax treaties apply.
Proposed section 394-Eligible finance share dividends

Senator Watson has provided suggestions in relation to the scope and operation of this section. His comments will be taken into account in the context of the review of this section, announced in the Treasurer's Press Release of 29 June 1990.
Proposed section 398-Modified application of depreciation provisions
Senator Watson has raised certain issues in relation to the modifications made to the depreciation provisions as they apply for the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC.

Under the depreciation provisions of the Act, depreciation of plant and equipment used in the production of assessable income is allowed as a deduction. Where the amount allowed as a deduction is later recouped by the taxpayer on the sale of the plant or equipment, the amount recouped is included in the taxpayer's assessable income. In the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC, the Commissioner is given a discretion to, amongst other things, determine the recouped amount to be included in attributable income.

Senator Watson suggests that the Commissioner's discretion is unfettered and could result in a recoupment greater than the amount actually claimed as a deduction. Accordingly, it is suggested that the discretion should be modified to ensure that the recouped amount is limited to the amount that has been allowed as a deduction or used in the calculation of a carry forward loss.

It is my advice that the provision could not reasonably be applied in this manner. The Commissioner's discretion is not unfettered as he is under a duty to apply the law in accordance with its clear purpose.

The operation of the depreciation provision was reviewed, in accordance with the undertaking of the Treasurer in the press release of 29 June 1990 and it was decided no amendment was warranted at this stage. However, it is expected that the matter will be reviewed in the context of the self assessment review of Commissioner's discretions that has been announced by the Treasurer.
Proposed section 421-Elections under CGT roll-over provisions
Senator Watson has raised issues concerning the time period for elections under the roll-over provisions of Part IIIA of the Act.

By way of background, under Part IIIA (Capital Gains and Losses) of the Act, certain asset disposals are ignored in determining the gain or loss that arises during a taxpayer's year of income. In general, the gain or loss is effectively deferred until the later disposal of the replacement asset by the taxpayer, or until the later disposal of the asset by another taxpayer. These provisions, commonly called roll-over provisions, are also applicable in the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC. As is the case under the Part IIIA, the roll-over provision may operate either automatically or at the election of the taxpayer or the taxpayers involved. Where Part IIIA requires that one or more taxpayers elect that a roll-over provision should apply, the election is modified for the purpose of calculating the attributable income of a CFC. In such cases, the election must be made by the CFC within two months of the end of the CFC's statutory accounting period, or within such time as the Commissioner allows.

Senator Watson submits that, notwithstanding the Commissioner's discretion to extend the basic two month period, a longer basic period should be provided. He supports this view by reference to the existing period which allows time until the lodgment of the taxpayer's return of income.

However, the normal operation of Part IIIA is not directly analogous. Under Part IIIA, the period to the lodgment of the taxpayer's return is allowed because it is convenient for the taxpayer and the ATO, and not because it is considered the minimum sufficient time. This is not possible for the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC since there may be several attributable taxpayers involved, each of which may have a different income year. Since the election to apply the roll-over provision must be common for all of these attributable taxpayers, a single date must be fixed.

Two months from the end of the statutory accounting period of the CFC is considered a reasonable time period as it is anticipated that, in the majority of disposals for which roll-over relief will be available, taxpayers will be aware of the implications of asset disposals through CFC's for which roll-over relief is to be available and would have taken the tax consequences into consideration before the disposal is made. However, it is recognised that certain roll-overs will be available for unanticipated or uncontrollable disposals. Further, circumstances which cannot be foreseen may require a longer period. Consequently, the Commissioner is to be given the power to extend the period if such extension is reasonable in the circumstances. If, in practice, it becomes apparent that the initial period is not sufficient in the majority of cases, an amendment to extend the period will be considered.
Proposed section 432-Active income test-company in the first year of operation
Senator Watson submits that a company in the first year of operation may not pass the active income test and that this has unfair consequences.

Where a company fails the active income test, generally only its tainted income is included in the attributable income on which resident taxpayers may be called upon to pay Australian tax. In most cases, the tainted income would be interest income from the deposit of surplus funds pending utilisation of those funds for active business operations. The Government sees no justification for the provision of a different tax treatment for this income compared with tainted income derived by an established company.
Proposed section 432 (read with sections 332 and 333)-Active income test-different countries of incorporation and activity
Senator Watson submits that it is unfair that a company cannot satisfy the active income test because it is incorporated in one country but carries on business in another country.

The Government does not agree with Senator Watson's assertion that the provision is ``unfair''. It is a deliberate anti-avoidance policy feature of the active income test that a ``letterbox'' company incorporated in one country but not carrying on business in that country cannot obtain the benefit of the active income test.

However, it should be remembered that failing the active income test will generally only cause the CFC's tainted income to be attributed to those residents who hold the requisite interests in the CFC.
Section 432-Active income test-qualified accounts
A CFC generally will not pass the active income test if its accounts are qualified by the auditors for any reason.

A necessary anti-avoidance requirement is that the company's accounts give a true and fair view of its financial position and profits. It is not proposed to provide any exception for qualified accounts.
Proposed section 438-Active income test-Roll-overs-asset disposals
Senator Watson points out that the roll-over provisions for the active income test and the calculation of attributable income are not analogous.

As background, in determining whether or not a CFC has passed the active income test, roll-over relief is also to be taken into account so that certain asset disposals are ignored. The roll-over relief is intended to be analogous to that provided for the calculation of the attributable income of a CFC.

The Senator's observations are correct in that the roll-overs are not analogous. However, it is anticipated that the majority of disposals for which roll-over relief will be necessary will be for transfers between wholly owned group companies. This relief has been provided. Amendment to the extend roll-over relief for other disposals on the same basis as for the calculation of attributable income will be considered before the first calculation of attributable income is required. Since these roll-over provisions are largely for disposals which are beyond the control of the taxpayer, it is anticipated that taxpayers' actions will not be restricted by the absence of the provisions at this stage.
Section 447-Tainted sales income-goods substantially altered by agents or subcontractors should be excluded

Senator Watson submits that where goods are substantially altered by a subcontractor or agent, for or on behalf of a CFC, then income from the sale of such goods should be excluded from the tainted sales income of the CFC.

The exemption provided in section 447 for a CFC that carries on a manufacturing operation is meant to apply to a CFC that itself engages in manufacture. This represents genuine business operations of the CFC. It is not meant to cover agency or subcontracting arrangements.
Section 459-Assessability in respect of certain dividends deemed to be paid by a CFC under section 47a (of the Principal Act)
In brief it is asserted that where a deemed dividend is included in a taxpayer's assessable income under proposed section 459 no relief mechanism is provided in the Bill.

Proposed section 47a is an anti-avoidance provision, designed to deal with taxpayers who enter into transactions that would enable an unlisted country CFC to make its profits available for the use of associated Australian or listed country companies without distributing the profits as dividends. Section 47a will deem these transactions as the payment of dividends.

Proposed section 459 deals with deemed dividends other than those paid to shareholders. Accordingly, in view of the abnormal nature of these payments, credit and exemptions are not available for these dividends.
Division 11-Keeping of records
Senator Watson suggests that the record keeping requirement be tightened to require records to be kept in Australia in order to facilitate tax administration.

This requirement would cause an additional and significant compliance burden on some taxpayers and, given the existing information gathering powers of the Commissioner the proposed section 264a, the Government does not consider that such action is warranted.
Clause 60 and 65-Transitional Regulations and Tax Administration Act

Before discussing the technical matters that were raised under these clauses, I would like to respond to the comments concerning the relationship between the Australian Taxation Office and the Attorney-General's Department. The Australian taxation office has asked me to assure Senator Watson and other members of the Committee that it has a good working relationship with the Attorney General's Department. Also, the departmental officers actually involved in the drafting of the foreign income regulations have asked me to convey to the Committee that there is absolutely no foundation in the rumour that the relationship between them is ``not all that it should be''. The drafting of the regulations is being given priority by the Office of Legislative Drafting and, given the complexity of the task, I am satisfied with its progress.
The comments made in respect of the construction of the regulations have been noted. They will be taken into consideration in the preparation of the final regulations.

I would like to take this opportunity to make some general comments on the regulations. The retrospective operation of the regulations is required from the start of the 1990/91 income year to accord tax exempt treatment for non-portfolio dividends and overseas branch profits derived by Australian companies from listed countries. In view of the fact that the proposed tax exemption also applies to substituted accounting periods for the 1990/91 year of income, it is necessary for the regulations to specify the listed countries as from 1 July 1989-that is, for early balancing companies.

Also, with regard to provisions which enable controlled foreign companies to deduct prior year losses in calculating their attributable income, the regulations need to be able to apply to losses incurred as early as 1 July 1983. Of course, this early commencement favours the taxpayer.

However, while the retrospective operation of the regulations will give taxpayers access to various concessional measures from the earliest date, it is also necessary that transitional anti-avoidance provisions operate effectively from the same time.

Extensive public consultation on the draft Bill alerted taxpayers to the listed country exemptions. In the absence of effective anti-avoidance provisions it would be quite easy, prior to the start of the 1990/91 income year, for taxpayers to transfer accumulated income from tax havens to companies in listed countries. The income could then be distributed to Australian corporate shareholders free of Australian company tax.

If the regulations did not have retrospective effect, there would be no listed countries until the regulations come into operation. Further, as only income from listed countries benefits from the exemptions provided, taxpayers would be disadvantaged if the operation of the package of the regulations and transitional anti-avoidance measures was prospective only.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (NO. 4) BILL
RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS ON NOTICE PRESENTED BY SENATOR WATSON DURING DEBATE ON THE SECOND READING ON 19 DECEMBER 1990
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (NO. 4) BILL 1990
COMMITTEE STAGES
Question 1
I refer to section 9, Page 3 which has the closest relevance to my question.
Credits in vostro accounts, i.e. amounts owed by Australian financial institutions to an offshore institution are not dealt with in the legislation.

Current practice is not to pay interest on vostro balances in credit, so they are not included in foreign debt. However, the practice could change such that interest was payable, such credits would be included in foreign debt and there would be a risk that debt equity ratios could, in such circumstances, be breached.
Are there negotiations on this matter and has the Parliamentary Secretary any information for the Senate?
Question 2
I refer to section 13, page 6. Amendments to 159GLA(i) specifies a number of conditions which must be satisfied at all times during the year of income.
Sub-paragraph a(c) (ii).

There is to be no amount owing by the resident holding company. However, the press release NO. 24 of 30th March 1989 referring to the pre-conditions refers to interest bearing debt. `` . . . the holding company does not itself have any interest bearing debt to the foreign parent bank or foreign associations.''
A basic principle of their capitalisation is that it only applies to interest bearing debt.
Are there negotiations under way to overcome the problem in the Bill which is a departure from the earlier undertakings including the press release. If so, what information can the Senate be given?
Question 3
S159G2A

I refer to the practical effect of the Bill which will require a bank to monitor each and every transaction passing through a nostro or vostro account to ensure that it is cleared within the prescribed period.

1. Given the application of the 10 day rule, is not the legislative requirement so restrictive as to be commercially unrealistic in that substantial resources would be required to monitor the high volume of transactions and that delays are generally occasioned by independent third parties.
2. Will the Minister give consideration to industry's request for a 30 day period?
3. Does the offending transaction result in the concession being withdrawn from only that transaction?
4. Is the whole account tainted and if so for what period?
Question 4
I refer to clause 28 clarifying that an initial payment of tax, due 28 days after the end of a year of income is due and payable on the relevant day.

Given the problems with the economy and the difficulties some companies are facing in paying their tax obligation due on 17/12 how immutable is this 28/7 date for companies balancing on 30th June 1991 or 28 days after the end of the accounting period?

While there may be some philosophical support for bringing tax payment obligations of unincorporated and corporate taxpayers closer together. Does not the Minister agree that further, the transitional provisions appear in the circumstances to need some further examination, in the New Year.
Question 5
I refer to the amendment following 82K2A.
1. Does the amendment apply immediately on tax auditor investigations or does the Australian Taxation Office first have to signal a problem with the Taxpayer's substantiation?
2. Is a request or objection first necessary to activate the new 82K2AA?
3. Does the Government intend to take similar action in the fringe benefits tax where similar substantiation rules apply under section 24 and section 65e?
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (NO.4) 1990
COMMITTEE STAGES
QUESTIONS ASKED BY SENATOR WATSON
Question 1. Vostro accounts
Since the Bill was debated there have been negotiations with the financial industry on this matter.

The thin capitalisation definition of foreign debt in relation to a company has two main elements. Firstly, an amount is owing to a foreign controller or non-resident associate of the foreign controller and secondly interest is payable on this amount.

As you stated in your question, the current industry practice is not to pay interest on vostro account surplus balances. Therefore vostro account surplus balances do not satisfy the second element of foreign debt and are consequently beyond the scope of the thin capitalisation rules. For this reason it was unnecessary to provide an express exemption from the definition of foreign debt.

It should be noted that the amendments were drafted to reflect the industry practice. The overall objective being to enable taxpayers to comply with the thin capitalisation rules without undue disruption to their normal business activities. If however, industry practice changes and interest is paid on vostro accounts, the Government will review the matter.
Question 2. Resident holding companies

Proposed section 159GZLA only applies to a small number of banks and the industry association concerned was consulted. The Reserve Bank was also consulted to ensure the provision conformed with banking industry regulations. The Government has been advised of the concerns of certain banks with this provision and the issue is currently being reviewed.

This provision allows a resident holding company to owe interest free debt to a foreign controller or a non-resident associate of the foreign controller. However, this amount must be subtracted from its notional foreign equity in the resident bank. Therefore the provision in effect, excludes such interest free debt from the thin capitalisation controls.
Question 3. Nostro and Vostro Accounts
1 &2. In this age of electronic fund transfers, a 10 day clearance period would appear to be a sufficient time to clear such accounts.
Therefore we are not considering extending the clearance period to 30 days.

3 &4. An offending transaction will only result in the concession being withdrawn from that transaction. Clause 9 prescribes that nostro and vostro accounts must be maintained on the basis that deposits are cleared within 10 days and overdraft advances are repaid within 10 days. Moreover, the account must be operated for the sole purpose of settling international transactions. Provided these conditions are satisfied a nostro or vostro account will not be tainted by an inadvertent failure to clear a deposit or overdraft within 10 days.
Question 4. Company Self-Assessment

The Government is not proposing to alter the system for paying company tax. As previously stated in the Senate by the Minister representing the Treasurer, any company which has difficulty in meeting its tax obligations should contact the Australian Taxation Office so that consideration is given whether to extend the time for payment or to allow the company to pay by instalments.
Different companies may face different financial problems and the Taxation Office needs to consider each application for time to pay on a case by case basis.

The matter that I wish to refer to relates to the information given on pages 42 and 43 of the report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies regarding the Institute's assessments of the coalition's family tax package and the Australian Labor Party's policies to assist families. This report is incomplete in the sense that it does not indicate the extraordinary controversies which enveloped the Institute during the last election campaign. Honourable senators will recall that the Institute of Family Studies chose to involve itself in a very political manner during the election campaign.

For example, the day Mr Peacock delivered the Liberal Party's policy speech, the Institute chose to make a press release which criticised one of the key policies of the coalition-the family tax package. The Institute apparently waited four months to publish its attack on Mr Peacock and chose the day of the policy speech to get maximum coverage. More happy, however, was Mr Hawke. On the day he delivered a major statement to the press club, the Labor Party's policies were contrasted favourably with those of the coalition.
Let me make the obvious point that men and women of good faith can differ. The coalition released a very detailed rebuttal of the Institute's attack on the family tax package.

In the time I have available, I do not have the opportunity to outline the many criticisms made by Dr John Hewson and Mr Connolly about the Institute's attack on the coalition policies. But, to my knowledge, these criticisms have never been adequately answered by the Institute. We would certainly welcome a detailed response from the Institute now. This is important because the Institute of Family Studies' standing was certainly damaged by its behaviour during the election period.

Honourable senators may like to recall just one fact. The coalition was offering some $830m a year in child-care tax rebates compared with some $87m offered by the Labor Party. In other words, the coalition was offering some 10 times more support for child-care. Yet, it was the Labor Party child-care policy which received the endorsement of the Australian Institute of Family Studies. There are some important questions which must be answered. For example, should a publicly funded organisation involve itself so prominently in an election campaign? Do the directors of the Institute, on reflection, believe its performance was appropriate? Are we to expect a similar performance during the next election?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you just tell the truth?

—I am pleased to record that a number of people associated with the Institute have indicated to various coalition members their embarrassment about the Institute's performance during the election period. However, I would be very interested to hear the board's responses to the questions which I have just raised. In some areas, of course, I recognise there are different philosophical approaches and, as I have said, men and women of goodwill can differ.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition attacked the welfarist approach of the Institute. The Institute may well consider whether it does not need to adopt a broader philosophical perspective and to examine whether all major shades of opinion are adequately represented on its board and on its staff. In a press release of 5 March, Dr Hewson and Mr Connolly criticised Brian Howe's politicisation of the Australian Institute of Family Studies. Since the election, I am pleased to say that the Institute has adopted a more constructive approach. We hope that this is not just a hiccup in the Institute's performance. May I express the hope, in conclusion, that Senator Richardson will ensure that the Institute adopts, and is seen to adopt, a role independent of government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak very briefly on the annual report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies. While browsing through the report I had a look at pages 40 and 41. As I understand it, someone on an average income is earning about $25,000 a year or perhaps a little less. The Institute has looked at the cost of children in Australia, and it says:

SPEECH.PARA: This work is still being evaluated but one paper describing the structures of the costs of children was produced during the year, `Research on the costs of children: policy implications', by Peter McDonald.
According to the Lee study, the full cost of one child in a one income family with an income a little above average weekly earnings was as follows-
and it has been updated to 1989. The extraordinary situation is that it costs $10,810 a year to support and care for a child between the ages of 11 and 13.

How can the Government possibly say that living standards are adequate in the present situation when average income is $25,000 a year and it costs $10,810, nearly $11,000, to look after a teenage child? It makes one wonder how people with young children can possibly manage. How can a one-income family with three or four teenagers manage? Of course, that is quite impossible.

I think the Government should take note of the annual report. I hope that the Minister for Social Security, Senator Richardson, will read, mark, learn and inwardly digest those figures because he has to have a clear understanding of the poverty that is presently existing amongst children in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak very briefly to the report of the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS). I would like to begin by congratulating the Institute on celebrating its tenth anniversary in 1990 and for its excellent annual report which sets out a wide range of activities and projects undertaken by the Institute over the past 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: The Institute's research program continues to be of great value and is an ongoing source of significant, sophisticated and reliable information about the state and well-being of Australian families. The AIFS has also played an important role in encouraging public sector debate about family related issues and I can only assume that it is the Government's paranoia about any sort of vaguely controversial public debate that is one of the factors for the Institute continuing to be starved of funds. I quote from page 3 of the board's introduction to this annual report:

The Institute's budget base has not been increased in real terms over the past four years . . . The Board . . . is concerned that funding restrictions are unduly confining the work of the Institute . . . Important research has had to be delayed or not tackled at all. The Institute's computer system is barely capable of meeting existing work demands, thus . . . threatening future research output. Limits have been placed on a more active dissemination program for the Institute's findings . . .

I find it extraordinary that work as vital as the Institute's can continue to be jeopardised. One could say, I could perhaps cynically suggest, that it is because the Government does not particularly want to have its economic and social rhetoric muddied by the facts as they appear in these research findings. But any Government should surely have the maturity and wisdom to appreciate the value of the information provided by the Institute.

On this we need to be clear. This research is of crucial importance and anyone who has followed the Institute's work over the years will realise that it provides not only an invaluable source of basic information and statistics but also signals clear directions to take across all areas of public and private enterprise in the development of comprehensive policies to assist Australian families.

I want to look briefly at two important areas covered by the Institute. Firstly, I refer to youth incomes. The Institute's 1989 report on young people's incomes What Price Independence provides case material that queries the prevailing Government's assumptions that parents are able and willing to support their children and that young people's living costs are somehow less than adults. These assumptions have been behind cuts in social security benefits for young people and this report clearly shows these assumptions have been more rhetoric than factual. It would, I suspect, be too much to hope that the Government might actually take into account the facts in this report instead of the myths upon which it has based its attacks on young unemployed and young homeless people.

Secondly, I wish to look briefly at child poverty. The Institute's work in this area has been significant and influential and I would urge all senators to read the publication on child poverty released in 1989. Perhaps the most important point the Institute has pushed in regard to child poverty has been to look beyond the economic costs and to point out the great social costs to our community which, as this report notes at page 40, means that the eradication of child poverty `cannot be seen as a ``welfare cost'' but as investments in future productivity and social well-being for the whole nation'.

Indeed, this attitude is indicative of the Institute's general approach to its research. It attempts, through its various programs, to foster a preventative approach in relation to family policy; it looks beyond a number crunching mentality; and it tries to place its empirical research squarely in the context of modern Australian society. It tries to say: here are the facts and these facts show the way towards developing policies and programs that can keep families together through very difficult times but can also support members of families that are unable to stay together for whatever the reason.

Difficult economic times invariably lead to increased strain on families and it becomes important that we should support a body like the Institute which has as its goal the protection of the family as the basic social unit and which directs its energies towards-as the board points out in this report on page 5-`the need for an efficacy of preventive social support for families, as compared with the higher costs and difficulties of later forms of intervention'.

If more attention were paid to the work of this Institute by government, the Opposition, trade unions and business, we would be well on the way to addressing some of the community's more pressing problems. We just might have fewer kids sleeping on our streets, fewer instances of domestic violence, fewer people queuing for emergency relief from welfare agencies and fewer families in crisis. This annual report demonstrates the value of the Institute's work. It demonstrates that it deserves more than a continuing financial snub from the Government.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

It is with considerable concern that I note that this Government continues to support tobacco research in this country at a time when it is generally recognised that a great deal of the death and injury to health which occurs as a consequence of drug taking and drug addiction is related to the use of tobacco. The statistics show that some 80 per cent of drug related deaths in this country are related to the consumption of tobacco. While enormous efforts are put into the interception of other drugs, particularly the so-called hard drugs, they in fact play quite a small part in the death and injury which occurs to Australians as a consequence of the use of drugs.

Therefore, it is with some interest that I note that, according to this report, the Tobacco Research Council has allocated an amount of over $1.8m to 29 research projects and administration. On page 1 of the report the Council outlines the objectives of the Rural Industries Research Act 1985 under which it operates. The first objective reads:
increasing the commercial returns to industry members and to the community in general by improving the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of tobacco leaf.
Elsewhere it points out that the actual amount of tobacco leaf grown per hectare has increased quite substantially as a consequence of that intention. The other objectives are:
making more effective use of the resources and skills of the community and of the scientific community in particular; and
improving accountability for expenditure on research and development activities.

I raise a very serious question as to the moral sense of having a research institute attempting to increase the commercial returns to industry members and the community in general by improving the production, processing, et cetera, of tobacco leaf when, quite clearly, increasing the returns to industry members by increasing the consumption of tobacco leaf has absolutely enormous disbenefits to the community in terms of the damage to health and the number of people who are actually killed as a direct consequence of that damage to health.

Under the second term of reference, `making more effective use of resources and skills in the community and of the scientific community', in my view that is an enormous misallocation of resources, particularly the scientific resources of the Australian scientific community, in researching tobacco production and the production of such a dangerous material. Further on, the report mentions the challenges facing the tobacco-growing industry. Under six brief paragraphs it lists a number of the challenges facing the tobacco industry, but not one of those challenges listed is to do with the growing concern in the community of the enormous health effects of the use and consumption of tobacco and tobacco products.

It would seem to me that the major challenge facing the tobacco industry at present is precisely the rising concern which the community is expressing about the consumption of this material. If this partly Government-funded body does not recognise that as a challenge to the tobacco industry and take that into account, then surely this body is not fulfilling its proper public function.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I congratulate the Cotton Research Council on its report and the work that it does in trying to increase the industry's commercial returns. I note that the Council is attempting to do this by placing heavy emphasis on crop and environment protection and improving on-farm operations and management systems. I note that 65 per cent of the project funding is directed to these activities, and it has the support of the industry itself in these objectives. I am pleased to tell honourable senators that it makes me feel happy to be able to talk about a report from a rural industry that is doing well. In these days when we constantly hear of the disaster in rural Australia-no matter what the industry; whether it is wheat, wool, sugar, meats, fruits, beans or a range of other industries-it is comforting to know that some rural people are coping reasonably well. I might add that they are doing so despite the Government, as many of the rural problems in Australia today are not the cause of international events but rather of some short-sighted and devastating policies of the Government.

It is a pity that when discussing the plight of the rural industries, Government members opposite have to resort to quoting the buoyancy of the cotton industry to suggest that the rural crisis exists only in selected industries. I can tell honourable senators opposite that what they fail to appreciate is that the cotton industry is the exception and not the norm. Sometimes I wonder whether the Government has embarked on a policy of sabotaging Australia's rural industries for some unforeseen agenda of its own. However, as I said earlier, amid the rural gloom-what the crop farmers call `white gold'-cotton is shining through.

In my own State of Queensland, growers are gearing up for the start of a rich cotton harvest next month buoyed by a market price surge and useful late rains. Current estimates are that the crop could produce a record 400,000 bales worth more than $150m. Currently, world prices for cotton have topped $500 a bale on news that the United States' stocks are at a record low. Only yesterday I read in our Courier-Mail of a multi-million dollar expansion of cotton ginneries at Goondiwindi, St George and Cecil Plains which are nearing completion in order to handle the expected big crop. It has also reported on the success of farmers such as Glen Fresser, who left our own South Burnett district, where he was growing peanuts, to take up cotton farming at Nandi, near Dalby. Glen has switched completely to cotton, and it appears that, unlike many others in rural industries, he is surviving and doing well. Despite all the good news, I must point out that the report states:
. . . volatility of export prices has and will remain a feature of the industry, making it more difficult than otherwise for growers to plan their operations.'
The report notes that the industry exports over 90 per cent of the cotton it produces, with shipments being made to a wide range of countries, but mainly to those in the Asian region.
In total, Australian exports amount to only some five per cent of the world trade. However, there is cause for concern. The Council states:

Up until 1988, the fibre strength of Australian varieties, overall fibre quality and reliability of supply enabled the local industry to obtain a useful marketing margin over corresponding grades from other sources.
But since 1988, this margin has eroded and while this may have been partly due to the effects of extended rain during harvest, it is a matter of concern to local growers.

We also have to recognise that while the cotton crop yield in Australia is high by world standards, the great bulk of the crop is grown intensively under irrigation and, correspondingly, costs per hectare are high. The Council also notes that the crop is also at risk from the devastating attack from insect pests necessitating substantial amounts of pesticides to be used, which is both costly and carries the risk of resistance developing in these insects. Many of our bureaucrats recognise that even if a rural industry seems to be returning reasonable or high prices for its goods, much of that money goes quickly into paying bills, as there are often very high costs associated with producing the goods.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some brief remarks to the report. Firstly, I would like to congratulate the members of the Committee for concluding their investigations into the last Federal election so promptly and for presenting their unanimous report in ample time for some action to be taken. Too often these reports have become merely historic documents because the next election has been held before there was any response to the Committee's findings. Some of the findings in this report repeat recommendations made in the 1987 election inquiry. I think all honourable senators hope that the Australian Electoral Commission will take note of the report and will have procedures in place for the next election to overcome some of the problems which were apparent last March.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of the recommendations seem to be merely sensible management practice and should, for example, prevent the queuing which was such an unfortunate feature of the last election. When we have a purported system of compulsory voting where people face a potential $50 fine for not voting, it is incumbent on the authorities to make the procedure of casting a vote as quick and convenient as possible. It is interesting to note that the claim that this was a record turnout still means that there were nearly half a million voters on the roll who apparently did not cast a vote.

On the question of electoral rolls, the Committee notes `sustained criticism' of their accuracy. We await with interest the results of the Electoral Commission's check survey investigating enrolments in six electorates in the lead-up to the election that was due for release late last year-and we expect an undertaking that resources will be available to correct any weaknesses identified in records and/or procedures. The Electoral Commission is moving to full-scale use of the roll management system which, allied with the current comprehensive habitation review, is designed to ensure that the rolls are as up to date and reliable as possible. It is particularly important that this task is completed shortly so that redistribution this year uses the most accurate data. I am sure that all senators and members have an interest in ensuring this and with my colleagues I shall monitor this process and review the enrolment figures and projections issued by the Australian Electoral Commission.

Some of the reforms recommended by the Committee are plain commonsense. For example, the straightforward step of allowing a notional preference distribution by scrutineers will mean that meaningful results are available on election night. The Committee reports that perhaps Electoral Commission procedures were not geared for the increased vote recorded by independent and third party candidates. In my view, this may well have been a one-off experience. Honourable senators might wish to recall that, in the vote for the House of Representatives Australia-wide, the coalition polled nearly 400,000 more primary votes than the Australian Labor Party (ALP) and that the Government's parliamentary majority was obtained despite the fact that Labor did not achieve a popular majority on the two-party preferred votes. Given that this outcome repeated the experience at the last State elections held in South Australia, Western Australia, Victoria and Tasmania, I wonder how many submissions were received by the Committee from the electoral fairness and anti-gerrymander activists who have taken such a high profile in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one, I don't think.

—I thank Senator Kemp. Not one was received. The Committee made no recommendations about the system of public funding for elections and the requirements for disclosure of donations and of third party election expenditure. In relation to the latter matter, honourable senators may be disturbed to learn that the analysis of third party election expenditure at the March Federal election reveals that some Government-funded political advocacy groups spent significant sums to influence opinion during that campaign. Of course, the Liberal and National parties support to the fullest the freedom of speech and expression, including the right to promote views through paid advertising, but apparent round robins of taxpayers' money being given to lobby groups which then urge people to vote for their government patrons is a completely different matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the role of the Australian Conservation Foundation is particularly noteworthy. It spent $164,581 during the election, urging people to give their higher preferences to the ALP, and after the election its Government grant was increased-at a time of fiscal restraint-to $275,264. The Joint Standing Committee previously examined the question of election advertisements and some Labor identities are calling for a broadcasting ban during election campaigns. However, they do not appear to have expressed any disquiet about the practice I have described. Many of the third party groups which advertised during the election campaign had been recipients of taxpayers' grants. While anyone is free to promote their views, it appears totally incongruous that these campaigns should be indirectly funded by the long-suffering taxpayer. Indeed, it has all the hallmarks of corruption for governments to expose themselves to this type of pressure. It might be useful for the Committee to take a further look into this matter. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the remarks of Senator Parer and in particular I welcome the attention he has drawn to the growing development in this country of taxpayers' funds being used by special lobby and interest groups for their own activities. However, at the end of the day they seem to become remarkably active during election campaigns in supporting the Government, which has often so wilfully used taxpayers' money.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a few brief comments on the report before the chamber. I was appointed to the Committee in the latter part of August and therefore some of the deliberations of the Committee commenced before I joined it. I would like to say that I think the Committee worked well. Even colleagues such as Senator Faulkner were at times able to bury party political views. In my view, the Committee worked comparatively constructively.

I wish to draw a number of remarks to the attention of the Senate. One of the major concerns in the report was queuing at polling booths. A range of measures has been urged upon the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) to prevent that happening again. Another item that was featured was the facilitation of the processes so that scrutineers on election night could observe the candidate-party preferred vote. This arose because of the interest in some areas that some minor parties and interest groups could alter the results significantly. The primary vote then is not a fair indicator of the results and parties want to know how the minor party preferences are flowing. These changes would give a good indication on election night about who will form the government.

Happily, the recommendations of the Committee, if they are adopted, will not hold up the Senate vote count too much. Indeed, one of the recommendations refers to the importance of the Senate and requires an improved performance in the percentage of votes counted and the votes publicly announced on election night. Honourable senators will recall the inadequate performance in relation to the counting of the Senate vote last March in some areas.

I have a number of other matters I would like to draw to the attention of the chamber. We are pleased that some notice has been taken of the constant complaints about incorrect mail addressed to constituents and the amount of return to sender mail we receive. It has been suggested in the report that the AEC take note of the mail we forward to it with a view to cleansing the rolls. Perhaps the next report the Committee brings down could even toughen this up a little further.

It is good to see that there are increased penalties for deceptive how to vote cards and the like. Penalties are not much good once the material is printed, but they may be a deterrent. We will be monitoring this closely. Also, it is good to see that some effort will be given to reminding the older citizens of their obligation to vote. There is a noticeable change in voting incidence after the age of 70 years, when the percentage of non-voting persons increases considerably.

One matter which was to have come before the Committee and has been referred to by Senator Parer, but which apparently faded away, was the expected supplementary submission from the Labor Party on its proposal to ban electronic advertising or whatever scheme it may have decided upon. One would assume that the Committee will meet to examine the submission when it is ready. Honourable senators will be aware that there is constant speculation in the press about Labor's new stance, and I hope that we will be able to hear its proposals soon.

This was a report into the 1990 election, not an all-embracing view of things electoral. As such, we tried to resolve some difficult situations which necessarily differ from State to State and region to region. For example, polling queues are worse in the city than in the country, and worse in Sydney and Melbourne than other capitals.

The Liberal Party remains concerned with various other aspects of the electoral process, and one of the more important of these is redistribution. A fair redistribution can occur only with clean rolls and adequate forecasting of population predictions. We are concerned about the level of accuracy of electoral rolls and hope that the current round of habitation reviews will cleanse the rolls so that a fair basis can be obtained.

We are concerned that, when the population predictions are made, they should be done from a base of sound statistics which can be verified. We also want the reasons for making such predictions to be spelled out. In other words, we want to know how the final numbers have been arrived at, and their level of accuracy. We look forward with interest to the next redistribution results and trust that the end product is fair, equitable and just.

I reiterate my support for the comments of Senator Parer, who noted that, whereas the Labor Party in election after election does not win the majority of votes, it does in fact win government. He drew attention to the fact that those who are concerned about fair elections should be concerned about this. Senator Faulkner, who is in the chamber, is undoubtedly concerned. We look forward to his support when we ensure a fairer redistribution. In conclusion, I recommend that all honourable senators read this report, which by the nature of our profession is of interest to us all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my Opposition colleagues Senator Parer and Senator Kemp and commend the whole of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, including Senator Kemp, for the work that is represented in the Committee's report. It is of interest to all honourable senators and it is right that we review, not only after each election but systematically, the conduct of elections in this country and the general provisions through the Australian Electoral Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: I made a submission to this inquiry-I think we were all invited to do so-and I am delighted to see that the Committee, in its recommendations and in the report on pages 36, 37 and 38, fully accepts the submission that I made, which was to ensure that there are resources and procedures in place to ensure that the Senate vote is substantially counted on election night and that that count is transmitted to the Australian public.

To my dismay, on the night of the last election-more than any other I can remember in the last 20 years-the Senate was hardly mentioned. When the nation's attention was placed on the election that was being conducted that day and the result was being transmitted to the Australian public, it was most unfortunate that the public was given the impression that the House of Representatives was the only important part of the election because it was the only thing that was really discussed that evening.

This is important not only for the purpose of having information and some indication on election night as to the eventual result, but also to make sure that there is no inadvertent misconception or inadequate view given to the Australian public about the Senate and its importance. This Parliament is made up of two chambers. When elections are conducted, the results in the House of Representatives and the Senate are equally important.
The Committee finds as follows in paragraph 4.30 of the report:

The Committee recommends that the Australian Electoral Commission review its overall procedures for conducting and reporting the Senate count, particularly its data input procedures, to ensure an improved performance in the percentage of Senate vote counted and publicly announced for every State on election night at future elections.

I thoroughly endorse that recommendation. I called for it and I am glad to see that is the finding of the Committee. I look forward to that being fully implemented by the Electoral Commission and to the Australian Government ensuring that resources are available for that to happen.

As a footnote, I note that, at 11 o'clock on the last election night, in New South Wales only 3 per cent of Senate ballots had been counted; in Western Australia, 11 per cent; and in Tasmania, a substantial 68 per cent. My own State of South Australia had the second best percentage in that 58 per cent was counted. However, honourable senators will be dismayed to know that, even though that relatively large proportion was actually counted in Tasmania and South Australia, it was not transmitted through the media to the public. We had to wait until the next day to learn from the newspapers the results of the substantial counts in those two States.

At 11 p.m., when most of the media coverage turned off, there could have been a report. So I am looking not only to the Australian Government to make resources available and the Electoral Commission to ensure that the procedures are in place, but also to the Australian media to ensure that the information made available to them on election night is transmitted in a systematic way, through periodic reports, so that the Australian public has the information and the reinforced perception that the Senate is equally important in the determination of vote.

Of course, it is understood by us all that the Senate vote is much more complicated and that the final result of the Senate usually takes about a month to count, given the exact procedure for distributing preferences to determine the ultimate sixth position in most States.

I again commend the Committee on all of its work. I commend Senator Kemp and Senator Faulkner, who are in the chamber, as members of the Committee, and I am particularly gratified that this report has included the recommendation I sought.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Cooney, I present the first report of 1991 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 1 dated 13 February 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.
