PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 so as to enable Australia to ratify Protocol I additional to the Geneva Conventions. Protocol I is concerned with the protection of victims of international armed conflicts.

When Australia ratifies Protocol I it will, at the same time, ratify Protocol II which is concerned with the protection of victims of non-international armed conflicts. However, Protocol II does not require legislative action to enable its ratification. Protocol II applies to situations of non-international armed conflicts between the armed forces of a Party and organised armed groups exercising some territorial control over territory of that Party. It does not apply to internal tensions, or disturbances such as riots or sporadic acts of violence.

The application of humanitarian principles to international conflicts is, of course, an immensely difficult problem, especially where, as under the Protocols, distinctions are sought to be made between the civilian population and combatants, and between civilian objects and military objectives.

Although it is true that such distinctions can become blurred and indistinct, and ultimately may even cease to exist in conditions of total war, the reality remains that, in the period of 44 years during which total war has been avoided, there have been many limited wars with grave humanitarian consequences. Sadly, further such wars can be expected to occur and indeed our defence forces are currently engaged in such a conflict in the Middle East. It is in relation to conflicts such as these that the Protocols are especially capable of having an important and beneficial impact.

While, for its part, Australia will continue to work tirelessly to achieve world peace, it must accept that limited wars are likely to continue and take appropriate action, such as is involved in the ratification of the Protocols, to promote international adherence to the humanitarian principles embodied in the Geneva Conventions and in these Protocols.

If limited armed conflicts cannot be avoided, it is to be hoped that they will at least be conducted with some regard for the rights of civilians, and that belligerent nations will treat prisoners of war and wounded in accordance with internationally agreed principles. I note in this regard the important protections provided by the Protocols for particular categories of persons such as the wounded, sick and shipwrecked and civilian medical and religious personnel.

It must be remembered that the Protocols were developed after exacting work by many bodies, in particular the International Committee of the Red Cross, over an extended period from the early 1950's. Finally, a Diplomatic Conference convened by the Swiss Federal Council held four sessions in Geneva from 1974 to 1977 to negotiate the final texts. The Australian delegation to these Conferences, which played a major and demanding role in the debates at the Conferences, was led by Mr Frank Mahony OBE, then Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department.

The length and arduous nature of the process of development of the Protocols reflects the great difficulties encountered in striking a balance between competing interests while maintaining the principle of absolute and unconditional respect for persons outside the conflict.

The frequent involvement of irregular forces in recent conflicts has made the process of obtaining support of some nations for the two Protocols more difficult. Nevertheless, some 99 nations have now ratified Protocol I and 89 have ratified Protocol II. The full ramifications of Australia's becoming party to the Protocols for the Australian Defence Force and for our civil defence arrangements have been exhaustively examined by the relevant authorities. That examination has revealed no reason for Australia not to proceed to ratification. Indeed, there is every reason to ratify and to encourage other nations to do likewise.

I have already mentioned the work of the International Committee of the Red Cross in the development of the Protocols. I should also like to take this opportunity to make special mention of the valuable contribution of the Australian Red Cross Society in this regard. A joint Government and Australian Red Cross Society Committee has been formed to discharge our obligations under the Geneva Conventions to disseminate information. The Committee will provide a vehicle for carrying out similar activities in relation to the Protocols.

The Bill you have before you amends the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 (the Principal Act) to give effect to Australia's obligations under Protocol I. I turn now to a brief examination of those clauses of the Bill dealing directly with individual Articles of Protocol I.

Firstly, clause 5 of the Bill incorporates into the Principal Act the `grave breaches' which, under the Protocol, are required to be punished. These `grave breaches' are to be found in Article 11 and in paragraphs (2), (3) and (4) of Article 85 of the Protocol. They include such acts as physical mutilations and medical experimentation involving prisoners of war or refugees and indiscriminate attacks involving excessive loss of life in the civilian population.

Clause 6 provides for a certificate under the hand of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade certifying as to any relevant matter to be taken as prima facie evidence of that matter in any prosecution for a `grave breach'. This restates the existing status of such a certificate.
Clause 7 vests jurisdiction in State Supreme Courts to hear an application from a person who claims to be a prisoner of war for a declaration of his or her status.

Finally I wish to stress again the importance the Government places on Australia's ratification of these instruments. Despite their limitations, they do provide some measure of humanitarian protection for the victims of armed conflicts. I am aware that the Attorney-General has on a number of occasions called for bipartisan support for this vital humanitarian law reform and indeed the former Attorney-General adjourned debate to allow the Australian Red Cross Society to meet with the Coalition to try and persuade them to change their stance of opposition to the legislation. The Government therefore calls again upon all parties to state their commitment to the protections afforded by the Protocols and in particular to all the protections afforded to civilians caught up in the horrors of modern warfare.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill amends a number of Acts administered within my portfolio and other related Acts. The Bill contains amendments of a minor policy nature and corrections to existing legislation. None of the amendments concerns major policy proposals or sensitive policy issues.
A detailed explanation of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum. I propose to confine my remarks to the more noteworthy aspects of the Bill.
Part 2-Amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979

The Bill provides for improvements to the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 which follow up the reforms to the Australian Federal Police (AFP) work force last year. These include changes to the review and appeal process designed to extend rights of review in a way which will enhance efforts to make the AFP a more unified work force.

No longer will the right to review only apply within the same stream of appointment. In cases where a vacancy is advertised to be filled by either a police member or a non-police staff member it will be possible for a police member to seek a review of the promotion even if the vacancy is filled by a non-police staff member. The same rights will also apply if the vacancy is filled by a police member and a non-police staff member wants to seek a review. This change accords with the policy of promotion by merit and will bolster progress towards implementation of a unified work force. These policies are a key feature of employment within the AFP.

This aspect of the Bill is another step in the process which is transforming the AFP into one of the more advanced government work forces. The new work force is designed to encourage a multi-disciplined approach to law enforcement. The Government has recognised that in a world where methods used by criminals are increasingly sophisticated, the nation's premier law enforcement body must be efficient and capable of fully utilising the talents of all its personnel. Establishment of a system of staff selection which is efficient and fair to all personnel is an important element in encouraging the development of a committed and fully utilised work force.

The Bill will also underpin the capacity of the Minister responsible for the AFP and an administrator of an external Territory to enter into an arrangement for the AFP to police Territory laws. It will give the AFP functions, powers and duties in relation to those laws where an arrangement has been signed.
Part 3-Amendments to the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988

Section 16 of the Cash Transaction Reports Act requires cash dealers to report suspicious transactions to the Director of the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. The Act contains a very strict regime for the secrecy of the information so supplied. Under subsection 16 (4), where a cash dealer has lodged a suspect transaction report, only the Director or `a relevant authority' as defined may require the cash dealer to provide further information. Clause 21 amends the definition of `relevant authority' to include a reference to the Australian Customs Service. Provision is made for access to information by the Australian Customs Service in other parts of the Act. However, by an oversight, the Australian Customs Service was not included as a `relevant authority' in section 16. This is remedied by the Bill.
Part 3 also amends the Act to take account of the pending change of name of the New South Wales State Drug Crime Commission to the Crime Commission of New South Wales.
Part 4-Amendments to the Crimes Act 1914

Part 4 amends the interpretative provisions of the Crimes Act and these changes are discussed in the explanatory memorandum. However, more importantly, it replaces section 76 of the Act-Obstructing, et cetera, public officers. The amendment precludes any adverse consequences which may flow from the decision of the South Australian Supreme Court in Austin v. Parsons (1986) 83 FLR 402 which sought to give a very narrow interpretation to the section. The new section is based largely upon that recommended by the Gibbs Committee in its recent interim report Principles of Criminal Responsibility and Other Matters. The new provision will apply only to conduct after commencement of the amendment.
Part 5 and Schedule 1-Amendments to the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973

Australia is a party to a number of international conventions, including the Montreal Convention for the Suppression of Acts of Violence at Airports Serving International Civil Aviation. These conventions deal with the problems associated with the disruption of international civil aviation by terrorism, hijacking, personal acts of violence, acts endangering the safety of aircraft in flight, and the destruction of, or interference with, aviation facilities. Part 5 of the Bill amends the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973 to create the offences necessary to give effect to the protocol of the Montreal Convention. The protocol supplements the Convention, to which Australia and 136 other states are already parties, and is an important instrument designed to safeguard the safety of airports serving international civil aviation.

To this end, the Bill makes it an offence for a person to unlawfully and intentionally perform an act of violence against a person at, or to disrupt the services of, an international airport. It is also an offence to damage the facilities of, or to damage any aircraft not in service located on, such an airport. In all cases it is necessary that the act endanger, or be likely to endanger, safety at that airport.
Part 6-Amendments to the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983

Part 6 amends the Director of Public Prosecutions Act in order to create a separate statutory office of Associate Director. The need to create this position stems from the gradual extension of the statutory functions of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) since 1984. In March 1984 the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions was primarily a prosecution agency with only a limited civil remedies function. However, since then, the civil remedies have been expanded and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 confers on the office a leading role in the confiscation of the proceeds of crime.

Also, additional powers have been conferred on the Director since the establishment of the Office. The Director is now empowered to sign ex officio indictments and to grant transactional indemnities against prosecution, powers that were previously exercised only by the Attorney-General. The Associate Director will be able to exercise all of the powers of the Director except the Director's power of delegation under section 31.

The Bill also extends the power of the DPP to give a use/derivative use indemnity in relation to evidence to be given in a broader range of State or Territory proceedings. If a person is to give evidence in a State or Territory proceeding, and that evidence may disclose the involvement of the witness in the commission of a Commonwealth offence, the Commonwealth DPP may give an undertaking that the evidence, and any further evidence that is derivative of it, will not be used against the witness in Commonwealth proceedings.

The Bill will also ensure that the Director has such powers where the State or Territory proceeding is a coronial inquest or a proceeding before a body such as the New South Wales State Drug Crime Commission or the Independent Commission Against Corruption which is prescribed by regulation for this purpose.
Part 7-Amendments of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987

The Proceeds of Crime Act is being amended to pave the way for the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) to enact its own legislation dealing with the confiscation of criminal assets. At present the Proceeds of Crime Act applies to indictable offences against a law of the Commonwealth or of a Territory. `Territory' is defined to include the Australian Capital Territory. As a result, where a person is convicted of an indictable offence against the criminal law of the ACT any related confiscation proceedings are taken under the Commonwealth Act and any recoveries are paid to the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Commonwealth.

The ACT has indicated that it proposes enacting its own legislation dealing with the confiscation of criminally derived assets. In anticipation of this the Bill amends the definitions of `State' and `Territory' so that the ACT, like the Northern Territory, is treated as a State and the Commonwealth Act will cease to apply to offences against the laws of the ACT.

The transitional arrangements are that the Commonwealth Act will continue to apply to any case in which action under the Commonwealth Act has already been taken at the commencement date. For example, if a monitoring order has been made, a search warrant has been issued or a restraining order has been granted in relation to a particular matter, all subsequent proceedings in relation to that matter will be taken under the Commonwealth Act notwithstanding the amendments made by the Bill.
Part 8-Amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979

Part 8 of the Bill makes a number of minor amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. None of the amendments extends the interception powers under the Act. However, these amendments will facilitate the efficient operation of the Act and resolve a number of administrative difficulties in the operation of the Act as it affects law enforcement agencies. It may assist the House if I outline the major administrative and operational difficulties which the Bill addresses.

A warrant issued under section 48 of the Act authorises both the installation and use of equipment to intercept communications on premises if the judge is satisfied that interception would be impracticable or inappropriate otherwise than by using such equipment. `Equipment' is defined for the purposes of the Act, and that definition specifically excludes a `line' which is also defined for the purposes of the Act. The use of a line may in fact be necessary in an interception under a section 48 warrant, and an unintended consequence of the definition of `equipment' is to exclude expressly the use of a line. The Bill will remedy this defect.

Subsection 60 (1) of the Act requires the chief officer of an agency to which a warrant has been issued to cause the managing director of the relevant telecommunications carrier to be given a certified copy of the warrant forthwith. It is necessary to be able to locate a certifying officer as quickly as possible so that the necessary copy can be certified before the original warrant is forwarded to the Australian Federal Police for execution. The present definition of `certifying officer' has caused administrative difficulties because of the small number of persons able to certify a copy as being a true copy of the original. Only two persons fall within the definition in the New South Wales Police Force, and in Sydney, where applications by the NCA are usually made, there is only one member of the National Crime Authority who may certify copies. The new definition of `prescribed officer' in the Bill will extend the number of persons who are able to certify a warrant as being a true copy for the purposes of subsection 60 (1), by including assistant commissioners of the Australian Federal Police and officers of the police force of a State of equivalent rank, and an authorised member of the staff of the Senior Executive Service of the National Crime Authority.

Under section 79 of the Act, the chief officer of each agency is required to destroy information obtained from a lawful interception when the chief officer is satisfied that it is no longer needed for a permitted purpose. At present, the permitted purposes specified in the Act are nearly all matters connected with the investigation and prosecution of crimes. The Bill extends the definition of `permitted purpose' so that the chief officer is able to retain records, in the form of the number called by a target service, which may be used to comply with the record keeping provisions in part VIII of the Act. I should stress that information used for this purpose will not include the content of conversations.

Subsections 81 (1) and (2) of the Act require the Commissioner of the AFP and the Chairman of the NCA respectively to cause specified particulars and statements to be recorded in writing as soon as practicable after the happening of the events to which the information relates. In fact the recording of information by both agencies is computerised. Since some doubt whether the use of the expression `in writing' authorises the recording of the information by computer, the amendments made to subsections 81 (1) and (2) by the Bill will enable this information to be recorded by means of a computer.

In the preparation of the first annual report of the Minister under division 2 of part X of the Act, it became apparent that the obligation imposed by subsection 94 (3) on the Commissioner of the AFP and the Chairman of the NCA to provide information to be included in the ministerial report within two months after 30 June may in certain circumstances be impossible if all the information required by paragraphs 101 (1) (b) and (d) were included. Those paragraphs refer to an assessment of the average time for which warrants applied for during the relevant year were in force. Given that warrants may be issued for periods of up to three months, such an assessment could not be made if a warrant issued in the final month of the year under report remains in force more than two months into the new year. A similar amendment to section 35 will allow the complementary State legislation to be amended so that it also provides a three-month period for the provision of information.

The Bill also makes a number of consequential amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act following the change of name of the State Drug Crime Commission of New South Wales to the New South Wales Crime Commission and makes changes to correct minor drafting errors which were made in previous amendments to provisions of the Act.
Part 9 and Schedule 2-Amendments to Other Acts

The Bill will enhance the efficiency of the National Crime Authority by enabling it to assemble and give evidence directly to the prosecuting authority. At present such material must be given to the Attorney-General or a law enforcement agency. This change was recommended by the InterGovernmental Committee on the National Crime Authority.

The second schedule to the Bill amends certain Acts to ensure that the Commonwealth retains full and effective control over the substantive elements of legislation which currently apply ACT laws for certain purposes. For example, several Commonwealth Acts apply ACT law in some external Territories or to activities aboard aircraft. However, on 1 July 1990 the ACT Government took over responsibility for criminal laws of the Territory. As a result, if the Commonwealth wished to amend the law applied by these enactments, it would have to specifically amend each of these Acts. I regard this position as unsatisfactory and as Jervis Bay Territory laws are currently the same as ACT laws but are subject to the ordinance making power of the Governor-General, I propose that Jervis Bay law be the law applied by these Acts. These amendments will mean that where the Commonwealth amends by ordinance the ACT law operating in Jervis Bay this will flow through automatically to other applied law regimes without the need for separate amendments.
In the case of those external territories which are currently subject to ACT laws the amendments will apply Jervis Bay Territory criminal laws but continue to apply ACT civil laws.
Financial Impact

The amendments to the AFP Act and the consequential amendments and the amendments to the NCA Act will have only a minor financial impact. It is not anticipated that the other measures proposed in the Bill will occasion any increased costs to the Commonwealth. I table the explanatory memorandum for this Bill, and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus)-by leave-agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend various Acts relating to matters dealt with by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Bolkus) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Part 2 of this Bill amends the Industry Research and Development Act 1986.

The need to amend the Act has been brought about by the Government's decision to extend the Grants for Industry Research and Development Scheme (known as ``GIRD''). This means that the Government's Industry Research and Development support measures have now all been extended and are thereby complementary.

These schemes have been underway since the mid-1980s and have contributed to a marked increase in our industry research and development. The predecessors of the present schemes operated for well over a decade. This continuing support demonstrates to the business community the Government's determination to encourage innovation in industry as a basis for enhanced competitiveness and strength. Planning for R& is necessarily a long-term commitment and I am pleased that the Government is able to encourage this through its package of support schemes. GIRD Grants will total approximately $32 million per annum for the next four years.

The National Procurement Development Program (known as the `NPDP') is a relatively new component of the package. The concept of R& specifically directed towards the purchasing requirements of government agencies shows great promise. It has already been embraced by the States and Territories in a truly national scheme. For these reasons, I am pleased to take this opportunity to bring the scheme into the Act, rather than continuing to operate under delegation.

Despite the Government's continuing strong commitment to encouraging innovation in Australian industry, it is also, of course, critical that the utmost value is obtained from outlays in R& support. To this end, the schemes are under constant scrutiny. Furthermore, the Government will require comprehensive reviews of the schemes before committing funds past June 1994 (in the case of GIRD) and June 1992 (in the case of NPDP) the latter review is to be undertaken by the Industry Commission.
The opportunity to clarify some aspects of the legislation and to enhance rights of appeal is being taken.

The amendment proposed by Part 3 of the Bill to the National Measurement Act 1960 arose from a drafting oversight which could invalidate commercial contracts if not remedied. Prescriptions of all derived system international units of measurement will now, subject to guidelines, be Australian legal units of measurement. The amendment has no financial implications.

The provision of accurate traceable measurements within a competent National Measurement infrastructure is important to the quality of manufactured products as well as to scientific and technical advancement. These amendments will also allow Australia's legal units of measurement to be prescribed in a more comprehensive but abbreviated form in the National Measurement Regulations.

The amendment proposed by Part 4 of the Bill to section 9A of the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 will enable the CSIRO to accept gifts of up to $1 million without having to obtain Ministerial approval. At present, approval must be obtained for any gift regardless of its value. The amendment will save administrative resources by reducing the number of Ministerial approvals required. The amendment will also provide for future increases in the $1 million threshold to be made by regulation rather than by further amendments to the Act.
Part 5 of the Bill amends minor drafting errors in the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974, Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Act 1989 and the Patents Act 1990.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in the day the Senate was debating a motion moved by Senator Robert Ray dealing with the question of disclosure of in camera evidence. In that debate, before I was interrupted by other business, I was saying that this matter involves a conflict between two principles: on the one hand, the principle of the need to respect in camera evidence and, on the other hand, the principle of the right of parliamentarians to use information in a way that they believe is in the best interests of the nation. For a long time it has been very difficult for the Parliament to balance those contrasting requirements and it has come to a head today in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray has adopted the majority position of the Committee-mind you, a majority of five votes against four votes-which is to apply a fairly strict restraint upon the use of this evidence, in particular that if it is evidence put before a committee it cannot be used unless the Committee or the Senate consents that agreement. The position adopted by the minority in the Committee was to give greater flexibility than that while accepting some restraint. The reason for greater flexibility was that we felt that a dissenting senator must have an ultimate right to use the information put before a committee to justify or otherwise explain that dissent. To use in camera evidence in this way would not be a path readily trodden by any senator. It is accepted that in principle this evidence must be respected. Only in very unusual circumstances should it be made public in this forum of the Senate.

It is my view that it is really only in unusual circumstances that the Committee should take in camera evidence. It has been my observation over a period of years that the practice has become more common. Evidence has often been taken in camera when it was unnecessary for that to be done. I urge committees, even the more sensitive committees, to be reluctant to do so. I can remember the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority arguing on a number of occasions that evidence being put before it really could be put in open hearing and that that was the preferable course of action rather than taking in camera evidence, which was almost an automatic temptation by the Committee. Of course, if the evidence is put in an open session before a committee, we do not run into this situation. But in unusual circumstances the Committee will require-because of a particular sensitivity in principle or because of a sensitivity in relation to personal matters of a witness-that the evidence be taken in camera. Then, only in the most extreme and unusual circumstances, should that privacy be abused.

Nevertheless, we think there needs to be greater flexibility for minority senators in these extreme and unusual circumstances. Therefore, we proposed an alternative, which is put in full in the Committee report that is before the Senate today and which I propose to move by way of amendment to Senator Robert Ray's motion in the first instance, if Senator Watson's amendment is not successful. That amendment would allow a dissenting senator, after all reasonable effort has been made by the Committee to reach agreement on the matter, to refer to that in camera evidence. We say in the proposed amendment that evidence should only be used to the extent necessary to support the reasoning of the dissent.

Witnesses who gave evidence should, if at all practicable, be informed in advance of the proposed disclosure of the evidence and should be given a reasonable opportunity to object to that disclosure and to ask that particular parts not be disclosed. The Committee should give careful consideration to any objection by the witness before making its decision. Consideration should be given to disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave the evidence or who were referred to in the evidence. That simply demonstrates the respect that is necessary for witnesses who give such evidence.

I think that the Senate is at one on this. I think it is normally the practice in any event that a witness giving evidence in camera is advised in advance that there are circumstances in which that evidence might be made public. Certainly in those cases where it is not the practice, it is my view that that should be explained to the witness. The witness should not be under the impression that the evidence will not be disclosed under any circumstance.

There is one other matter that I shall mention now because I do not wish to speak separately to my amendment when I move it. It has been put to me that perhaps we have not given enough attention to the question of evidence put in camera that is of a national security nature. It has been put to me, and I see the merit of the argument, that that is one area in relation to some evidence perhaps where there should not be an option-even in the sort of extreme circumstances that I have in mind that would apply to this amendment that such evidence should not be made public. Senator Newman in particular has raised that with me. I do think that even if the amendment that I propose to move is carried, that aspect should be looked at again by the Procedure Committee. I would suggest that that be the case.

Similarly, this point has been raised with me in relation to certain evidence that gets put before the National Crime Authority. As the Senate is aware, the National Crime Authority does not take operational information but there may be evidence put before it which could in some way, if made public, benefit criminal elements. It may relate to the capacities of a police force or information about the nature of certain criminal networks. It may not relate to a particular operation but, nevertheless, if those involved in the criminal world became aware that this information was in the hands of police through its being put into the Parliament as a result of being taken up through the National Crime Authority, followed by a dissenting report and then certain in camera evidence being made public, that would not be desirable.

I understand that there is debate at the moment about legislative amendment to the National Crime Authority Act which might help to overcome this possibility. But if that is not the case, I would also suggest that at some time in the future, if my amendment is carried, the Procedure Committee might look at this aspect again.

Subject to that, I foreshadow that in a moment or two, after Senator Watson's amendment is dealt with, I shall seek to move the amendment which has been circulated and which is set out in detail in terms of the minority report. This will give minority senators who are dissenting to a report of a committee some further flexibility. Nevertheless, I think the amendment reasonably respects the interests of the person who happens to be giving in camera evidence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up the debate, which has been very long as I think we anticipated would be the case on this topic, most of the contributions have been positive. I do not think we have quite resolved the conflicting issues that we first outlined at the start of the debate. I would indicate that having moved the motion, I cannot accept Senator Watson's amendment. I am only speaking as an individual and what I am saying may give guidance to others who are foolish enough ever to follow my advice.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not like leaving in the hands of a witness whether something should be published or not. We discussed this matter in the Procedure Committee. Senator Reid pressed the matter several times and was the only one to support it. In fairness, I am trying to reflect both the majority and minority view on the Committee. Therefore, I think it should be rejected.

I want to make one other point. Several times Opposition senators have referred to this motion being carried 5-4. I do not think anybody has alleged that it was carried in a number crunching way. It was simply a matter of having a proposition to debate, knowing that there would be an alternative proposition. In my experience on the Procedure Committee, we have not too often resolved matters by a hard vote. In fact, I have been on the Committee since August 1981, initially in another form, and I have yet to recall an actual real vote. That could have occurred-my attention sometimes wanders a little at these meetings. I would indicate that from my point of view, representing some members of the Committee, I do not accept Senator Watson's amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Amendment (by Senator Hill) agreed to:
Leave out all words after ``That'', insert ``the following guidelines proposed at page 4 of the report, for the disclosure of in camera evidence, be adopted:

A dissenting Senator who wishes to refer to in camera evidence should advise the committee of the evidence concerned, and all reasonable effort should be made by the committee to reach agreement on the disclosure of the evidence for that purpose. If agreement is not reached, the dissenting Senator may refer to the in camera evidence in the dissent only to the extent necessary to support the reasoning of the dissent. Witnesses who gave the evidence in question should, if it is practicable, be informed in advance of the proposed disclosure of the evidence and should be given reasonable opportunity to object to the disclosure and to ask that particular parts of the evidence not be disclosed. The committee should give careful consideration to any objection by a witness before making its decision. Consideration should be given to disclosing the evidence in such a way as to conceal the identity of persons who gave the evidence or who are referred to in the evidence.''.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of other motions to be moved. Although they appear in a certain order, I think it would be better to put before the chamber the positive recommendations rather than those put forward for general discussion. I suggest that we dispose of them first and then return to the other items. Therefore, I move item 6:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following order proposed by the Committee, at page 11 of the report, for access to video recordings of Senate proceedings, be adopted:
That persons other than television stations may make use of video recordings of Senate proceedings, subject to the following conditions:
Recordings of proceedings are to be used only for the purposes of:
(a) providing fair and accurate reports of Senate proceedings; or
(b) providing information about the proceedings and operations of the Senate,
and shall not be used for:
(c) political party advertising or election campaigns;
(d) satire or ridicule; or
(e) commercial advertising.

I understand that this came out of a request, firstly, from Senator Peter Baume to have a video tape on the user pays principle of his final speech in this chamber. I understand that some senators may want a video tape of their great contributions here. I see no reason to stand in the way of this. I understand senators get 100 free copies of their speeches if required. I have never quite availed myself of that, nor have I ever read a pink.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your maiden speech or ordinary speeches?
—No, ordinary speeches, I think. As long as it is user pays--
—You wouldn't find 100 people interested in yours.

—We would need a big video tape for Senator Crichton-Browne, would we not? `Recidivist Revisited' would be the title. Those senators who would like to see themselves recorded for posterity giving the odd great speech should be able to get those great speeches at their own cost.
—On a full cost basis?

—I think it should be on a full cost basis, but the cost of a video tape is about $10. I do not think we would charge for the technical assistance, editing or anything like that. I, therefore, commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following order prosposed by the Committee, at page 12 of the report, for publication of Government documents presented to the President when the Senate is not sitting, be adopted:

That, if a minister provides to the President, or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, or, if the Deputy-President is unavailable, to any one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees, a document which is to be laid before the Senate, on the provision of the document:
(a) the document shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the document is authorised by this resolution;
(c) the President, the Deputy-President, or the Temporary Chairman of Committees, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the document; and
(d) the President shall lay the document upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.

Virtually at the end of every session we carry this resolution and it is merely proposed to standardise it and put it in the Standing Orders. If debate is required, Senator Coates has firmer views on this if there is any opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —One matter that has been raised is that whilst the spirit of what is in the recommendation is agreed, there is concern by some that this might mean that certain documents have slipped through without, perhaps, the appropriate analytical attention that they should receive from the Senate. The question has been raised as to whether such documents could automatically appear on the Notice Paper when the Parliament resumes, rather than be dealt with as are the many documents which do not actually reach that form. I do not know whether Senator Robert Ray, in his personal capacity, has any view on that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I should have added something to the explanation. It does not directly answer that question, but I will come to it in a moment. In proposing the procedure, I indicate that the intention is that it should apply to government documents only and not to statutory documents such as delegated legislation normally tabled by the Clerk. That is the first clarification. I think what Senator Hill is asking is: if we get an annual report in, will it appear on the first day on the Notice Paper as a tabled document?
—Yes.

—I would imagine that, firstly, the President would table all of those on his return-the President has acknowledged that-and, secondly, they can be debated in that section of papers that normally comes about on that first day. If necessary, for the convenience of the chamber, if there are a lot we may bleed them out over the week, so we may have 10 one day and 10 the next rather than get an uneven distribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is very important that we adopt this proposal. As Chairman of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration I have always been one of those concerned about the timely tabling of reports. One problem about the Parliament not sitting for, sometimes, a period of a couple of months is that reports that become available for tabling then have to wait those couple of months before being available. Of course, it means that the department or authority concerned has, as the date of tabling their report, a date those couple of months further down the track than when it was strictly available.

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that if a report becomes available on 5 January, as happens with committee reports, it can be tabled with the President and thereby become available. That is the date that it is recognised as having been available. Of course, as Senator Robert Ray points out, paragraph (d) of the proposal states:
(d) the President shall lay the document upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.

That is the point at which a motion to take note of the document would be available and for the matter to be dealt with. This proposal really ensures that matters that members, senators and the public generally are concerned about get on to the public record as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect, on the surface, that there is an intrinsic logic in the proposal but I want to say, for the record, that it does provide a mechanism for a government which has got very difficult and sensitive documents to postpone the presentation of those documents to the Senate after the Parliament rises. That is not to say that there is not logic in what is proposed.
—You can do that right now, and delay it for three months.

—I am not unaware of that. In the circumstances now the Government has to present the document in due course, but if it knows it has got two weeks and then it will be made public and debate will take place without a contribution from the Parliament, it is able to lower the temperature.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other side of the coin, the difficulty might well be under present circumstances that the Government may well have a document relating to conduct which has findings in it which, it may be concluded, are defamatory in respect of individuals. It may be that it, therefore, presents it to the Parliament. I think that is what happened in Western Australia with the McCusker report. The Government wanted to table it in Parliament because of some difficulties and this, at least, overcomes that problem, because if it is presented to the President it is deemed to have been presented to the Senate. As I say, it provides a mechanism to allow the Government to get the documents out on the public record without debate for some time.

TALK.START.PARA: — Do I understand that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) clearly has given an undertaking that any documents presented during the recess will not be just tabled by the Clerk, similar to the list we received today of documents tabled by the Clerk, but will, indeed, be put on the Order of Business amongst the proposed presentation of documents, which means that they automatically come up for debate?
—I have no objection to that at all; I think it is sensible.
—So long as we have an assurance that that would take place, then I am perfectly happy to go along with this.
—They will be tabled by me, Senator Walters, and then they will be open for discussion.
—Could I clarify that. Mr President, they will be tabled by you, but does that mean that they will be put on the Order of Business for automatic debate, because if it does not I am not happy with it.
—My advice is that they will be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990 relating to the presentation of committee reports when the Senate is adjourned, be varied by omitting paragraph (2) to read as follows:

(1) That, if the Senate is not sitting when a committee has prepared a report for presantation, the committee may provide the report to the President or, if the President is unable to act, to the Deputy-President, or, if the Deputy-President is unavailable, to any one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees, and, in that event-
(a) the report shall be deemed to have been presented to the Senate;
(b) the publication of the report is authorised by this resolution;
(c) the President, the Deputy-President, or the Temporary Chairman of Committees, as the case may be, may give directions for the printing and circulation of the report; and
(d) the President shall lay the report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.

In August 1990 the Senate adopted on a trial basis a procedure whereby committee reports may be presented to the President when the Senate is not sitting. By deleting paragraph (2) from the original order this will be now adopted on a permanent basis.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Coates

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order before Senator Robert Ray moves proposal No. 10. He seems to have overlooked on the list an earlier recommendation in the same section as that relevant to No. 10 on page 15 as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: That, in future, where the Senate intends that an order have a continuing effect, words along the following lines be included in the order to make that intention clear:
This order has effect notwithstanding anything contained in the standing orders and is of continuing effect.
Was that an oversight or does the Minister have a clear intention not to move that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have taken some advice on this matter and I am still not perfectly clear on it. Given that the Committee adopted that, maybe it should have come up at this stage. It is an oversight by me, but we might have to get some clarification on that and come back to it.
—Would it be in order if I moved it in accordance with the Committee's recommendation?
—I will let Senator Coates do it, as it is his baby.
—If the Minister wishes to do it, I am happy.
—I will move that the recommendation concerning continuing orders on page 15 of the report be adopted.

—A motion in the terms that Senator Coates has just put may be inadequate. For example, the discussion makes it clear that it is simply limited to future resolutions for a start, but I am not too sure whether that is adequately covered by the words that have just been used.
—I am happy to move it more explicitly if that is preferred.
—Yes, I would.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in future where the Senate intends that an order have a continuing effect, words along the following lines be included in the order to make that intention clear:
This order has effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders and is of continuing effect.
I hope that that reassures Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that covers the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to record that I agree with the wording the way it is, as distinct from proposals that there was some doubt as to whether the resolutions in the present Standing Orders were not continuing. I am glad that it is acknowledged at least that that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the orders of the Senate of 5 December 1989 relating to the referral of Bills to committees cease to have effect on 1 July 1991.

I believe that this was carried at the time of the Committee without opposition but that some opposition has emerged. It relates to the new committee procedures. It relates to the debate on 5 December. Indeed, when we had this debate on the committees as to whether we would set up this new committee system, there was some confusion on the floor of the Parliament. Senator Chaney and I both intended that this committee system should be experimental, should be reviewed at an appropriate time, and should be a sessional order rather than a continuing order.

It is true to say that a lot of technicalities and election dates have made it totally unclear as to precisely when that would occur. The intention of the Procedure Committee is to make that review much more likely by putting a sunset clause in on the current committee system so that we will be sure to get a report back before that sunset clause comes into effect.

I am not making any judgment as to whether I believe the current committee system-that is, the reference of Bills after the second reading stage to the committee stage debate-is working. I have seen some quite good examples and some very moderate examples of how well it has worked. Various Ministers and various committee members from all sides bring back different reports. All I say is that the jury is still out, but we had better have a look at it at some stage. It was never intended to go on forever without review. This resolution makes it quite clear that there is a sunset clause that will force a review. We would need the results of the review-I suggest before this sitting period ends-so that we can look at that and continue it as it is, not continue it at all, or modify it according to the appropriate means.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, there is already a sunset provision in that the amendment which was moved by Senator Robert Ray and accepted by the Senate on 5 December 1989 provided that it would operate for a parliamentary session. That amendment seems to have overtaken a provision that was in the motion as put before the Senate by the Committee, which was for it to operate as a continuing order of the Senate. The only discussion really is what is the most appropriate date for a sunset clause-whether it now needs to be brought forward. As I understand the argument, it is that the election took place before these provisions actually came into effect and, therefore, there was no session between the passing of the original motion and the completion of a session. Therefore, the provision that we now find ourselves with is one that was to commence on the first day of the sitting after the election and to operate for the session. As I understood it, and as a result of Senator Ray's amendment, it was accepted that it was not intended to have a continuing effect but that it was to be for a trial period for a reasonable time.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my view-and I have to confess that at the time of discussion of this briefly in the Committee I was not properly aware of some of those finer details, which is my fault-that that does not affect the merits of the case at the moment. It is my view-particularly from the experience we have had that it is taking a while for this new procedure to evolve-that there ought to be a reasonably lengthy trial period. Already we have seen considerable improvement from our first steps after implementation of the new procedure. Already we have by informal arrangement modified some of the original thoughts as to operation that we had on all sides of the chamber. We realise that some further modifications are still necessary and that the procedures can continue to be improved. In other words, the judgment that has to be made in due course can be made on a system that still has room to be improved and to operate better than it is at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seeing that you have changed your mind, do you want to refer it back to the Committee?

—I was going to say that we do provide in this report that the Procedure Committee will take up the issue in May and look at how it is operating. I think that should continue. In May, the Committee might decide to look at it again during the Budget session. I do think that it would be just a little too precipitous at the moment and not give the new system a fair trial if the cut-off date was brought in as of 30 June 1991, which is only a few months away. We are not arguing with the principle that it is for a trial period; we are not arguing that it needs to be reviewed by the Procedure Committee; I am saying on reflection that at the moment the date that has been put in this motion-at the end of this financial year-is a little too early for a fair judgment to be made of the operation of the new system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse much of what Senator Hill has said. I am not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Procedure, as honourable senators would know, and I can imagine how, meeting in order to get a report to the Senate by December 1990, that Committee made the recommendation which is before us now as a motion because the teething troubles of the first period of sitting using this new committee system were considerable. We have in my Party room discussed its operations already this year. Several of my colleagues have had what they consider to be, both on their behalf and also on behalf of many organisations in the community, a very good experience, although we had to grapple for quite some time with this system.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Hill that there is still a way to go and I am very happy with that part of the recommendation which suggests that a review is still in the hands of the Procedure Committee with recommendations due in May. Clearly, we have more work to do and we are all in the position of looking at it and seeing how it works as we go into it in the new sitting period. We would be unhappy in supporting the motion which the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) has put because we think that the other aspect of the report which talks about the review is the way we would prefer it to be. To have, in effect, the thing killed off on 1 July I think would affect the way we all operate with the system between now and then. Accepting that a review is taking place is a more positive environment in which to use the system for this six-month period or until May. At that time we will have a much better perspective on the system.

I say all this in the context of leading a party for which it is an enormous burden to work with this system. All of my colleagues carry four or five portfolios and sit on three or four committees, some of which are not in their portfolio areas. It is very difficult for us to service that system properly.

Nevertheless, it is of benefit in developing better legislation and, particularly, in giving a voice to people in the community on legislation. We are happy with that aspect of this Committee report which says there is a review and recommendations will come before the Senate in May. We look forward to those recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few brief remarks about this matter. I do not want to get into the merits of the system that has been adopted; that is a debate for another day. I want to make it clear that the reason for this proposal is to attempt, at this late stage, to implement what was the clear intention of the Senate in December 1989. It was that there be a short experiment with this referral of Bills to committee procedure. Even if the sunset clause of June 1991 is adopted, the experiment will still be a lot longer than was originally intended.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite anybody in the chamber to talk to former Senator Chaney about what his intention was in agreeing that the matter ought to be a sessional order as adopted in the last session of the Parliament. It was adopted as a sessional order, in order that it would come to an end when the Parliament was next prorogued; that is, at election time. Senator Chaney, in his confidence about winning the election, made it clear in discussion when the amendment was moved to change it from a continuing order to a sessional order that he did not want to have the system set in concrete without there being a new decision after the election. As it happened, the election occurred before the Parliament sat again at the beginning of 1990 and that session came to an end.

My argument, all along, has been that what was adopted in December 1989 as a sessional order should have come to an end at the end of that session; that is, at the dissolution of the House of Representatives. That did not happen because priority was given to observing the other leg of the procedure, which was that it commence on the first sitting day of 1990. At the very least, those two clauses were ambiguous. But, despite the fact that it was a sessional order which should have been terminated and should have required a new decision in the new session, the commencing date of the first sitting day of 1990 was observed rather than the status as a sessional order.

Hence I want to emphasise the need to have a sunset clause on the matter so that there is some pressure on the Procedure Committee and the Senate itself to have its review which is being proposed for May. I venture to suggest that if there is no June 1991 sunset clause the May 1991 review will not happen and will not be dealt with in May 1991. It will drift on, as with so much else in this place, until much later in the year. The period of operation will continue to drift on and will end up going until the end of the session which will probably be the end of 1992 or early 1993 without having the proper review as was originally intended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to withdraw the motion on the basis that honourable senators have had a better view of it and we do not have a unanimous view. The Committee can follow it up in whichever way it likes in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now come to some fairly standard motions to note what is in the report because the Committee could not come down with a conclusive view on it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of this part of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few brief comments. As a new senator, my first impression coming into this chamber and listening to Question Time was that the Chair had very little control over the answers of Ministers. I was very pleased to learn that the arm of the President is well buttressed by a series of Standing Orders and precedents, which give the President quite substantial control over the way questions are asked and the way answers are given. I was pleased to read in the report that the Standing Orders and precedents are actually detailed.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators who have had the opportunity to witness the degeneration of Question Time in the other place over recent years will recognise the importance of Senate rules. We must all have some considerable sympathy for you, Mr President, for what you inevitably face in enforcing the Standing Orders. The report indicates-and I happen to agree with this aspect of it-that the rules applying to answers are not as strictly enforced as they might be. It also points out that the rules applying to questions are also not as strictly enforced as they might be.

Mr Deputy President, I recognise that there must inevitably be some considerable discretion given to the Chair on making judgments on issues such as the relevance of answers. However, it is important in my view to note that the Chair does not have the right to ignore Standing Orders or, through a very loose interpretation, to alter substantially the guiding rules under which Question Time operates. Nor, in my view, does the Chair have the right to substitute other rules which have not been debated or accepted by this chamber.

Changes in Standing Orders can, of course, only be made by this chamber. It therefore causes me some concern, and I hope it may cause some concern to my colleagues, to read in the report the view that Question Time is better conducted with a liberal application of rules and with minimum intervention by the Chair. I do not believe this is the case. As I have said, looking at the practice in the other place, we have seen what in fact happens when standing orders are not effectively and appropriately applied. But also, my comment is sustained by reference to the experience in this place.

In my view, a very liberal application of the rules has meant that, too often, Ministers have been able to get away with long, rambling answers which are often used to gratuitously attack the Opposition and avoid providing the information which has been sought by the questioner. Odgers points out in his standard work, Australian Senate Practice, that Question Time is:
. . . the most obvious manifestation of responsible Government, i.e. the direct accountability of the Executive to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all your spurious points of order?
—Just hold on; just control yourself. Question Time relates to the administration of Government departments and through Question Time:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the searchlight is thrown on to all aspects of government activities, and Ministers must account for their administration.
Far too often, in my view, Ministers treat parliamentary Question Time with contempt.

As a result, the number of questions asked during Question Time has fallen under this Government, averaging some 22 per day per Question Time compared with around 28 questions per day under the Fraser and Whitlam governments. It is probably worth recording that prior to 1972 the number of questions per day averaged over 30, including supplementaries. In 1971, for example, over 33 questions were asked on average per day, and indeed answered.

The report suggests that the number of questions has been increasing in recent times. I do not think that is sustained by the statistics. In the last two sitting weeks in December, the number of questions averaged only 22-roughly in line with the average since the advent of the Hawke Government. It is pleasing to read in the report that the President has positively responded to the wish of honourable senators that there should be a tighter application of rules applying to Question Time. I have the strong view that we should aim to achieve a target of 28 questions, including supplementaries, during Question Time. This would restore previous practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many points of order have you taken during Question Time?
—Senator Faulkner makes very little contribution to this chamber, so if he wishes to make a statement, why does he not stand up and give a speech rather than yell out gratuitous insults?
—Order!

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, I will continue. Twenty-eight questions can be achieved, even by this Government. On some three occasions since the election this target number has been achieved or exceeded. If 28 questions are not achieved then, in my view, Question Time should be extended until the target number is reached. Mr Hawke has set a target number for the House of Representatives. Senator Faulkner may snigger but his own Prime Minister believes there should be a target number. In my view, the target number in the other place is too low but nonetheless, I welcome the acceptance that there should be a target number of questions asked during Question Time. I would urge the Government to adopt a similar practice in this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the tolerance shown by this chamber to Government Ministers is rapidly running out. I predict that unless the performance of Ministers during Question Time rapidly improves, the Senate itself will change the rules relating to Question Time. Let the Ministers recall the precedent that was established by Senator Lionel Murphy when he was Leader of the Opposition. This is what Lionel Murphy, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, did in 1967. He moved a motion which gave unlimited time to Question Time to ensure that all honourable senators with questions had the opportunity to ask them.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Opposition leaders move those sorts of motions.

—That applied for four or five years. I am not urging that on this chamber. All I am urging on this chamber-and I am surprised I have been subjected to the abuse by the Minister at the desk, Senator Robert Ray-is that Question Time achieve a standard of performance which has been achieved by previous governments in previous decades. I am not urging that it be tightly constrained by rules, but I am urging that we should see a tighter application of standing orders. I believe that the consequences of not doing that will require this chamber-and I am sure it will receive the support of the majority of honourable senators-to restore tighter rules to Question Time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —With the concurrence of the Senate, I would like to speak on this issue from the floor. If there is no objection I will. The issue that Senator Kemp raised is something that is constantly before the participants in the Commonwealth Speakers conference, both at a regional level and at the Commonwealth Speakers conference itself. We have discussed this issue in the past and I think we have come down on the point of view that a strict application of the standing orders would be a total disaster. I ask all honourable senators to have a close read of them and I think they will agree with me. There has got to be some give and take at Question Time. After all, it is not Sunday school.

INTERJECT.PARA: Recently I had an opportunity of speaking to Speaker Weatherill from the House of Commons and also the Clerk of the House of Commons, Sir Clifford Boulton. These are people who are experienced and have seen many Speakers in action in the House of Commons. They say that they try not to be bogged down because they do not want to reach the situation where there are continuous points of order during Question Time. They believe that they come down quite strongly on the side of the Chair being more flexible.

It is also a point of view that was taken by some of my colleagues in New Zealand where only a few years ago a new Speaker strictly applied the Standing Orders at Question Time. For the first couple of months everybody thought he was good but then it developed into chaos. I have some figures here that give the number of questions, the number of supplementaries, the total, the sitting days and the average for every year since 1981 until the end of 1990. I would seek leave to have that incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason that I have mentioned 1981 is that that is the first full year in which no government had control of the Senate. Again, the reason for mentioning that is that now we have four parties and a number of Independents in this chamber, it is a much more combative chamber. I have found in my experience that we have a much more structured Question Time than we ever had before 1981. Certainly from when I was elected in 1975 and 1981, we had a much less structured Question Time. I believe that the structured Question Time we have at the moment leads to a great deal of frustration, particularly for the Opposition backbenchers, in trying to ask a question.

INTERJECT.PARA: Let me just give the Senate an example of what a normal day is at Question Time: five Liberal questions, two Democrat questions, one from the National Party, one from the Independent, seven from the Government, and with three or four supplementaries, quite often one backbench Opposition member gets one question during Question Time which has perhaps averaged 21 or 22 questions. Of course, we have got a structured Question Time, which is something the Opposition wants. It has been a long time since the Opposition has not handed me a list and said that I have got an open Question Time. If one looks at when we did have an open Question Time, the Senate often did get 28 questions. But it will never get 28 questions whilst we have a structured Question Time.

You, Mr Deputy President, and I remember coming into this chamber when there were 28 or 30 questions a day. Often, as a new backbencher, one would get two questions quite easily during Question Time. There was not the structured Question Time that we have today.

But let me point out to Senator Kemp and to other senators that in 1990 we averaged 22.6 questions per sitting day. In other years to 1984 we had 20.7, 19.5, 21, 22, 22 and 23. In fact, last year was the best year with the most questions asked since 1984. In 1983 we had 20; in 1982, 23.1; and in 1981, 25.2.

I wish to make a few other points. It is very hard for me to decide in the chair whether the answer a Minister is giving is becoming a debate. I would point out, particularly to some members of the Opposition, that when a point of order is taken very early in the Minister's answer it is impossible for me to determine when that answer is going to become a debate.

We also have the problem of the Chair deciding when a Minister's answer has been too long. If honourable senators want me to introduce a time limit, I will. But I just say to the Senate that I believe that that would be another disaster. I believe that, in implementing a time limit on the asking of a question, a time limit on the answering of the question and a time limit on supplementaries, we would get 14 or 15 questions in the hour if we were lucky. I say that because I have sat here and seen the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), for example, take eight minutes to answer a question and there has not been the slightest objection and no point of order. I have seen another Minister go for three minutes and a point of order has been taken purely because of the way that Minister is answering the question. So I come down very strongly in support of the Procedure Committee report.

I say again to Senator Kemp and others: have a look at the table of questions which goes back to 1981 that I have now put into the Hansard. If they think of the political changes that have occurred in the Senate since 1981, I think they would have to agree that last year was very good year by comparison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to defend the President's conduct of Question Time. I think the suggestions that are implicit in the criticism of Question Time are unreasonable. One can say that there ought to be some particular number of questions asked and answered each day. There is no particular problem about that but there is no particular magic number of questions. I do not know what is so magic, for instance, about 28--
—It is just that just about every other government has been able to achieve that. It is as simple as that.

—It is not a matter of every other government being able to achieve that. I think honourable senators have to look at the quality of the whole operation. If we want to, we can have a rigorous administration of Question Time, as happens in the House of Representatives. I saw a part of the House of Representatives Question Time today. One of the front bench members of the Opposition sought to provide a quote as a preface to a question. Because the House of Representatives is more rigorous about the nature of questions, the Speaker attempted to make him come to his question very rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, in the Senate there is-one might even use the words-a more civilised atmosphere at Question Time. Members of the Opposition, in the framing of their questions, can get away with much more as far as presenting information as a preamble to a question is concerned. All sorts of things are supposedly ruled out by the Standing Orders in the nature of questions-arguments, inferences, imputations, epithets, ironical expressions and hypothetical matter. Those sorts of things are, in a reasonable administration of Question Time, allowed quite reasonably and everybody gets on in a much less gladiatorial way than would occur if there were to be a very strict administration of Question Time.

I would like to ask members of the Opposition, in view of their criticism, to think about the fact that there has been a change in the last couple of years in the nature of the structure of government which has affected the way in which Ministers are able to answer questions in the Senate. At the moment, six of the eight Ministers who are answering questions in the Senate are in the Cabinet. I think that is an unusually high number--

TALK.START.PARA: —Quality will out.

—No advertising, please. I have not done an analysis, but my impression is that several years ago there was a much smaller number who were in the Cabinet. When we had 27 or 28 departments, there was a much greater proportion of questions to Ministers representing Ministers in the House of Representatives and there was an inability to answer straight away all questions that came up. Hence, many more questions would have been answered quickly because the Minister representing was able to say that he did not have a brief on the matter and that he would refer the question to the appropriate Minister. We now have a situation where senators have a right to expect more substantial answers because of the fewer number of departments in the current ministerial structure.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a higher proportion of Ministers who are in the Cabinet and, therefore, they are fully responsible for the portfolios they are administering. Even in the case of Senators Tate and Collins, who are not in the Cabinet, their portfolio responsibilities are broad enough to provide for them to answer in a quite substantial way. So simplistic comparisons of numbers do not necessarily reflect the way in which questions are answered.

I think the President does an excellent job in balancing the need for Ministers to provide sufficient information in reply. He displays a great tolerance in respect of the way in which questions are drafted by those who are asking them. The way in which Question Time is administered here is very reasonable and I think it would not be in either side's interests to try to be very much tighter in this respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President--
—Senator Kemp, you have already spoken to the motion.
—Can I speak twice on this motion?
—No.
—You're an expert on Standing Orders.
—I did not claim that I was an expert on Standing Orders. There were some comments made that I want to comment on. Can I seek leave to make some remarks?
—You may seek leave. We are in the Senate, not in committee. That is why you cannot speak a second time. But you can seek leave.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I might give an explanation why leave was refused. In these sorts of debates senators put all their arguments up front. If senators get up and speak early in the debate they just have to cop it if they are shot down and misrepresented.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not address these issues; I simply moved the motion to take note and thought I might respond to any intelligent comments that had been made. Maybe I should sit down. What we heard from Senator Kemp today is just the normal Opposition mentality-that is, Question Time should really be like Little Big Horn all over again; the Opposition can go downhill with the breeze and we are not allowed to fight back while being chopped to pieces. It is not like that, Senator Kemp. Question Time is a very combative thing. In this chamber it is more combative than anywhere else in the world. It has evolved that way, although I have no idea why.

While we are on the subject of questions, let us go to questions rather than answers. Let me say something about the length of questions. I think Senator McLean would agree that his question to me today just scraped into one page. So the questions are getting longer. As well as the questions getting longer, we are also at the point that I think Senator Coates referred to. Ministers in this chamber have direct responsibility for the Departments of Industry, Technology and Commerce, Defence, Foreign Affairs and Trade, Social Security, and Administrative Services.
