A lot of the bigger departments of government are represented here, so we are much more likely to get detailed questions.

The day of the single-phrased question has gone; it is always four or five points. Members of the Opposition hope that the Minister cannot get it down in time and so will forget one, and hope that we will have supplementary questions, whether they are required or not. The growth of supplementary questions has skyrocketed in recent years. I think Senator Kemp said that some days are worse than others. I agree with him that some days have not been the best. Sometimes I have said to my colleagues that I think we should shorten the questions, then we get interrupted with inane points of order that have no relevance to the Standing Orders; they are just argumentation. So I send another note down, `Don't bother. If they're not going to cooperate, we won't.' I think the point is that I discerned-obviously Senator Kemp has not-some attempt on this side towards the end of last year to try to get more questions answered.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not shown by statistics.

—Statistics do not mean everything. I can get up to 40 questions a day if 25 are put on notice-they still apply as questions. Members of the Opposition have a structured Question Time. The only time questions increase to 28 is on Friday when the lid is lifted. I do not criticise structured questions, that is their choice, not our choice.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the most inane and vacuous statement coming from Senator Kemp is that the Standing Orders should be applied strictly. I ask honourable senators to take their minds back to questions that have been asked in the last two days to see whether any of them could have got through the following rules: questions should not contain statements of fact or names of persons unless they are strictly necessary to render the question intelligible and can be authenticated. Honourable senators should think of Senator Vallentine's question today that could not be authenticated. It should have been bowled out under the Standing Orders. There should be no arguments in questions. Well, goodbye Senator Short! Every one of his questions contains argumentation. Questions should not contain inferences. Goodbye Senator Alston! Every one of his questions has inferences. Questions should not contain imputations-there were only a few, but a few more will get them. They should not contain epithets or ironical expressions. There is not much sense of humour opposite. Senator Harradine is looking my way. Quite a lot of his questions have that whimsy and irony when he asks them. So we have to bowl all his questions out.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was minding my own business.

—I know, I just thought I would give the honourable senator a hit on the way through to make sure he is awake. Questions should not contain hypothetical matter. We are always being asked hypothetical questions. Maybe Senator Kemp was not referring to those to be strictly applied-commonsense is the thing. I think that the President, on occasions--
—I was referring to the rules in your report. You gave us this report.

—It is passed down from on high, is it? I am sorry, I did not realise that I had the Ten Commandments in front of me. The President intervened and probably upset some of the Ministers when he told them to sit down and shorten their answers, something I never saw in my two years or 18 months in Opposition.
—That is not fair.

—Well, they did not. When we were getting the 18-minute answer on cosmic mix from someone I regard highly, I did not hear any presidential intervention to say that we should not. We did not intervene because we were so fascinated by the answer. Then we get to the next three rules: questions shall not ask for an expression of opinion. How often are we asked for an expression of opinion or a statement of the Government's policy? Today we had questions on government policy, defence exports and a whole range of matters, all for an illegal opinion. I must say that that is sometimes enforced. The main rule is commonsense. If those opposite want that rule book applied to the Standing Orders--
—Relevance, debating the question; what has happened to those? We did not get any response to those.
—Senator Kemp says that we have to be relevant to his narrow, illogical, poorly-based, unauthenticated questions. Ministers have to be bound by relevance to his question!

SPEECH.PARA: This matter has been debated over many years. A colleague here has quoted Senator Lionel Murphy and what he did. He did some good things in the Senate and he did some bad things, but he always acted as an Opposition leader. If Senator Kemp ever makes that 10-yard journey he will be amazed how he will do a 180-degree turn.

Senator Walters knows what it is all about and that is why I like her. She sticks to the Liberal Party first and worries about the Standing Orders, procedures, committees and all the rest later. However, I really do believe that she should be deselected, so I will not encourage anyone to take her on.

Those opposite will change if they walk to this side because they will see it from a different perspective. The clearest example of that that I ever went through in this chamber-I will conclude on this note-was reading Senator Fred Chaney's great speech on four-year terms made in 1974 when he was vigorously opposed to it because he was in Opposition; in 1977, he was fervently in favour of it; and in 1988-89 he was fervently opposed again. Those opposite should draw a line down the middle of the chamber and, depending on which side they are sitting on, they will look at things from a different perspective. I agree that in Question Time we should try to get more numbers up and keep questions relevant and short.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, answers short. That is the issue.

—Those opposite should keep their questions short as well-it applies to both sides-cut out vacuous points of order and cooperate, and we may see a gradual improvement. I think we are starting to see a partial improvement at the moment. I can tell honourable senators that they will not be able to legislate for it by changing these rules because it is difficult for any Presiding Officer-be it Senator Sibraa, Senator Colston or anyone else-in the chair to interpret when and where to draw the line. I am really surprised that members of the Opposition come in here and suggest that these rules should be enforced. If we take a point of order tomorrow on all questions and 90 per cent are knocked out, those opposite would want to go to the barricades as we are being undemocratic and unfair. In conclusion, I agree a bit with Paul Keating. I think that Question Time is a privilege extended by the Government to the Opposition.

—by leave-Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. I would like to refer to the comments that Senator Coates made. He said that I reflected on the conduct of the President in this chamber. I did not reflect at all on the conduct of the President; in fact, I went out of my way-Senator Coates can read the Hansard-to praise the President's role. I appreciated the difficulties--
—I'd be surprised if I mentioned your name at all.

—Can I make the personal explanation? Just keep quiet so that I can make it. I said that I appreciated the difficulties of the President. I was making some proposals by which I believed Question Time could be reformed. I was reflecting on the conduct of this chamber, not the conduct of the President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I was called from the chamber, but upon returning I listened to some of the colourful contribution of Senator Robert Ray. Lest what we on this side of the chamber are seeking be misinterpreted, I think it important to remind the Senate that the Opposition members on this Committee state in the report before the chamber that we consider that the rules relating to Question Time should be applied with the aim of achieving more questions and answers per day.

SPEECH.PARA: We accept the goodwill and good faith of the President, but the debate within the Procedure Committee was really along the lines that there can still be goodwill and good faith but that a stricter interpretation of the rules applying to both the asking of questions and the answering of questions would allow the asking and answering of more questions during the period of one hour. It is that sentiment that we are simply seeking to communicate in this debate. We do not want the type of interpretation that I think Senator Robert Ray alluded to, which would simply lead to a breakdown of the functioning of Question Time. I agree that there must be some element of commonsense in the interpretation. As a senator in this place I think it could be tightened further and could achieve the objective we think is desirable, which is getting more questions asked and answered while still maintaining the spirit that I think the President has sought to maintain from the chair.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We move on to item 4: televising of question time-personal explanations. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of this part of the report.

This has been around for a long time. Frankly, who determines whether someone has had a bad go? Who is the arbiter? How does one resolve it? I think the Committee said that it could not really be done in a proper manner. We have not had the problem so far, fortunately; we hope that it does not turn up but, if it does, it will be almost impossible to arbitrate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Estimates committee reports, recommendations for further consideration of matters, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of this part of the report.

I think this matter came out of a reference that the Chairman may have made in this chamber at the start of the last Committee of the Whole. The initial intention was to draw up a new committee procedure which had various checks and balances. Quite frankly, it was a bit of turkey for the plate for both the Opposition and the Government. It was all a bit of a trade; we would all go forward and we would all get something out of it. One of the things we were supposed to get out of it was that, when questions came up in an Estimates committee, certain matters referred to in the Estimates committee report would then be debated in the Committee of the Whole, which would lessen the debate in the Committee of the Whole, which sometimes gets up to 20, 30 or 40 hours. That worked only moderately the first time. The second time a new device was found: the Government was receiving letters saying, `I reserve my 167 questions' or, `I reserve my 1,432 questions'. They could all come up in the chamber and it totally subverted the intent of the reforms at the time. That is the problem. In my view, it is a breach of faith in some ways. I do not see how one can possibly solve the problem by restriction. I could think up various Standing Orders, but I know that the moment I think one up another device will be dodged through the back door. The only thing I can do-and I hope I never have to implement it-is threaten vengeance. The sacrifice I have to make to achieve that vengeance is to sit over that side and I do not intend to do so. If I do, Senator Kemp, and you are a Minister, you will pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just explain a few facts of life to Senator Ray. Quite frankly, we do not get responses to questions we have asked in Estimates committees on time.
—Every Defence question was answered and I still have questions in reserve.

—I am not talking about Defence; I am talking about my particular interests-community services, health and social security. We do not get the answers before the Committee of the Whole. If we do not get the answers or if we get them in a few minutes before the Committee of the Whole, how can we possibly decide whether there will be a need for further questioning? That is the first issue. The second issue-and I am sure this will happen to Senator Ray when he is in opposition; I am quite sure it will happen to him pretty soon-is that we get answers from the officers at the table and people who are interested in those responses say to us, `You were not told the truth. This, indeed, is what occurs and that officer diddled you'; or, `You did not go far enough with your question. He took you very literally and he did not give you the full answer. He did not say, ``Well, you are right, senator, actually, but had you asked this particular question I could have given you a different answer, had you just gone an inch further''.' For those reasons it is necessary for further debate in the Committee of the Whole. When one is given information by someone outside that one has been misinformed during the Estimates committee, either from the lack of a precise question that one should have asked to get the truthful answer or because of a frank lack of knowledge by the departmental officers-I am not saying deliberate lies; I am saying lack of knowledge, perhaps-it becomes necessary for one to defend one's position and to be able to reserve one's right to re-ask the question in the correct term and get the correct answer in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ray will enjoy that privilege when he is in opposition; he will be given the same sort of information that we are given, and that I have been given, and he will want the same sort of opportunity to question the Minister on the additional detail. I am prepared for the Minister to have that in a very short time. I am very happy for the Minister to have that, because we work in a different way on this side; we always have. During Estimates committees when we were in government-and Senator Ray can ask my friend Senator Kemp-the Ministers were questioned very closely by government senators because they often saw it as a way of questioning the bureaucrats on their incompetence and we had very constructive Estimates committees. That does not occur now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there then; I did not see any of that; that is a mythology.

—It is not a mythology. I can assure the Minister that it is not; the Minister should ask Senator Kemp, because at that stage he happened to be trying to defend his own Minister, and she was asked some very curly questions, and her departmental officers were asked--
—Who was that?
—The Minister should know if he was there.
—Senator Guilfoyle?

—Yes, Senator Guilfoyle. She was asked some very curly questions, as were her officers, by government senators. I assure the Minister that that is completely accurate. Now we sit in Estimates and the Labor senators never open their mouths. They never ask a question; they never open their mouths. The only question we get in our committee on community services and health is, `How many women have you employed?'-that is, all the feminist questions. We do not get any questions from the Government senators at all; it is a farce as far as the Labor side is concerned. Do not try to stop our questioning of the bureaucrats; do not try to stop our questioning in a proper fashion in the Committee of the Whole, because we like taking advantage of that. I would not for one minute deny Senator Ray that opportunity when he is in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of item (9), I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of this part of the report.

This is one I referred to the Committee to see whether the Committee wished to do anything with it; the Committee did not. We do not believe the circumstance will probably occur again, so it is just left.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That consideration of committee reports under standing order 62 take place on Thursdays, after the time for the consideration of General Business.

This motion has been around for some time, so I will have to regroup and think of some of the arguments. One of the things we did last session was to restructure sitting times essentially to say that in future we would have ministerial statements on a Thursday and would sit on the Thursday night of the second week. We also went to the Friday committee system. One of the suggestions that I brought forward was that the debate we went through today, the consideration of committee reports, should be held on a Thursday after the consideration of general business. To some extent, along with ministerial statements, that blocks out a long section of the parliament's proceedings, either to private business or business of the Senate, and gives Government business a better run on a Wednesday.

This matter has not been particularly discussed between the parties. It has been hanging around- I think I have put five notices of motion to put it off-and no-one seems to be enthused either to oppose it or support it. I would not be broken hearted if it did not get up, but I think it is more logical that committee reports be dealt with on a Thursday rather than on a Wednesday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the face of it, this is a small matter designed to try to improve Government opportunity and Government efficiency. We can understand the reason for that. It is proposed in the light of extending the Thursday sittings to 10.30 p.m. Therefore, on the one hand we understand the arguments in favour of it. It will give government a better run with legislation on the Wednesday.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that from an Opposition point of view-actually, from a senatorial point of view-there have been some concerns expressed among my colleagues which might be answerable. I will therefore raise them. There is a concern that the consideration of committee reports will potentially be squeezed off the list by either a ministerial statement which is introduced during the day on which there is debate or, alternatively, a ministerial response to a committee report. In other words, we are putting this aspect of committee reports further down the sitting week. We are taking pressure off the Government's program in the earlier part of the week, but as the pressure increases as the week continues, there is the danger that a squeeze will occur. It might be this aspect of business, which individual senators regard as very important, which suffers. We express those concerns. I think the sentiment in the chamber, following my brief discussion with the Australian Democrats, is that the change should be given a go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want me to make it till the end of this sitting?

—I would prefer that. It might well be that the concerns which have genuinely been put by some senators are not well founded, and I hope that is the case. I do not suggest for a moment that the Minister is suggesting this change in order to push off consideration of committee reports. He would also appreciate that senators regard this as an important function. But, if it was in place until the end of this sitting, we would have an opportunity to see how it worked. If it works without this extra stress occurring and inhibiting individual senators in their rights in this regard, then no doubt it could be easily extended.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator ROBERT RAY)-by leave-proposed:
That the following paragraph be added:
(2) That this order come into effect as from 21 February 1991.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to express my support for this proposal-generally, not from a Government point of view. I think it will be a sensible arrangement for the Opposition. It will allow the Opposition, which will benefit most from the change--
—Don't talk me out of it.

—I am trying to encourage honourable senators opposite. Private senators' business is made up of the various matters of general business dealing with consideration of committee reports and so forth. I would have thought it need not always be after the time for general business. It could be before or after, but it means that Thursday afternoons and evenings on both first and second sitting weeks would effectively be open to the non-government parties to determine how to administer it. If they wanted, on certain occasions, to give priority to consideration of committee reports, they could; if on other occasions they wanted to give priority to a general business Bill, then so be it. I think it is a useful consolidation of time.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to Senator Hill that there have been quite a number of Wednesdays over the years when honourable senators have not had the full hour on committee reports with the 7.30 adjournment because some other major matter has taken precedence. There is probably more chance of getting time for committee reports if they are dealt with on a Thursday.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Estimates committee groupings as agreed to by resolutions of the Senate of 9 and 10 May and 11 September 1990 be varied to move the Department of Community Services and Health and Department of Veterans' Affairs to Estimates Committee E and Department of Transport and Communications to Estimates Committee F.

The matter of workloads of Estimates committees was raised with me, both on my side of the chamber and, I think, by Senator Reid on behalf of the Opposition. It was pointed out especially that Estimates Committee C had an unfair workload compared with Estimates Committee F.

I immediately sent off a letter to Senator Reid suggesting a change. Senator Reid said that she would get back to me eventually. In the meantime, I think we have both lost that correspondence, because neither of us has been able to track it down.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, she has it.

—I am glad that she does have it. I think it reflects what I have just said, but if it does not, I will look at that letter. The proposal was that Estimates committee groupings as agreed by resolution in the Senate on 9 and 10 May and 11 September 1990 be varied to move the Department of Community Services and Health and the Department of Veterans' Affairs to Estimates Committee E and the Department of Transport and Communications to Estimates Committee F.

SPEECH.PARA: When looking at the hours that the Estimates committees sat, I can see that Estimates Committee C sat for 46 hours; compared with 20 hours for Estimates Committee B; 14 hours for Estimates Committee D; 17 hours for Estimates Committee E; and eight hours for Estimates Committee F. So I can see the reason for complaint. But no complaint has much relevance when we consider that Estimates Committee A sat for 60 hours and 14 minutes. That is a matter it can sort out for itself, as long as most of us are not on it. I think we would all agree with that. We will leave that Committee with it. One thing that I have to be conscious of at all times--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think you have the wrong correspondence.
—I do not have any correspondence.
—What you have lost, you have remembered inaccurately.

—I have not remembered anything; someone else has drawn this up based on what I think I said ages ago. Let us begin this debate tonight. If there is an alternative proposition that honourable senators want me to look at tomorrow, we might do so.

—There is still some concern, in particular about the proposal to divide Health and Community Services. There is a feeling that honourable senators who have a particular speciality in one part of that package tend to have it in the other as well. Under the amended program they would be divided-half of that would be moved to another group. We would appreciate the opportunity to discuss the matter further with the Government. We will make ourselves available tomorrow to do that if somebody on Senator Ray's behalf could do so. We would be pleased to resolve it tomorrow. We realise that Estimates are coming up and it has to be resolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I will make some comments relating to government funding-I should say taxpayer funding-of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). As part of the ACTU President's new year's message to Australia he was kind enough to inform the public:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACTU is part and parcel of the Government of Australia.

This will not surprise honourable senators on this side of the chamber. We have long argued that Bill Kelty is in fact a senior member of Mr Hawke's Cabinet. Undoubtedly, Senator Robert Ray could easily confirm that.

Mr Kelty of the ACTU wields a veto power over government policy. We, in this chamber, can all recall for example how Mr Keating's consumption tax proposal was vetoed by Mr Kelty. It is surprising that Mr Ferguson is prepared to openly inform the public of the fact that the ACTU and the Government are one and the same-indivisible, inseparable. This will certainly confirm the worst fears and suspicions of the public. They did not elect Mr Ferguson and Mr Kelty and the other ACTU functionaries to be part of the government of this country. They know that the influence of Mr Kelty and the ACTU is one of the major reasons that the reform process in this country has ground to a halt before it has in fact hardly started.

As an aside, one may reflect-drawing on Mr Ferguson's comments-on the fact that if the ACTU is part of the Government, where does that leave the ACTU when the Government falls? Presumably, the ACTU will not object to a greatly diminished role under a coalition government.

It is a good thing for the ACTU that the public did not have a chance to vote on whether they wanted the ACTU to be part of the Government. Opinion poll after opinion poll shows that the public believe that the trade union movement already has too much power. In fact, in a recent poll that has come to my attention over two-thirds of Australians, including a majority of trade union members, agree with the proposition that the trade unions have too much power.

The arrogance of the ACTU bosses has reached unprecedented levels. Last month we had the astonishing spectacle of Mr Ferguson demanding $10,000 from the organisers of the Australian open tennis championship if they wished to avoid the disruption of the championship. In most circles this type of behaviour would be regarded more akin to extortion or blackmail. We read in the press that the trade union bosses tried to censor a film made by Mr Tom Zubrycki on the history of the trade union movement entitled Amongst Equals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who paid for it?

—It was paid for by the taxpayers; it cost the taxpayers to the tune, I believe, of $200,000 to make a film about the glories of the trade union movement. According to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 15 January:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if Martin Ferguson . . . has his way, you will never see `Amongst Equals' as it was made. It will either be locked away in ACTU House in Melbourne or heavily edited-rewritten in other words.

Apparently Mr Ferguson and the former ACTU president, Mr Crean, now a Minister of this Government, did not like the reporting on the Robe River dispute and believed that the film did not pay sufficient attention to the prices and incomes accord. In most circles such behaviour by an individual to censor the work of an artist would be more typical of Ceausescu than a leader in a liberal democratic society. It is this type of arrogance, this lack of respect for proper proprieties and form, which has led the ACTU to place itself in a totally untenable position regarding the use of taxpayer funds.

During the last session I requested information from all departments on grants that they had made to the ACTU during the term of the Hawke Government. I am now in a position to report to the Senate on the answers that I have received from the Ministers of the Hawke Government. I stress that the figures I will be quoting for these grants were made only to the ACTU; they do not involve grants made to other sections of the trade movement section. Senator Short has detailed the huge extent of grants made by the Government from taxpayers' funds to the trade union movement generally. His research showed that the Hawke Government has provided over $25m to trade unions since it came into office. This includes some $7m in the current financial year.

The ACTU is the largest individual union recipient of these grants. Overall, the Hawke Government will make grants to the ACTU in the order of a huge $4m this financial year-this is $4m of my dollars, your dollars, Mr Acting Deputy President, and Senator Collins's dollars-the dollars of taxpayers given to the ACTU which, as Mr Ferguson tells us, is part and parcel of the Government.

It is interesting that the taxpayer pays more to the ACTU than do its affiliates. Perhaps the taxpayer feels more affectionate towards the ACTU than do its members. That is one inference that people could draw from these figures, but it is a most unlikely inference.

The ACTU's statement of income and expenditure shows that in 1987-the latest accounts which are available; I was able to obtain these accounts last week-the ACTU received $2.5m from affiliation fees. Just remember: the ACTU got $4m from the taxpayer and $2.5m in affiliation fees. Maybe in the current year the ACTU has been able to get more in affiliation fees; I could not find out. The contrasting figures we have before us are: $4m taxpayers' dollars and $2.5m affiliation fees from other trade unions. Since 1983, when it came into government, the Hawke Government has granted an incredible $11.6m to the ACTU.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two tables which summarise grants made by the Government to the ACTU. The first table relates to the current financial year and the second table summarises all published grants made from 1983.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This table excludes the $135,000 recently paid largely from taxpayers' funds by the Department of Social Security, the Drug Offensive Unit and the Commonwealth Bank-what the Commonwealth Bank is doing in this exercise I am not too sure-to sponsor an ACTU campaign being run in the Cleo magazine to boost union membership among working women. I will return to this issue presently.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be seen from the tables which have been incorporated in Hansard that significant grants have been made by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to the ACTU. I spoke in the Senate during last session about the improper use of taxpayers' money to promote trade union activities and policies. Australia already has a large variety of aid organisations doing some excellent work. There is no reason why the ACTU through its arm Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA) should be receiving vast amounts of taxpayers' funds to promote its goals. In the introduction to the APHEDA annual report, Martin Ferguson states that APHEDA is the ACTU's overseas aid arm. He says:
. . . using money donated by Australian trade unions and their members, it (APHEDA) is enabling them (people in developing countries) to lead productive lives . . .

Let us remember it is using money donated by the Australian trade unions and their members. There is no mention there by Mr Ferguson that of the $3.1m spent by APHEDA in 1990, 83 per cent came from the taxpayer. Cliff Dolan, Chairperson of APHEDA, in his statement in the APHEDA report, also fails to mention the huge contribution received from the taxpayer. Indeed, he says:
. . . the money available for worker training now reaches over $3 million.
He says that this is remarkable `especially considering the Government's decreased spending on overseas aid as a percentage of GDP'.

It has to be said that there is some irony here. Government spending on APHEDA has risen from $110,000 to over $2.4m in 1989-90, compared with the first year when the Hawke Government came into office. One has to continue through to the back of the APHEDA report before one finds those details.

Grants have been made by APHEDA to organisations such as the African National Congress, the Commonwealth Trade Union Council, South Pacific and Oceania Council of Trade Unions, and community radio in New Caledonia. Senator Harradine's dollars are being given to those organisations.

Over $120,000 is spent by APHEDA on what is described as development education. Taxpayers will be surprised to learn that this money does not go to aid overseas countries to assist in the alleviation of poverty, but for `educating Australian workers about the fundamental causes of third world poverty and injustice as well as APHEDA's role in helping to change the situation'.

Perhaps some of this money could be used to explain to Australian workers why they are now being thrown onto the dole queues and poverty as a result of the Government's recession-the recession, of course, we had to have. Some may think cynically that development education is just propaganda for APHEDA and the ACTU. I think they would be right. The report tells us that stories written by APHEDA's part time journalist in `all cases' have stressed that `APHEDA is the overseas aid agency of the ACTU. We believe this benefits the whole trade union movement'.

It is this type of statement which, naturally, will raise concerns. Money which is granted for overseas aid ends up helping to pay for a journalist in Australia whose work, among other things, has the effect of helping to promote the ACTU. How is it that money appropriated for overseas aid ends up promoting the ACTU? This is a matter to which the Auditor-General could turn his mind.

Does the APHEDA development education material which is being given to Australian unionists stress the vital role that free enterprise and democracy play in alleviating poverty and injustice? What does Senator Crowley think? Well, if a recent summary of their views on Vietnam are any indication, as contained in the APHEDA report of June 1990, APHEDA's development education program seems grossly inadequate. Given our own appalling industrial relations system, many people will regard with wry amusement the fact that Australian aid is being used, according to Senator Evans's answer to my question, to promote the establishment of sound labour relations in other countries. Certainly, they could give instruction on how unions can extract from the Government vast sums of taxpayers' dollars.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is only one of a number of departments which make substantial grants to the ACTU. We have learnt, for example, that in 1990-91 alone, over $170,000 is being paid to the ACTU, among other things, to help with union amalgamations. How is this money spent? Is there proper accountability? Many of the unions which are amalgamating have large memberships and substantial resources. For example, $70,000 has been granted to assist the amalgamation of the Waterside Workers Federation and Australian Foremen Stevedores Association. Senator Collins would know those two unions very well. Is it too much to ask Senator Collins whether these two well-resourced unions could have found the money to assist in their own rationalisation. Why did the taxpayer have to come in? Why the taxpayer should be forced to fund a reform which the unions believe to be to their own benefit is beyond belief. In my view it is a disgraceful use of taxpayer funding.

The ACTU has been able to obtain funds from other departments. For example, the Department of Employment, Education and Training provided $50,000 to the ACTU to employ a research officer to investigate the effects of award restructuring on women in the retail industry and the clerical occupations. It would be interesting to see that report.

The Department of Community Services and Health has been a huge contributor to the ACTU, providing over $650,000 during the term of the Hawke Government, including a sum of $80,000 in this year alone. Grants paid include money for a national child-care coordinator and production of booklets and leaflets relating to the HIV-AIDS issue. Unlike union amalgamations and grants to dubious overseas organisations, these may well be worthy activities but, as I shall suggest later, they may well be matters which the ACTU itself should be funding rather than relying on taxpayers, particularly in view of the fact that the ACTU seems to have a lot of money to spend on other activities.

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy plans to make grants totalling $75,000 to look at alternatives to logging in National Estate forests. Again, it will be interesting to see how that money is actually spent.

Senator Alston has recently detailed a number of astonishing grants made recently by various government organisations, including the Department of Social Security, to sponsor an advertising campaign to boost union membership. Of the $135,000 provided by the Government for this ACTU campaign, some $45,000 came from the Department of Social Security jobs, education and training (JET) scheme-a training program designed to get sole parents back into the work force.

How can it possibly be justified that money appropriated by this Parliament to assist sole parents ends up with the ACTU to promote union membership? As with the grants paid to APHEDA, it seems to me that the Auditor-General should investigate to ensure that this is a proper use of moneys appropriated by the Parliament. There are two issues here, of course. Has the money which has been appropriated been appropriated in a way which, effectively, represents the aims of the Parliament in appropriating the money? The second issue is how this money is actually spent on the ground?

There are two issues which I think this chamber should address itself to. First of all, it is clear that the trade union movement is not short of funds or assets. While the ACTU has been given over $11m of taxpayers' funds by the Hawke Government to carry out a variety of activities, some of which seem to have no particular relevance to the needs and interests of Australian workers, it apparently has funds available to purchase part of the Labor Party's headquarters in Canberra-John Curtin House.

It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald, for example, in November that the ALP was selling one-third of its share in John Curtin House. True to the policy of the Hawke Government which has allowed Australia to run up massive debts, the ALP is apparently in debt to the tune of $7m. This contribution by the ACTU in purchasing one-third of John Curtin House will help pay back these huge debts. We do not know how much the ACTU will be paying for its one-third share. I do not know; it has not been reported. That could possibly be revealed by Senator Collins, who is at the table, at the end of this adjournment debate. In view of the money which has been granted to the ACTU, it would be most interesting. We know from its published accounts that the ACTU has general reserves in the order of $1.7m.

Secondly, this purchase by the ACTU highlights the issue of propriety. It is apparent that the leadership of the ACTU is either too arrogant or too foolish to see the impossible position in which it has placed its organisation. The propriety I refer to is where, on the one hand, an organisation receives directly vast amounts of taxpayers' funds from the Labor Government for its activities and, on the other hand, is prepared to pay substantial amounts of money to the Labor Party either to assist in its re-election or to help fund its debts. On the one hand, the Labor Party giveth to the ACTU and, on the other hand, it receiveth. I can tell Senator Collins that there is an issue of propriety there.
Senator Collins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins cannot even see it. Let me go on and explain it to him. That is probably true; maybe Senator Collins cannot see the issue of propriety. It is, indeed, possible that Ministers in this Government cannot see that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Warwick Parer has indicated that in the last election the ACTU paid $150,000 in election expenditure. The Senate can be assured that this expenditure was designed to assist the re-election of the Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give you a list of some employers, in fact, and who they give their money to.

—Senator Collins should just give some answers to the questions I have raised. His response could be fascinating tonight. He could be on the front pages of all the newspapers. President Ferguson was uncharacteristically sensitive about Senator Parer's criticisms. He suggested that Senator Parer's criticism of the ACTU's election activities represented an attack on democratic rights of individuals and organisations to seek to influence politicians. It is, of course, no such thing.
—He said he might deal with me. What does that mean?
—They do make these threats. Senator Parer will notice that Senator Robert Ray tonight was inclined to make some threats. Senator Collins mumbled something under his breath.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Parer was arguing that it was an abuse by the Government to use taxpayers' funds to influence lobby groups which, in turn, campaigned on behalf of the Labor Party. Martin Ferguson has already told us that the ACTU is part and parcel of the Government of Australia; it is not an independent lobby group. No-one in this Parliament knows how effectively all the taxpayers' money that has been given to the ACTU is being spent including, I suspect, some Ministers.

In view of the very close links between the ACTU and the Government one would have thought that commonsense would have indicated that every action would be taken to ensure that not only are proprieties maintained, but also they are seen to be maintained. I believe, therefore, that no taxpayer funding should be given to the ACTU-none whatsoever. The ACTU is a huge organisation. How many members does it claim-three million? And it relies on $4m from the taxpayer to get it over the hurdle this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep smiling.

—I think members of the Labor Party find this amusing. I do not think the public will. Senator Crowley finds it amusing, but let me tell her that the public do not find it amusing at all. Certainly, funding that is now being given for a large variety of factors without any proper accountability should be abandoned as a matter of course.

SPEECH.PARA: In Martin Ferguson's words, the ACTU is part and parcel of the Government. I do not argue the issue with the President of the ACTU. He is absolutely right. The ACTU receives millions of dollars from the Labor Government, it campaigns on behalf of the Labor Party and is considering purchasing Labor Party headquarters. I, therefore, argue that it is an intolerable use of taxpayers' funds for the Labor Government to fund the activities of its partner in government.

I believe that the Auditor-General should be asked to examine how these grants, given by the Labor Government to the ACTU, are being spent so that we can be assured and, indeed, even the Minister can be assured that the Labor Party is not indirectly funding its own political activities through government grants. That would make us all happy-just to have that assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, H.R. Nicholls.

—That is a really telling attack. The relationship that this Government has with the ACTU highlights the fundamental problems of the corporate state which Labor has instituted. It relies totally on giving privileged positions to a powerful few who can and, as I have shown, do, use their positions to extract huge sums of money from the taxpayers to pursue their own private interests. Let us not fool ourselves. The payments I have mentioned are not made in the public interest, they are made to promote the private interests of the Government's powerful friends and, where practical, promote the Government. This marriage between the ACTU and the Hawke Government is not a marriage made in heaven, it is a marriage made at the expense of the Australian people and at the expense of proper proprieties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for calling me. I know I am not on the list tonight, but I came into the Senate because, by accident, I overhead some of the remarks that Senator Kemp was making. I promise to try to be very brief on this occasion. The reason I have come in to make a comment at all is that I think the speech we have just heard from Senator Kemp is probably one of the meanest and nastiest I have heard in this place.
—Well, he is pretty mean and nasty.
—The Minister will understand that I resisted the temptation to attribute such qualities to the speaker and addressed them only to the speech.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem I have with Senator Kemp, smiling and graceful as he was when he said all of that, was that he actually drew that dreadful tactic from the bottom drawer called smear by innuendo. He seems to know better the motives of all those people covered by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the board of the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad (APHEDA). I do not know if he knows, but I am actually on the board of APHEDA. I was on the board of APHEDA originally as a more senior member at its inauguration, and have been in continuous service ever since. I take strenuous objection to the implications in Senator Kemp's speech of what I or the board members of APHEDA are doing, firstly, in even implying that we do not know what we are doing and, secondly, that we are misappropriating taxpayers' money.

Senator Kemp's principal claim is that any tax dollars going to the ACTU are going in the wrong direction. That is a bold claim and totally indefensible. I object to it strenuously because he attaches to that implications of gross impropriety and wickedness on behalf of the ACTU. I would simply like to ask Senator Kemp whether he would care to defend at another time the amount of taxpayers' dollars that go to 1,001 organisations around this country, even those that enjoy tax concessions when people make contributions to charitable organisations, even those that are tax concessions through what are called legitimate claims by business against the cost of their exercise in industry.

Tax dollars are going into any number of organisations in this country. I blush not at all that this Government properly provides tax assistance, tax dollars, in a variety of ways to assist the work done by the ACTU. If Senator Kemp wants to suggest that it is unreasonable of the ACTU to be promoting unionism and not free enterprise, I would ask him whether private enterprise in this country promotes unionism while it is also promoting its own private enterprise. It is a farce and I am not prepared to spend too much time tonight debating farce. Senator Kemp's claim, through its implications and its innuendos, suggests gross impropriety by the ACTU and by the board of APHEDA. I simply mention those points to suggest that Senator Kemp's arguments would not hold up in grade 3 and they certainly do not hold up in this place. That is a matter of logic. Smiling as he goes does not make Senator Kemp's claims any more persuasive but just more palatable if the television camera is on him at the time.

As to the board of APHEDA, the remarkable thing about that organisation, and the reason that it has enjoyed assistance through the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) for its work, is that it is distinguished in kind in the work it has done in overseas places, many of which Senator Kemp presumably could list. Unlike Senator Kemp, I could not list them all without referring to a piece of paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are on the board; you should know.

—No, I do not hold all that detail in my memory, but I do know where to find it. The distinguishing feature of the ACTU, through its aid arm APHEDA, is that unionists teach their skills to people in other countries, particularly Third World countries, so that they can use them in their own countries. We do not take bricks and mortar; we do not take equipment; almost invariably, we teach the skills of the work force of Australia, offered in considerable generosity through the services of APHEDA, to members in the recipient organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the distinguishing character of APHEDA that needs to be acknowledged as well as, I am happy to say, the generosity of the ACTU through its great contribution to the administration of APHEDA. The initiatives for this came from the recognition of the work of the union movement, particularly that of Norway and Sweden, in the Middle East. The recognition of that type of foreign aid, if you like, was to distinguish it quite considerably from other aid organisations that are more in the business of providing bricks and mortar, food, clothing, equipment and so on. This organisation has always had as its priority to take the skills of a variety of qualified workers in this country-teachers, nurses, bricklayers, plumbers, electricians and so on-to countries where they are very welcomed and which have been able to cheerfully seek that service from us.

It is a matter of record that the AIDAB section of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has been very pleased to offer money but, as is the case with all of the recipients of AIDAB's concessions and grants, APHEDA meets strict requirements and its funding is no different from any other taxpayers' dollars going to any other aid organisations. I sincerely hope that Senator Kemp does not want to dismiss APHEDA and its claim on the tax generosity of the people in this country as apart from any other aid organisation that receives tax dollars. Senator Kemp's suggested proposal is outrageous. I find it outrageous and also utterly disappointing, showing, as it does, his complete lack of understanding of what distinguishes APHEDA and also his lack of understanding of the generosity of the ACTU in assisting it.

To this point very few people in this country have understood development education properly. Were Senator Kemp to inquire, he would know that the campaign for funding through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for development education in this country has come from-if not all-almost all aid organisations in this country. It is not just APHEDA that has money for development education; it is any number of aid organisations. If Senator Kemp wishes to make a wickedness out of this, he must sheet this claim home to World Vision of Australia, to Community Aid Abroad, and to the other very reputable aid organisations operating out of this country. Development education is something that is poorly understood and it is quite clear that we need to have funding to promote it and to extend the understanding in Australia of what development education is about.

Another point that Senator Kemp made in his grab bag of abuse by innuendo was to suggest that the ACTU should not have any involvement with taxpayers' dollars through the jobs, education and training scheme. Who does Senator Kemp suppose has been one of the large suppliers of training and education, employment opportunities and assistance in the training in this country? It took ages to negotiate with the trade union movement the proper way of providing training assistance so as to guarantee that the rights won by workers were not eroded. It would be very easy to slip in a training program to provide work at very reduced pay. That might even be something that people would eventually come to agree with. But the union movement said, `If you want to do that, you must talk to us so that we can guarantee the rights of those trainees to adequate training and to an adequate employment opportunity in a way that guarantees the rights of workers to award wages and conditions'. We cannot introduce a scheme that just undercuts everything for which the union movement has fought for a century. I believe we could say a century. I think that the Labor movement in this country is formally 100 years old. My colleagues might confirm that. I am not quite sure of the date of its inception; I think it is about that time.

As for the suggestion that the trade union movement should not have connections with government, the trade union movement actually gets its parliamentary representation through the Australian Labor Party. I make no apologies for that. I do not think that any unionists would either. It is precisely because, without their own representation, their rights and conditions were not adequately covered. Senator Kemp should check out the late nineteenth century; he should check out anything he likes about the history of how workers were denied their rights and access until a union movement was established and fought for and guaranteed those rights, which were never properly exercised until we had parliamentary representation for those workers' representatives.

With these comments, I simply serve notice that I will take Senator Kemp's speech and read it very closely in case more points of fact should be made to this Senate about the organisation APHEDA. I am very disappointed to have to take issue with Senator Kemp in this place so early in his parliamentary career when he has succumbed to the temptation of arguing by innuendo instead of sticking to facts. He did not resist the temptation to attribute motive or draw his own conclusions from those facts. He argued his points only by ascribing evil motive or poor intent to the ACTU, to the union movement, to those thousands of workers and aid workers in this country. It is a disgrace and a shame-a blot on Senator Kemp's character. As I say, I will examine his speech very closely. If anything further needs to be said about it, he can be assured that he will be hearing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment briefly on the preparedness of the Federal Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) to participate in the Family Law Act inquiry which originally, on a motion by Senator Brownhill, was planned as a joint select committee. Like Senator Brownhill's welcome, mine is not entirely unqualified. I believe that the Federal Attorney-General should be requested to ensure that no delays occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference have now been agreed upon between the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for the earlier proposed Senate inquiry. I wish to put on record that we will not allow the Attorney-General to delay proceedings or to water down the terms of reference. It is entirely urgent that the terms of reference are drawn wide enough to cover all the concerns that have been expressed by people who have gone through a very traumatic stage in their lives. In particular, I wish to put on record the matters I have been able to negotiate with Senator Brownhill to ensure that some of these concerns are covered.

One of the concerns is the inclusion of previous reports by the Family Law Council, the Law Reform Commission and the Australian Institute of Family Studies. It is important that we do not reinvent the wheel but that we make use of the quite extensive reports and inquiries that have been carried out recently and which are germane to the matters which will be before the committee of inquiry.

Further, it is important to look at the current procedures and staffing of the Family Court of Australia as well as the legal costs imposed on parties in proceedings before the court. These are not matters that are, in their entirety, covered by legislation, but they are matters which are of extreme importance to people who have to deal with the Family Court and they must be handled by that committee. In addition, it is essential to examine the extent to which the adversarial procedures of our legal system are used by the Family Court and lawyers-perhaps more so by lawyers than by the court itself-to create and intensify conflict. This may well be a jurisdiction where the adversarial system should be modified in the interests of the parties that appear before the Court.

Finally, and most importantly, I believe the inquiry must address alternative means of dispute resolution and must address the funding for mediation, counselling and legal aid services. I believe it is important that these matters, having gone that far, are included in the terms of reference so they can be addressed by the committee of inquiry to be established. I trust that the Attorney-General will accept these and other matters that are currently part of the draft terms of reference and look forward to the establishment of the committee of inquiry at a very early date, within weeks.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 23 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister ensure that there will be a comprehensive and open investigation into the recent incident on Elcho Island in the Northern Territory in which an Aboriginal man was shot by police?
(2) Is the Government concerned that the shooting of David Gundy in Redfern and this incident may jeopardise successful negotiations concerning an instrument of reconciliation with Aboriginal people?
(3) Considering that police forces are under control of State and Territory Governments, in what way is the Federal Government going to exercise control over police forces in these matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following response to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A coronial inquiry into the death of an Aboriginal man who was shot and killed, during police action, on Elcho Island is in progress. The Coroner has conducted two sittings in Elcho Island and the inquiry will resume on 21 January 1991 in Darwin. No separate inquiry is proposed by the Commonwealth at this time.

(2) The tragic shooting of David Gundy is a matter of concern to this Government. The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody is currently holding an inquiry into his death. Separately proposals are currently being developed for a process of reconciliation between indigenous Australians and the wider community.

(3) State Governments are responsible for the operational control of their police forces. Wider policy issues concerning policing methods are matters which have been considered by the Police Ministers' Council. The Council continues to keep abreast of progress with implementation of the Royal Commission's report. A final report is due following completion of the Gundy matter in March 1991. The Police Ministers' Council will be briefed on that report.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 July 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government consider lead poisoning to be a problem in Australia; if so (a) how is it currently being diagnosed; (b) what is the most common cause; (c) how is it treated; and (d) what payment arrangements exist for such treatment, for example, is it covered by Medicare or private health insurance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am advised that hospital morbidity data collected by the Australian Institute of Health (from all States and Territories except Tasmania) indicate about 40 cases of lead poisoning result in admission to a public hospital each year. On the basis of this data, lead poisoning could not be considered a major cause of clinical morbidity in Australia.

Low level chronic exposure, particularly of children, continues to be an issue of public health concern. The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&RC) has determined that blood-lead levels in excess of 25 micrograms per decilitre (25ug/dL) are a matter of public health concern. Recent studies have shown that a significant proportion of children (8% of children in the 1990 Wollongong Lead Study and 7% in the 1983 `Study of Lead Exposure, Lead Absorption and Lead Toxicity in Children of Port Pirie') have blood levels above this recommended level of concern. The significance of this is now the subject of a long-term study of environmental lead exposure and early childhood development in Port Pirie, funded by the NH&RC and scheduled for completion in late 1991. Early results from this, and comparable studies overseas, indicate that marginal impairments of neuropsychological development can result from the sorts of environmental exposure levels that can occur within industrially exposed and densely settled urban populations.

The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission has published a discussion paper on the control and safe use of lead at work (July 1990) which included detail of a survey sample of occupationally exposed workers. This sample included 32 females. Blood-lead tests of 3137 of these workers, in June 1988, indicated a range of concentrations, with some 69.5% of subjects having blood-lead levels greater than 29ug/dL.

(a) To diagnose lead poisoning, a full history and examination for clinical signs (for example, neurological symptoms) would initially be undertaken in a patient suspected of exposure to lead. Diagnostic tests are described in standard medical reference texts, such as ``Medical Toxicology-Diagnosis and Treatment of Human Poisoning'' (Ellenhorn and Barceloux, 1988).

(b) Lead poisoning may result from occupational, non-occupational, environmental or intentional exposure. Common causes of lead poisoning are occupational and environmental exposure during lead smelting operations and industrial processes such as battery manufacture; eating from unfired or lead-glazed pottery; ingestion of lead-containing paint flakes and lead sinkers; motor vehicle exhausts from leaded petrol; and sniffing leaded petrol.

(c) In lead exposed workers, the treatment is removal from exposure and keeping the patient active. In cases where blood-lead levels are considered clinically important, treatment may include the removal of lead from the body by chelation therapy. This type of therapy is more common in cases of acute poisoning in children.

(d) Medicare benefits are payable for services listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule where rendered by qualified medical practitioners. While there is no specific item in the Schedule to cover treatment of lead poisoning, services rendered in conjunction with treatment, that is attendances at which treatment is given, pathology services, etc, would attract benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 10 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's department or any agency for which the Minister is responsible entered into any contracts with Gary Morgan's company, Roy Morgan Research Centre, since 1975; if so, for each contract since 1975:

(b) what was the fee;
(c) was the contract put out to tender; if so, why was Roy Morgan Research Centre chosen; if not, why not, and why was the Centre chosen;
(d) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to supply a copy of the questionnaire;
(e) did the Centre supply a copy of the full questionnaire used to conduct the survey; if so, please provide a copy of the full questionnaire;

(f) if a part only of the questionnaire was supplied, was the Minister's department or agency aware of the exact nature of the full questionnaire; if not, why not, and what safeguards were taken to ensure there was no conflict of interest or subject bias;
(g) were there any questions asked by the Centre which were not included in the report supplied by the Centre; if so, what were they;
(h) please provide a copy of the Centre's report;

(i) if, for whatever reason, the Minister's department or agency will not provide a copy of the report, please provide an outline of its contents and an explanation as to why the Minister's department or agency refuses to provide a copy;

(j) was the Centre specifically asked by the Minister's department or agency to provide a computer printout of the survey; if so, did the Centre provide an interpretation of the survey results; if not, what special skills and qualifications does the Minister's department or agency have in the interpretation of attitudinal survey data and please provide an outline of how the survey data was interpreted;
(k) how were the survey results used by the Minister's department or agency; and
(l) did the proposal to commission the survey emanate from within the Minister's department or agency or from within the Minister's office or another department or agency.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Sport and Recreation

The Sport and Recreation Branch of the Department entered into 6 contracts with the Roy Morgan Research Centre between June 1984 and June 1987 for the conduct of research into the physical activity levels of Australians. Questions were included in the Centre's weekly national Consumer Opinion Trend omnibus survey.
Answers in relation to the points raised are:

(a) Yes. The contracts followed the recommended standard Departmental format of the time. Contract specifications included the scope of the project, employment of personnel, release and indemnity provisions, ownership of project material, termination conditions, applicable contract law, terms of payment and address for service of notices. The specifications were not altered after signing. The work was able to be performed as agreed.

(c) The initial survey was put out to tender. Subsequent surveys were undertaken by The Morgan Centre to ensure continuity of data collection procedures, analysis and reporting. The contract(s) was awarded on the basis of expertise, experience, methodology and value for money.
(d) The Department provided the questions to the Centre for inclusion in the omnibus survey. A copy of the regular baseline questions was supplied to the Department by the Centre.
(e) No. Refer to (f). A copy of the Department's questions is available on request.

(f) No. The exact nature of the full questionnaire used by the Centre in each week that the Department's questions were included in the omnibus survey could not be known due to reasons of commercial confidence. The subject matter of the Department's survey required no additional safeguards beyond the standard commercial arrangements between business clients.

(g) Yes. Of the baseline Consumer Opinion Trend questions, some questions relating to aspects of employment, home ownership, style of house, ownership of TVs or VCRs, electoral enrolment and religion were not relevant to the activity levels survey and were not included in the report. Questions inserted in the same Consumer Opinion Trend Survey by other clients were not reported.
(h) See (i).

(i) The 6 reports submitted by the Centre are some 200 pages each and contain tables of data and interpretations on aspects of physical activity such as frequency, duration, intensity, location of activity and reasons for non-participation, cross tabulated against sociodemographic factors such as age, income, employment/occupation and location. The cost of reproducing the volumes is not considered to be justified. However, a copy of the reports can be made available for inspection if requested.
(j) Yes. Yes. Additional interpretation was undertaken by appropriately qualified officers of the Department. The analysis did not involve interpretation of attitudinal data.

(k) An information paper outlining salient results was distributed widely throughout the sport and recreation field. A series of information sheets on particular aspects of the data was also produced and distributed widely. Following the conclusion of the six surveys, data was combined and aspects published in the booklet ``Physical Activity Levels of Australians'' in 1988. The data also assisted in the planning of program initiatives and the monitoring of changes in activity patterns over time.
(l) The proposal for the conduct of the surveys emanated from the Department.
(2) National Australia Day Council
This portfolio has had responsibility for the National Australia Day Council since 1984.

The Roy Morgan Research Centre conducted market surveys during the period 1983 to 1985 to assess the nature of community awareness of Australia Day and the nature and extent of participation in Australia Day activities.

Information relating to these surveys has been archived and is not readily available. The resources required to research and compile the information required to answer this part of the question cannot be justified.
(3) Office of Government Information and Advertising
Yes, the Office of Government Information and Advertising (OGIA) has entered into one contract with the Roy Morgan Research Centre since the Office was created in 1982.
Prices and Income Accord (December 1983-August 1984)

(a) No, there was no specific contract. The Centre was commissioned to include seven questions in their nationwide omnibus survey in December 1983, to help design the advertising campaign on the Prices and Income Accord. The Centre was then commissioned to conduct a further two surveys, in July and August 1984, to monitor any changes in community awareness of the Accord after the start of the advertising campaign.

For the July survey, the Centre was commissioned to include twelve questions in their nationwide omnibus survey. Seven questions were the same as those asked in the December survey, while the other five questions were related to the community's perception of the effectiveness of the Accord.

For the August survey, the Centre was commissioned to include fifteen questions in their nationwide omnibus survey. Twelve of the questions were the same as those asked in the July survey, while the other three questions were related to the advertising campaign for the Accord.
(b) First survey (December 1983)...$2,440
Second survey (July 1984)...$4,450
Third survey (August 1984)...$5,740

(c) No. Research was needed to direct a campaign publicising the Accord and the Centre was commissioned to include questions on the Accord in their nationwide omnibus survey. No other omnibus surveys were able to include the questions at the time required.
The other two surveys were a continuation of the earlier research.
(d) No.
(e) No.

(f) The surveys were omnibus or shared cost surveys, and the Centre only provided a copy of that part of the questionnaire which contained the questions OGIA commissioned. The Centre did not provide a full copy of the questionnaire as it contained questions commissioned by other organisations, and these are considered confidential to the organisations placing them.

The Centre is a member of the European Society for Opinion and Marketing Research (ESOMAR) and is bound by that organisation's code of professional behaviour. The department relied on the professionalism and integrity of the Centre's staff to ensure there was no conflict of interest or subject bias between the subjects addressed in the questionnaire.

(g) Yes, as it was an omnibus or shared cost survey. It is also likely that some questions were asked not related to the subject to provide demographic data (such as age, marital status, income, education etc) to ensure that samples were statistically representative.
(h) Copies of the tables, an overview by the Centre and an internal summary will be made available on request.
(i) See above.
(j) No. The Centre provided OGIA with an interpretation of the survey results.

(k) The results of the first survey were used to help design the advertising campaign on the Accord. The other two surveys were used to monitor the effect of the advertising campaign on the community's level of awareness and understanding of the Accord. They were also used to assess whether further awareness raising activities were needed.

(l) The Office of Government Information and Advertising decided to undertake the market research to help design the advertising campaign for the Accord and then to monitor the community's level of awareness of the Accord both during and after the campaign.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 11 October 1990:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the oestrogen patch `Estraderm' be available on the Australian market for use by Australian women requiring that treatment.

(2) Has the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee asked for additional clinical trials for the drug which are above and beyond those requested by the 31 countries, including the USA and New Zealand, which have already approved the drug's use.

(3) Can Australian women needing hormone replacement therapy but unable to take hormone replacements orally have the oestrogen patch prescribed in Australia and dispensed in New Zealand for delivery back to Australia.
(4) Can the oestrogen patch be supplied on special application to the department; if so, what criteria are laid down for the supply of the patch.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)-(4) The `Estraderm' patch, that is designed to be applied to the skin and deliver a predetermined dose of oestradiol, the most active of the naturally occurring female oestrogen hormones, has been considered by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC) on seven occasions since December 1988.

The sponsor company, Ciba-Geigy, has so far been unable to answer ADEC's concerns about the safety and efficacy of the product. A recent resubmission from the company has been evaluated but will not be considered by ADEC until February as the company has requested more time for the pre-ADEC consultation process.
ADEC has not asked for additional clinical trials above and beyond these requested by the countries which have approved a version of the drug for use.

However, as the patches used in clinical studies and marketed in certain countries, such as the USA, are not clearly the same as those proposed for Australian women, ADEC has insisted that the company unequivocally identify which trials have used the patch for use in Australia. Variations in drug delivery associated with the different delivery systems may result in an altered safety and efficacy profile.
Since the use of oestrogen can be associated with cancer of the womb and other severe adverse reactions, establishing the safety of the Australian drug delivery system is essential.

However, if a woman is in serious need of hormone replacement therapy and is unable to tolerate the other alternate forms of oestrogen available on the Australian market (oral tablets, subdermal (under the skin) implants, injections and topical creams and gels for vaginal use), then permission for supply of patches can be given under the department's Individual Patient Usage (IPU) Scheme.

The only other way an unmarketed product, for which there are alternate available forms, can be used in Australia is in the context of a clinical trial. However, the sponsor company has not expressed an interest in this option.
A patient would not be allowed to personally import the product without IPU approval.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1990:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand the honourable senator to be referring to the Standing Subcommittee on Intercountry Adoption of the Council of Social Welfare Administrators. The organisation described as ICA is formally known as the Australian Inter Country Adoption Network (AICAN). Neither AICAN nor any other adoptive parent group is a member of the Standing Subcommittee. The membership of the Subcommittee is comprised of Commonwealth officials from the Departments of Foreign Affairs and Trade and Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and State and Territory officials from Departments responsible for child welfare.
The views of adoptive parent groups are presented to the Subcommittee through its State and Territory members who undertake close and continuing consultations with adoptive parent groups.
