ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Joint Committee of Public Accounts: Review of Defence Project Management

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Of the 68 recommendations detailed in the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts (JPCPA) Review of Defence Project Management (Report 243, 1986):
(a) how many have been implemented and with what result?
(b) how many have not been implemented and why these have not been implemented?; and
(c) how many no longer remain relevant to Defence project management and why are they no longer relevant?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Of the 68 recommendations 56 have been implemented. Both before and after the JPCPA inquiry a number of measures were implemented by the Department of Defence to improve the overall level of efficiency, effectiveness and resources management in the area of project management. In particular the creation of the Capital Procurement Organisation in June 1984 (subsequently re-organised into the Acquisition and Logistics Organisation in 1989) brought together into one organisation, those Departmental elements responsible for the bringing into service of approved major capital equipment and those elements responsible for financial programming and budgeting, procurement policy and procedures, and the industry policy and involvement program. The implementation of these measures has resulted in:
(i) more efficient project management and cost control measures being exercised over the overall major capital equipment program;

(ii) the establishment of clearer lines of responsibility, in particular the devolution of greater authority and independence to the Assistant Chiefs of Staff-Materiel and to project managers, to give more autonomy in the management of individual capital equipment projects;

(iii) the development and promulgation of a Capital Equipment Procurement Manual which provides procedural guidance on Government and Defence policies, including procurement and industry policy, financial management statutory requirements, procurement and contracting matters; and
(iv) enhanced training and professionalism in Defence project management.
(b) Three (3) recommendations (Nos 8, 15 and 60) were accepted in varying degree, but not fully implemented. The current situation against each of these recommendations is as follows:

(i) Recommendation 8: Major Equipment Submissions are considered for project approval following extended internal Defence review. The key issues of capability, cost, risk, timing, likely industry involvement and support arrangements are considered in this process. However, it is not always appropriate to seek from industry tender quality costs in advance of Government approval. For the same reason, complete equipment support requirements will not always be available at that stage. These matters are refined further before contract award. An endorsed Equipment Acquisition Strategy (EAS) is required, however, prior to seeking project approval.

(ii) Recommendation 15: While no specific study as proposed has been carried out, the use of computerised project management tools has been extended considerably in Defence in recent years, eg. in project management techniques and packages for networking and resource management. Some of this has involved computer simulation modelling.

(iii) Recommendation 60: This matter is continually under review with the aim of reducing reliance on overseas courses as Australian course options become available. The effectiveness of the courses at Australian tertiary institutions such as USQ and ADFA is being examined. Some overseas post graduate courses that are unavailable in Australia are still required (eg advanced Integrated Logistic Support course elements such as Logistic Engineering). Some experience of overseas management systems and practices is achieved through overseas courses and personnel exchange programs.

(c) The remaining nine (9) recommendations (Nos. 2, 4a, 7, 11, 27, 35, 61, 67 &68) of JPCPA Report 243 have not been accepted or are not relevant. The reasons why these recommendations were not accepted or are not relevant are as follows:

(i) Recommendation 2: Staff Targets no longer exist. They have been replaced by Defence Force Capability Proposals under new arrangements which give sponsorship of proposals to HQADF. These proposals describe the function and desired performance of an equipment or system as a basis for determining, among other things, estimates of costs. The proposals are then developed in greater detail as Major Equipment Submissions for review by the Force Structure Policy and Programming Committee; these submissions must address project cost and through-life costs in detail.

(ii) Recommendation 4a: Close relations are maintained between the A& Organisation and the project sponsor, but placing sole responsibility for progress of a project through the FYDP with A& staff would put unacceptable emphasis on procurement aspects at the expense of force development and force structure aspects.

(iii) Recommendation 7: Staff Objectives, Staff Targets and Staff Requirements no longer exist as such in the development process for Capability Proposals. However, Project Definition Studies themselves now form an important element in the development and refinement of many capability proposals.

(iv) Recommendation 11: A costing section was established within the Capital Procurement Organisation (CPO) in 1987, but following the reorganisation of the CPO in 1988, its functions were subsumed in the work of a section with broader responsibilities. Because of the rate at which new technology and capabilities are incorporated in military equipment, the resources required to maintain reliable equipment cost databases are extensive and it is now considered preferable to obtain information on project costs from contractors, project definition studies and overseas Defence organisations.

(v) Recommendation 27: It is not practicable for contracts to list all conceivable events which might cause contract delay outside the contractor's control. The current pro-forma contract in DEFPUR101 is considered to provide an effective but necessarily flexible clause.

(vi) Recommendation 35: Compliance with appropriate Australian standards is expected of local suppliers of items of major equipment but complete insistence may in some areas involve unjustifiable costs.

(vii) Recommendation 61: The PSC has devolved career development responsibilities to individual departments and it was not relevant to pursue this with them. Development of civilian project management personnel is facilitated by mobility of staff between core and project branches thereby widening the relevant experience of officers. The project pool is a key mechanism in this regard. Additionally, a new system (CIVTRACK) is being piloted to identify training and career development needs for staff including project management staff. Individual branches are also developing staff training plans. The recently instituted Departmental senior officer performance appraisal process will include discussion and guidance on the individual's career development in the project management career path; it will also provide an avenue for ensuring that A& managers give priority to training and development of their staff.

(viii) Recommendation 67: The JPCPA considerations were conducted prior to the implementation of Program Management and Budgeting (PMB). In keeping with the criteria of PMB and the emphasis on reporting achievements against clearly defined goals and objectives, the information made available to the Parliament and public is now more comprehensive than in 1984-86. In such reports there has been a significant increase in the amount of information made available through Program Statements and the Defence Report. Whilst it is possible to provide information against specific requests, the provision of the full range of information sought against all projects would have significant resource implications.

(ix) Recommendation 68: Audit involvement in Defence major projects has been substantially increased since the JPCPA review. The Department's Management Audit Branch has increased resources and priorities allocated to its examination of major projects. A separate Directorate within the Branch is now responsible for acquisition and logistics matters with particular emphasis on capital acquisition. Outside consultants have assisted with the development of new audit methodologies in the capital acquisition area and a new audit manual reflecting contemporary audit practices in relation to large capital acquisition projects has been produced. Copies of this manual have been provided to the Australian National Audit Office (ANAO). The Department meets regularly with the Australian National Audit Office to review audit activities generally and the Management Audit Branch's annual report to the Defence Audit Policy Committee is provided to the ANAO. These initiatives have substantially improved the oversight of major projects both within Defence and the ANAO.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is it taking so long for the Government to respond to the report on the Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners, made available to the Government in October 1989.
(2) When will the Government be responding to the recommendations of the report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government gave preliminary consideration to the report of the Inquiry into the Needs of Australian Mariners, Commonwealth and Allied Veterans and Allied Mariners during the Budget session.
Two of the matters raised in the report's recommendations were dealt with at that time, namely:
* compensation for Australian mariners interned in Nazi Concentration Camps; and
* the adoption of a medals-based approach to determining Qualifying Service for service pension purposes.
The Government accepted both of these recommendations.
(2) It is intended that the remaining recommendations will be addressed when Government business permits.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: The Home Show

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 27 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it correct that the ABC does not cover the production and screening costs of `The Home Show' program entirely out of its own resources and that some of the costs are met by contributions in kind or in cash made by persons, companies or organisations associated with the home building industry; if so, would the Minister provide an itemised list showing the value and the donors of such contributions.
(2) If such contributions were received would they be likely to jeopardise the editorial independence of the ABC.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The program is a co-production involving three parties. One of the co-producers, Famous Artists International, obtained $350 000 to fund its one-third share of the production budget from the Housing Industry Association.
(2) No. Editorial content is judged by the ABC solely on its merits. The ABC imposes two safeguards to ensure its editorial independence is maintained, as follows:
(a) All co-producers are required to take into account the ABC's editorial guidelines particularly in relation to funding from outside the ABC; and

(b) The ABC maintains total editorial control over all product that is broadcast and is therefore in a position to make an assessment of the editorial content, and to require deletions or inclusions as it sees fit.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the value of imports of light aircraft into Australia in 1989-90.
(2) What was the corresponding value of imports in the previous financial year.
(3) What level of wholesale sales tax is levied on light aircraft sold in Australia.
(4) What other taxes, if any, are levied on sales of light aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A `light aircraft' category does not exist for import statistics. The closest category to light aircraft is `imports of aeroplanes and other aircraft (excluding helicopters and non powered aircraft) of unladen weight not exceeding 2,000 kilograms.'
Imports of aircraft in this category into Australia were valued at $17.3 million in 1989-90.
(2) Imports for this category were valued at $34.4 million in 1988-89.

(3) All aircraft other than gliders (including motorised gliders, hang gliders and motorised hang gliders) are exempt from sales tax. The exemption also applies to equipment and parts for aircraft, and materials (other than lubricants) used in the construction or repair of aircraft. The relevant exemption provision is item 119a (1) in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

(4) Although the income tax provisions would apply to income derived from the sale of all goods and services, including the sale of light aircraft, there are no other Commonwealth taxes applying specifically to light aircraft. Light aircraft are also imported duty free.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the holders of Commonwealth home loan mortgages, proposed to be sold in accordance with the recommendations of the Task Force on Asset Sales, be subject to any increase in costs associated with the administration of their mortgages; if so, what will be the additional costs.
(2) What are the guidelines which will be used by the Department of Finance to determine the successful purchaser of the mortgages.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Following the Minister for Finance's announcement of 6 December 1990 these mortgages have been sold to the ANZ Bank.
The ANZ Bank does not levy any mortgage management charges on its own home loans portfolio and it does not intend to do so for these mortgages, either.

Financial Institutions Duty (FID) will, however, be applied to the relevant loan accounts in future. For the average mortgage holder, this would equate to an estimated seven (7) cents a month for the life of his/her mortgage. This is a Territory tax and its application is at the discretion of the ACT Government.
(2) The main guidelines used by the Task Force were as follows:

* Prospective purchasers were invited to submit offers to acquire the mortgage portfolio on the basis that the mortgagors would not be adversely affected as a consequence of the sale and that the administration of the mortgages in future would be conducted in a manner consistent with industry standards; and
* The relevant attractiveness to the Commonwealth, on both financial and other grounds, of the offers to purchase submitted by prospective purchasers in the sale process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 29 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Government taken any steps to ensure that budgetary allocations to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for hospital services are directed exclusively to the care of veterans and are not used to finance those patients who might more reasonably be expected to be treated under separate Medicare arrangements; if not, does the Government intend to take such steps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Hospital care for entitled veterans and war widows is provided through the repatriation hospitals and by agreement with other institutions-public and private. Health care at the expense of the DVA for the general public is available only at repatriation hospitals, in certain circumstances.

Repatriation General Hospitals are modern acute care hospitals. Maintenance of medical and related skills requires their staff to have access to variety of patient mix and medical conditions. Since 1971 therefore, it has been recognised by successive Commonwealth Governments that the continuing viability of repatriation hospitals requires a proportion of community patients to be treated.
The budgetary allocations to the Department of Veterans' Affairs for hospital treatment recognise this reality and are therefore not intended for exclusive benefit of veterans.

As noted in the Budget papers, the allocations are made for payment to the relevant repatriation hospital operations trust accounts. The purpose of the trust accounts, one of which exists for each hospital, is simply to fund that hospital's operations. It follows therefore that the allocations are intended to cover all activity in which the hospitals can legitimately engage.

The authority under which the Repatriation Commission operates the hospitals is contained in section 89 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. That section, in conjunction with Sections 85 and 86, also establishes their primary responsibility as the treatment of eligible veterans and eligible dependants. Section 87 extends the hospitals' treatment coverage to other veterans while Section 88 enables treatment of members of the wider community; provided in both cases that the treatment of the primary groups of eligible veterans and dependants is not adversely affected.
Because of veterans' preferences to be treated elsewhere, community patient numbers in some repatriation hospitals are at high levels.
The facts which must be faced are:
* It is impracticable to effectively operate the Repatriation General Hospitals without community patients.

* Responsibility for community patient care is a matter for the States and not for the Repatriation Commission and the Repatriation Hospitals. The States cannot be compelled to pay for community patients in Repatriation Hospitals.

* It is not in the best interest of veterans and war widows to continue to be compelled to attend the Repatriation Hospitals to keep them viable. It is in their interest to have the Repatriation Private Health Scheme which gives them greater flexibility for the choice of doctor, specialist and hospital.
* There is no alternative to hospital integration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 29 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many ex-servicemen from the British Nuclear Testing Program of the 1950s and 1960s, conducted at Monte Bello Islands off Western Australia, and Emu Ridge and Maralinga, South Australia, are surviving.

(2) (a) How many ex-servicemen have taken action against the Commonwealth claiming damages or compensation in relation to their participation in this program; (b) how many have been successful; and (c) how many still have cases pending.

(3) How many ex-servicemen qualify for compensation as a result of the Federal Government's recognition of two cancers, multiple myeloma and leukaemia (other than the chronic lymphatic type), as arising out of exposure to radiation and/or fallout during the nuclear testing program.

(4) Have any estimates been made of the number of veterans who would qualify for compensation if the following cancers were also recognised as having been incurred in, or aggravated during, participation in the program: (a) cancer of the thyroid; (b) cancer of the breast; (c) cancer of the pharnyx; (d) cancer of the esophagus; (e) cancer of the stomach; (f) cancer of the small intestine; (g) cancer of the pancreas; (h) lymphomas (except Hodgkin's disease); (i) cancer of the bile ducts; (j) cancer of the gall bladder; and (k) primary liver cancer; if so, what are they; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Approximately 6,400 Australian servicemen were involved in the British Atomic Tests Program in Australia. Separate figures on the mortality amongst ex-servicemen who participated in the Tests Program are not recorded. The only figures available are those obtained in 1982/83 for the Commonwealth Department of Health following a survey of the health of Australian personnel who took part in the Tests Program. The Report of that study, entitled ``Health of Atomic Test Personnel'' records that at the end of 1982 five hundred and thirty-four ex-servicemen were confirmed dead, although the cause of death is not recorded.

(2) (a) 57 common law actions have been initiated against the Commonwealth by ex-servicemen or the widows of ex-servicemen. 269 claims for compensation have been lodged by ex-servicemen or the widows of ex-servicemen under the Commonwealth's compensation legislation. Q 358(3) deals with those ex-servicemen who qualify for compensation under a Special Administrative Scheme for Test participants who have multiple myeloma or leukaemia (other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia) as well as the dependants of such participants.

(b) One common law action has been successful, the jury awarding the plaintiff $679,500 in damages. Under the provisions of the Commonwealth's compensation legislation, 26 claims have been successful. Q 358(3) deals with those ex-servicemen who have qualified for compensation under a Special Administrative Scheme for Test participants who have multiple myeloma or leukaemia (other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia) as well as the dependants of such participants.

(c) Of the 57 common law actions initiated against the Commonwealth by ex-servicemen, 54 are still pending (two actions have been withdrawn and the other action is referred to in paragraph (b) above). Under the Commonwealth's compensation legislation, one claim is yet to be determined. Q 358(3) deals with those claims by ex-servicemen who have applied for compensation under a Special Administrative Scheme for Test participants who have multiple myeloma or leukaemia (other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia) as well as the dependants of such participants.

(3) Any ex-servicemen who participated in the Atomic Tests Program who have multiple myeloma or leukaemia (other than chronic lymphatic leukaemia) as well as the dependants of such participants are eligible to apply for compensation under a Special Administrative Scheme which was established by the Government in September 1989. Each case is considered on its merits.

To date twelve claims by ex-servicemen or the dependants of ex-servicemen have been considered under this Special Administrative Scheme. Of these twelve claims, four have been successful and four have been disallowed. Of the remaining four claims, three had previously been accepted under the Commonwealth's compensation legislation, and one under the Commonwealth's repatriation legislation.

(4) No estimates are available of the number of ex-servicemen who have (or have died from) the eleven cancer conditions specified and there are no plans to undertake any studies to determine the incidence of these particular conditions amongst ex-servicemen who participated in that program.
Epidemiological studies that have been undertaken do not show a causal link between exposure to ionising radiation and the development of these cancers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of the incidence of direct mailing of advertising material from the United States and Canada; if so, can anything be done to prevent the continuation of this practice.
(2) What protection exists for Australian consumers who purchase items from direct mail vendors overseas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While I am aware that direct mail advertising originating from North America is being sent to Australian consumers, I do not know the volume of such mail. Australian legislation, in general, does not prohibit the solicitation of business through the mail. It is not clear that any such prohibition would be practical or provide any benefit to consumers. If Australian businesses are permitted to solicit by direct mail advertising, it would be incongruous to prohibit overseas businesses doing likewise.

(2) The provisions in Part V of the Trade Practices Act 1974 protect consumers from a wide range of unfair practices, including misleading or deceptive conduct, and imply conditions and warranties into contracts for the supply of goods or services by a corporation (and in some cases by an individual) to a consumer. Whether this protection is available to consumers purchasing through mail order from an overseas company will depend upon the particular circumstances of the transaction and the application of the rules for resolving conflicts of laws which arise in international transactions. If the seller has no place of business in Australia, however, any remedy granted by the courts may be difficult to enforce. The country in which the seller has its place of business may also confer rights upon consumers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 5 December 1990.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In terms of Reserve training what will be considered eligible training and what will not be considered eligible training in each of the three Services for the purposes of the Training Guarantee Act.

(2) Has the Department of Defence or the Australian Defence Force prepared any guidelines on what will be considered eligible training in compliance with the Act, if so, what are they; if not, why not.

(3) How will the training be measured and deemed eligible under this Act, given that all Reserve training does not involve a set course, but rather training on individual nights over an indeterminable period.
(4) How will Reserve training comply with the Training Guarantee Fund and how will the charge be collected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) For the purposes of the Training Guarantee Scheme, a training program is defined as eligible training (by Section 27 (1) of the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990) if:
(a) the program is a structured training program; and
(b) the sole or principal object of the program is to develop, maintain or improve employment related skills of employees or other persons.

As with Service training programs in general, practically all Reserve training programs meet these criteria. Service training programs are structured through the utilisation of a systematic approach to both the design and conduct of the training, including as essential features:
(a) formalized employment related training objectives,
(b) training material and teaching methods specifically developed to help achieve these objectives, and
(c) assessment methods which ensure that the students have achieved these objectives.

The design and approval of these training programs is undertaken by personnel who are appropriately qualified through having attended the necessary training development, management and administration courses.

(2) The Department of Defence and the Australian Defence Force believe that the guidelines provided by the Training Guarantee (Administration) Act 1990 and the Australian Taxation Office in the booklet `The Training Guarantee-Your Questions Answered' are sufficient at this time. Neither the Department of Defence nor the Australian Defence Force intends producing additional guidelines at this stage.

(3) The main objective of Reserve training, as it is with the majority of training programs in the regular forces, is to prepare personnel as effective members of a Service team. Reservists will normally spend the majority of their Reserve training obligations in a structured training program developing, maintaining or improving skills specific to their military employment. Their training therefore meets the eligibility criteria under the Training Guarantee legislation. The need for Reservists to undertake some of their training at night or on weekends is not a consideration as regards the eligibility of the training program.

(4) The Training Guarantee obligation is for employers to spend 1% of their total payroll amount on eligible training in each financial year. Reserve personnel spend the majority of their Reserve time in developing, maintaining or improving skills specific to their military employment by means of structured training programs. Expenditure on this training substantially exceeds the Training Guarantee obligation. As no shortfall will occur in respect of the 1% obligation under the legislation, no charge will be payable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What number of citizens band radio operators is estimated to be unlicensed.
(2) What amount of licence fees is evaded by such unlicensed operators each year.
(3) What would be the annual cost of stricter enforcement of licensing requirements.
(4) Would such measures lead to a net saving to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No formal examination of this matter has been conducted as there are no easily accessible sources of information on the number of CB transmitters sold.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics do keep figures relating to importation of CB equipment but these are based on excise revenue. The generic nature of the classification and the lack of knowledge about the number of units makes it impossible to accurately estimate the number of CB transmitters held by operators.

For all of these reasons the Department has not been able to make comparisons on other than statistical samples from its own regulatory campaigns. These statistics indicate that, for the sample areas, between 40 to 60 percent of CB transmitters were found to be unlicensed.
Because of the small statistical sample and differing demography, the result would be very unreliable if these figures were projected to the national level.

(2) If the number of unlicensed CBs was as high as is implied by the information available to the Department, the amount of licence tax evaded annually, based on the 1990 licence tax level and September quarterly licence statistics, is between 4.0 and 10.0 million dollars.

(3) Stricter enforcement of licensing requirements will entail significant costs for increased personnel, motor vehicles, technical equipment and accommodation in remote locations. Increased court costs from a greater number of court actions could also be anticipated for the more difficult cases, but this may be offset to some extent by an increase in the issue of ``on-the-spot'' fines as an alternative enforcement approach.
However, firm figures on these costs are difficult to quantify and would depend on the level of enforcement activity pursued.

(4) Yes, providing a reasonable balance was maintained between staff engaged in the activity and the results flowing from the action. However, it needs to be recognised that no level of resources could ever completely eradicate the practice.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it possible for an ex-serviceman who served post-war to receive a lump sum 100 per cent disability pension payment in arrears; if so, under what circumstances would such a payment be possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Disability pensions may be provided to veterans for incapacity resulting from war-or defence-caused injuries or diseases. When entitlement to a disability pension has been established a rate of pension is assessed. All veterans entitled to a disability pension, regardless of the type of service they have rendered or the rate of pension, are paid in the same manner.
Disability pensions are paid fortnightly, no lump sum payments are made. However, arrears of pension may be paid in the following circumstances;
* where a veteran lodges a claim for pension, which is subsequently accepted, payment of pension is backdated to a date no earlier than 3 months prior to date of claim;
* where a veteran lodges an Application for Increase (AFI), and an increase in pension is subsequently granted, payment of the increased rate is backdated to the date of the AFI; and
* in both cases the arrears cover the period from the earliest date until the day before regular payments begin.

Where a claim or AFI is rejected at the primary determining level and the veteran seeks a review by the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, and is successful, arrears of pension may also be paid.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: Repair Capability

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence upon notice, on 6 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the justification for the acquisition of an autoclave for the repair of aircraft bonded panels and engine components, tender reference RFT 08/93971K July 1988.
(2) Is this repair capability duplicated in the civilian Australian infrastructure, particularly, does ASTA have facilities of a similar capability or better.
(3) Has civilian capacity for this repair function been assessed; if so, what grounds determined the decision to procure a stand alone system detailed in this tender.
(4) Does the procurement of this repair autoclave entail any additional employment of highly skilled or specialised personnel.
(5) What is the estimated cost of the project and equipment including training and personnel costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Repairs to aircraft large bonded panels in the past have been undertaken overseas because commercial companies in Australia have concentrated on production rather than on repair work. RAAF has undertaken repairs of small panels to the limit of an existing small autoclave; this RAAF capability is required for the possible repair of battle damaged aircraft operating from forward bases. The autoclave acquisition was justified on the basis of efficiency gains to be made by performing in Australia repairs which are currently performed overseas.

(2) Both ASTA and Hawker de Havilland have facilities for this type of work but are set up for large scale manufacture rather than low volume repair. Recently ASTA set up its Military business unit which will have installed a large autoclave by April 1991 and aims to provide a repair capability for aircraft bonded panels. Therefore action on the RFT has been suspended pending an assessment of ASTA Military's capability to effectively and efficiently perform bonded panel repairs. An autoclave is only one element of that capability.

(3) Civilian capacity is continually assessed. In 1988/89 the repair of large bonded panels was trialled unsuccessfully at ASTA's Fishermen's Bend facility. This inability of Australian industry to meet RAAF requirements led to the issuing of the RFT.

(4) RAAF possesses skills associated with repair of bonded panels including autoclave operations. These skills are considered fundamental to the RAAF's capability to perform battle damage repair on modern aircraft. No additional employment of personnel was proposed as part of this minor project.
(5) The estimated cost of the autoclave project was $lm.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 11 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the status of the Commonwealth Guidelines on Bleached Kraft Pulp Mills, which were released some 12 months ago, with respect to their adoption by State Governments.
(2) If a bleached kraft pulpmill proposal were to be developed over the next 12 months, could the proponents be certain that the Commonwealth Guidelines would be the same as those released last year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth's environmental guidelines for new bleached eucalypt kraft (BEK) pulp mills were released on 12 December 1989 as part of the Government's Pulp and Paper Industry Package. The guidelines specify emission limits based on the best available technology economically achievable (BATEA) and requirements for solid waste disposal, site suitability criteria and baseline studies and monitoring.
The objectives of the guidelines are:
(a) to ensure protection of the environment from emissions generated by future BEK pulp mills; and
(b) to clarify for State/Territory government agencies, industry and potential investors, the minimum environmental requirements of the Commonwealth for any new BEK pulp mill.

In pursuit of these objectives, the Commonwealth is seeking to negotiate with the States/Territories, which will have responsibility for licensing and regulating any new BEK pulp mill, agreements on procedures for environmental impact assessment (EIA), baseline studies, monitoring programs, and regulatory action during mill commissioning and operation. Negotiations are in progress at officer level with Victoria, New South Wales and Tasmania.

(2) The guidelines will normally be subject to a 5-yearly review, to take account of technological improvements and new knowledge on environmental impact, using procedures the same as, or similar to, those used to develop the original set of guidelines.

The review could be brought forward if particular environmental concerns have arisen, major new developments in BATEA have occurred, or a major new mill was about to be considered close to a scheduled review date.

Currently, the Government is not aware of any of the conditions for a review being met. While we are aware that there is work being conducted towards further reduction of organochlorine emissions and that there have been some promising developments, we are not aware of any mill which has sufficient operational experience with any new or improved technologies to give us the data that would be required to develop, for instance, a new limit on annual average absorbable organic halide (AOX) emissions.

The Commonwealth recognises that the States may require more stringent environmental controls than those embodied in the guidelines. In the event that a State were considering tighter limits for specific emissions, the Commonwealth would be willing to assist in their formulation.

While the guidelines do not specify the technologies to be applied in a mill, they do set requirements based on the concept of BATEA; that is, technology installed and operating commercially in a similar mill elsewhere. The Commonwealth will not require a mill to incorporate unproven technology.
The guidelines do not replace existing Commonwealth and State/Territory EIA processes, which would consider a wider range of environmental impacts than those included in the guidelines.

(8) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PLANS

The Commission acknowledges the importance of community development plans. Work has commenced on developing a community planning program. In the meantime, both the Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training are examining options for providing assistance to communities in the preparation of community development plans.

Under new administrative arrangements for CDEP, communities will have to provide a CDEP works program when making applications for CDEP grant funds. The works program will comprise a list of projects that the community sees as important to its social, cultural, recreational and economic development.
Communities are being encouraged to develop specific CDEP plans and/or community development plans. The CDEP works program would be an integral part of either of these plans.
ASSESSMENT CRITERIA
All CDEP grants are assessed by the Commission on the annual ``Grant Assessment Form'' which is completed by Regional Officers as part of the annual draft estimates documentation.

In addition to the annual grant assessment all CDEP projects are to be fully reviewed on a three year cycle commencing in 1991/92. It is envisaged that these reviews will be undertaken by officers from the Commission and the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Social Security.
PRIORITY SETTING

Under new administrative arrangements priorities for the allocation of CDEP Oncost and Support funds will be determined by Regional Managers in consultation with Regional Councils and CDEP communities and organisations.
INACCURATE PAYMENTS

It is acknowledged that some communities do not always submit fortnightly variation schedules. However, while this can cause short term inaccuracies, community entitlements are adjusted when subsequent schedules are received.
While delays occur between the Commission and DSS this does not result in over or under payments by ATSIC, as any adjustments necessary (after DSS checking) are made in subsequent quarters.
The lack of sanctions under the standard grant offer has been corrected by additional mandatory special conditions for CDEP.

The administrative changes to the CDEP system to take effect from 1 April 1991 have been designed to simplify the calculation of communities' entitlements and should reduce the possibility of inaccuracies.
MANAGEMENT AND ACCOUNTING TRAINING

The lack of qualified Aboriginal people has been a problem for DAA/ATSIC and communities alike. Training initiatives have been taken by DAA/ATSIC and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address this issue.

As a part of new administrative arrangements for CDEP, a Training Needs Schedule and a training program to meet these needs for each CDEP is required. Under the Department of Employment, Education and Training (Training for Aboriginals Program) funding may be made available for communities to engage a consultant, where appropriate, to prepare training needs analyses and/or training schedules for project participants.
ENTITLEMENTS, ALLOWANCES AND AWARD PAYMENTS

Since the ANAO audits of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were conducted there has been a significant improvement in the take up rate of the Family Allowance Supplement by CDEP participants. The Department of Social Security is promoting this allowance through its Aboriginal Liaison Officers and Community Agents.
While ATSIC encourages the payment of wages at award rates, the setting of pay rates is left to the discretion of community councils and organisations.

Award coverage for CDEP communities is a complex issue as the nature of the work generally is only part-time. The Commission is currently in the process of contracting a consultant to undertake research into industrial relations issues associated with CDEPs including the question of award coverage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 12 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) What deductions, if any, are made by the Federal Government, or financial institutions, from superannuation paid under the 3 per cent productivity award.
(b) In respect of any deductions made, are they levied on a pro rata basis for part-time or casual workers, or are they levied at a flat rate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) and (b) The Minister for Finance's superannuation responsibilities are confined to the superannuation arrangements for the Commonwealth's civilian employees.

Accordingly, this answer is restricted to the current superannuation arrangements for Commonwealth public servants. Employees of Commonwealth agencies with their own schemes, for example the Government Business Enterprises, are covered by arrangements very similar to those in the private sector and are taxed accordingly. The taxation of superannuation benefits in the hands of the recipients is taken to be outside the scope of the question.
Commonwealth public servants could have their superannuation provided under one of the following arrangements:
(1) the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme (CSS) established by the Superannuation Act 1976; or
(2) the Public Sector Superannuation (PSS) scheme established under the Superannuation Act 1990; or
(3) the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988 under which:
(a) employers are required to pay continuing contributions on behalf of their employees to a superannuation fund on every pay period commencing 1 July 1990; or

(b) those employees whose current weekly earning is less than $110.00 per week or whose employment contract is not exceeding three months, are provided with a cash benefit equivalent to the employer contributions that would have been paid to a superannuation fund had this provision not been in place; or
(c) a safety net is provided by which employees who do not receive their productivity benefit through any of the other superannuation arrangements can be paid a benefit; or
(4) special arrangements for senior fixed-term employees (for example, continuing membership of a previous superannuation scheme during their Commonwealth employment).
Interim Arrangement for Productivity Benefit

For the period 1 January 1988 to 30 June 1990, the productivity benefit was provided for all employees now covered by the first three of the four categories described above under the Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988. It was administered by employers and was not funded until the employee exited from Commonwealth employment and as such not taxed until received by the beneficiary.

The benefit provided under the interim arrangement approximated an accumulation of the productivity contributions with interest at the long-term bond rate, without any deduction for administrative expenses.
The CSS and PSS

The CSS and PSS are the two major schemes for Commonwealth public servants. They require members to contribute and the employer cost of providing benefits is greater than the 3 per cent productivity benefit. From 1 July 1990, the schemes incorporate the 3 per cent benefit for public servants in their benefit structure, including the amount of the unfunded benefit at 30 June 1990 under the interim arrangement.

From 1 July 1990, employers have been required to pay the 3 per cent productivity contribution into the superannuation funds established for the CSS and PSS. No administrative fee is deducted from the productivity contribution itself.

The productivity contributions form part of the assessable income of each fund, as do earnings arising from the investment of the productivity and member contributions. After allowable deductions (which would include the administrative and other costs associated with the investment of the fund), the taxable income of the fund is subject to tax at the rate of 15 per cent.

Income tax is deducted from the net earnings of each superannuation fund prior to determining the amount available for distribution to individual members' accounts. The amount available for distribution may also be adjusted by a transfer to, or from, the reserve account mechanism which has been adopted to stabilise the rate of interest allocated to member and productivity contributions. Employees share pro rata, according to their equity in the fund, in the distributed after-tax income, irrespective of whether they are full-time, part-time or casual.
Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act 1988

This Act is the means by which the 3 per cent productivity benefit is provided to employees who are not members of the CSS or PSS or do not have their superannuation provided under a special arrangement (eg fixed-term employees continuing membership of a previous scheme). The Act is the renamed Superannuation Benefit (Interim Arrangement) Act 1988, following extensive amendment in 1990 to put in place permanent arrangements.

The Act generally requires employers to pay the productivity contributions for such employees to a fund approved by the Minister for Finance. The Minister has approved a number of industry-type funds under the Act to receive 3 per cent productivity contributions from employers. In addition, the Minister has nominated the industry fund, the Australian Government Employees Superannuation Trust (AGEST) to receive productivity contributions under the Act. Employees have the choice of contributing to the AGEST or an approved fund. In cases where the employee does not make an election contributions are paid to the nominated fund (AGEST).

The amount of individuals' unfunded benefit at 30 June 1990, if any, under the interim arrangement is to be transferred by employers to either the AGEST or an approved fund, as appropriate, and hence become a funded employer contribution. Regular contributions are required by employers after the transfer.

An amount of $0.60 per week is deducted from each weekly contribution paid to AGEST (irrespective of the amount of the contribution) and placed in a reserve account. All of the costs associated with the operation of AGEST (including administration, audit and legal costs) are met from the reserve. Funds remaining in the reserve are available for distribution to members.

There is also a levy of $1.00 per weekly contribution for death and total and permanent disability insurance cover. Members who are already a member of another superannuation scheme which provides similar insurance cover may elect not to pay this levy to the AGEST.

Like the CSS and PSS, the productivity contributions form part of the assessable income of the AGEST, as do earnings arising from the investment of the productivity contributions. After allowing for the $0.60 placed in the reserve account and, where applicable, the $1.00 death and total and permanent disability insurance cover, the taxable income of the fund is subject to tax at the rate of 15 per cent.
Employees share pro rata, according to their equity in the AGEST, in the distributed after-tax investment income, irrespective of whether they are full-time, part-time or casual.

The amounts charged by the various approved funds and the way they are levied may vary. For example, an approved fund may offset the administrative cost against income prior to the allocation of interest to members' accounts.
Other Provisions of the Superannuation (Productivity Benefit) Act

It was recognised that a flat weekly administrative charge could represent an unreasonably high proportion of a part-time or casual employee's productivity contribution. Accordingly, special provisions to cater for such cases have been determined by the Minister under the Act.

Under the determination, employees currently earning less than $110 per week or on contracts of less than three months may elect to receive an unfunded benefit calculated in the same way as the interim arrangements that applied to Commonwealth employees between January 1988 and June 1990. Benefit payments of $500 or more must be preserved in accordance with the Occupational Superannuation standards. This enables low income earners and short-term employees to avoid the administrative charges payable on productivity contributions. Employees who elect to receive their benefit in this way would not have insurance cover for death and total and permanent disability.

The Act also provides a safety net for employees for whom no productivity contributions or benefits have been provided (eg inadvertent omission by employers to pay contributions). It gives such employees a benefit calculated in the same way as the interim arrangement.
Special Arrangements

Where special arrangements are made for fixed-term employees, the charges levied on the productivity contributions would depend on the nature of the special arrangement. In general, it is likely that where a private policy was arranged or payments were made to an industry fund, there would be some charges. Where membership of a previous employer's scheme was continued, any administrative charges would depend on the arrangements made by the employer.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Minister's assertion in Senate Question Time on 1 December 1990 (Hansard p5371) that since Labor has been in Government $8 billion has been cut from the budget of Social Security, what would this figure have been if the unemployment rate which was current for March 1983 was the unemployment rate Australia faced now and what assumptions are made in the calculation of this figure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The $8 billion outlays reduction figure represents the cumulative impact of Budget savings measures introduced over the period from the 1983-84 Budget to the 1989-90 Budget inclusive.

To try and calculate the impact on Social Security outlays and savings measures if a different economic situation had prevailed since March 1983 would be a hypothetical exercise requiring many assumptions about what Government economic and fiscal policies and market reactions would have been in a different set of circumstances.

There were over 70 savings measures introduced within the Social Security portfolio over the first seven Budgets of the Labor Government. It would not be practicable to recalculate the savings outcome of each of these individual measures on the basis of a series of questionable assumptions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 19 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to a letter dated 31 January 1990, referring to the Kamunting Road Christian Cemetery, located in Malaysia, where Australian casualties of the Malaysian Emergency, Indonesian Confrontation and the Vietnam War are commemorated, in which Air Vice Marshal Roser, Assistant Chief of Defence Force Personnel stated: `In order to ensure that maintenance standards are sustained my staff are in the process of arranging for the Defence Adviser, Kuala Lumpur, to carry out periodic visits to the cemetery. Any deterioration in maintenance standards should be detected early and rectified promptly'; since this letter was written what visits have been carried out, and what reports have been made, on the state of Kamunting Road Christian Cemetery.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Don Taggart, Executive Officer, Office of Australian War Graves, visited the cemetery in June 1990 and his report contained the following text: ``Arrived at Kamunting Road Christian Cemetery at 9.30 am and at once was surprised at the size of the cemetery and the fact that from the outside I could see every grave. The cemetery was smaller than I expected and the three post war plots were immediately visible from the road. The condition of the cemetery was better than many civil cemeteries in Australia and I was able to walk freely throughout most areas. The grass was in need of cutting but the appearance did not prevent a visitor from quickly finding the post war plots. The grass in these plots had been mown only a few days earlier and the shrubs though sparse, were in good condition. The border areas were not dug over and were dry but had been recently raked. They were even and clean. The edges needed trimming and straightening and as mentioned in earlier reports the borders were too wide. All in all, a satisfactory appearance.''

The Defence Adviser's staff, Kuala Lumpur, maintains an informal network (administration of war graves in Malaysia is a Consular matter) that reports on the condition of the various war cemeteries in Malaysia. In the case of the Kamunting Road Christian Cemetery on the outskirts of Taiping and the War Cemetery in Taiping the Defence Adviser's Office receive verbal reports on a six to eight weekly basis. The Officer Commanding Land Liaison Section Butterworth, a Major in the Australian Army, calls into these two cemeteries whenever he is undertaking duty travel in a southerly direction from Butterworth and reports on their condition by phone. The reports have always been positive with the most adverse comment received being that the grass required attention, with the rider that given the enormous rainfall often experienced in the area it is often difficult to maintain high horticultural standards. No formal reports have been submitted due to the positive nature of the comments received.
Additionally, the Officer Commanding Land Liaison Section arranges annual ANZAC Day observances at Taiping and Kamunting Road Cemeteries and these are planned for 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 19 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) ``Was the Minister congratulated by President Kabua of the Marshall Islands for his work in seeking to terminate the United Nations Trusteeship over Micronesia when he was in Majuro in November 1990.
(2) What is the Government's position on termination of this Trusteeship with regard to the people of Palau (Belau) who have not yet had the chance to express their right to self-determination.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: President Kabua wrote to me in October 1990, just prior to my visit to Majuro, expressing his gratitude and that of the Government and people of the Republic of the Marshall Islands for raising the question of termination of the United Nations Trusteeship in my speech to the United Nations General Assembly on 2 October 1990. During our meeting in Majuro, the Honourable Tom Kijiner, Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Republic of the Marshall Islands, also explicitly welcomed Australia's strong support on the Trusteeship termination issue and said his Government very much appreciated the helpful reference to this contained in my speech to the United Nations General Assembly.

(2) It is incorrect to state that the people of Palau have not yet had a chance to express their right to self-determination. Since 1983 Palauans have voted on seven separate occasions on a Compact of Free Association agreement negotiated between the governments of Palau and the United States. On each occasion a clear majority of voters has supported the proposed Compact, always less, however, than the 75 percent majority necessary to override the non-nuclear provisions of the Palau Constitution. Palau therefore remains under United States administrative authority as the last component of the Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands. The Australian Government considers that a decision on the Compact and the termination of the Trusteeship with respect to Palau is a matter for the Government and people of Palau.

This was the last narrow gauge line into the Gladstone yard and closure will allow the yard to become a one-gauge operation. This will give operational savings and allow the return of some land to the State of South Australia for other uses.

(2) 28,627 tonnes were carried in 1987/88, the last year that the line carried wheat traffic. Assuming a net payload of 26 tonnes, approximately 1,100 truck trips would have been required to haul the grain carried during the 1987/88 season.
(3) and (4) The Federal Government does not hold this information.

(5)and (6) Grain traffic had already transferred to road before closure occurred. Since the line was carrying no traffic when closed, retention of the line would have made no difference to the number of trucks on the road, nor to road trauma or environmental pollution.

(7) The basis for closure of this line was that the South Australian Cooperative Bulk Handling (SACBH) had let the contract for the handling of grain in this area to road, commencing with the 1988/89 harvest and there was no real expectation that it would be regained by rail. The South Australian Government agreed to the closure. This is the normal pattern for the closure of grain lines in South Australia.

(8) The use of roads by grain trucks and related issues are matters for the State and local Governments, which are responsible for the roads used by these trucks. The SACBH, which effectively determines the mode of transport of grain by awarding contracts for transport of grain from its silos to the ports, is a State instrumentality.
(9) It is a matter for Government to determine which of AN's operations should be supported financially by the taxpayer.

(10) As mentioned under questions 5 and 6, this line closed because it was no longer carrying traffic. Consequently, the question of funding it as a Community Service Obligation did not arise. However, the Government has decided that AN's mainland freight operations should operate on a commercial basis. It would be necessary to identify a compelling social and/or environmental case to warrant changing this.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Mobile Review Teams

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Social Security mobile review teams are operating throughout Australia.
(2) What is the cost of putting the review teams into the field, including salaries, transport, accommodation, etc.
(3) How much money in terms of overpayments has been recovered as a direct consequence of the activities of the mobile review teams.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) From 1 February 1991 there will be 60 mobile review teams in operation throughout Australia.

(2) The cost of running the mobile review teams in 1990-91 is expected to be approximately $16m. This consists of $12m for salaries, $2m for motor vehicle running expenses and $2m for travel allowances.
The average cost of operating a full team per fortnight is $10 500.

(3) As a direct result of mobile review team activities for the 1989-90 financial year, cumulative savings in outlays per fortnight amounting to $4.6m were achieved by stopping incorrect payments of pensions and benefits.
The Department of Finance has accepted as reasonable that, in this type of case, payments would have continued for 26 fortnights (one year) but for a team's intervention.

On this basis, estimated savings of $120.4m were attained as a result of deploying teams over the 1989-90 financial year. Overpayments of $9.3m were also identified. Each individual overpayment case is assessed to determine whether recovery action, waiver or write-off is appropriate. Separate data are not maintained on money recovered from overpayments identified by mobile review teams compared with other review activities.

During the 1989-90 financial year, total overpayments raised as a result of all review activity undertaken by the Department or advised by clients amounted to $81.4m. During the same financial year $73.3m was recovered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the cost of Australia's 1992 Expo pavilion in Spain, including all incidental fitout costs necessary to complete the pavilion display for opening: (a) how much money was budgeted to be spent; (b) how much money has been spent so far; (c) how much money is now estimated to be necessary to complete the pavilion as planned; (d) was a fixed price entered into for the construction of the pavilion; if not, why not; (e) what controls have been placed on the expenditure on the 1992 pavilion; and (f) who is responsible for the expenditure and who is monitoring that expenditure.
(2) What is the purpose of the pavilion.
(3) Does the Government have any sponsorship for the pavilion.
(4) Which, if any, businesses and individuals have been approached to sponsor the Australian pavilion.
(5) With reference to question (4) which, if any, businesses and individuals have declined to participate and which, if any have accepted and will provide sponsorship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) $A25 million at February 1989 prices and exchange rates for the design, construction and operation of the pavilion over the six months of the Expo. As at 7 January 1991 this equates to an out-turn cost of $36,110,000.
(1) (c) $A36,110,000 (including design, construction and operation). This amount includes (b) above.
(1) (d) Yes.

(1) (e) The Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT), in consultation, where appropriate, with design and construction consultants, the Australian Construction Services, is closely monitoring all program expenditure and commitments to ensure that the project is completed within budget. Monitoring procedures adhere to standard Commonwealth accounting practice as laid down in the Audit Act and Regulations.

(1) (f) The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories through DASETT, is responsible for the expenditure. DASETT, the Department of Finance and the Commonwealth Parliament are monitoring the expenditure.

(2) To promote the growth of international tourism to Australia; the growth of Australian trade, industry and investment; awareness and understanding of Australian society and culture; and to enhance our political and cultural ties.
(3) Yes.
(4) Seventy-five major Australian companies and corporate organisations were invited to participate as major partners with the Commonwealth.
Some 150 companies were approached to consider becoming official suppliers.
Names of those companies approached are held by DASETT, but for reasons of commercial confidentiality it would not be appropriate to release details of the firms involved.
(5) Two companies have elected to participate: QANTAS Airways and another large Australian company with which contract negotiations are currently underway.
Negotiations are continuing with a number of companies who have expressed interest in becoming official suppliers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to correspondence between the Minister for Community Services and Health and Greystanes Children's Home, 2 Grose Street, Leura, NSW, 2780 are, 14 young adults over the age of 16 inappropriately housed in a specially designed 38-bed children's home with 24 babies and children.
(2) Has Greystanes been discussing alternative accommodation for these young adults with the Minister, his department and other agencies for the last four years.
(3) Has Greystanes, in desperation, offered to provide a new accommodation service and, at the request of the department, did it submit a proposal in 1989.
(4) Has Greystanes received a decision on this proposal.
(5) Does the Minister intend to approve the application by Greystanes for a new service for these 14 young adults.
(6) Is the department procrastinating in the knowledge that the States will be taking over responsibility for accommodation services.
(7) Who will provide a service for these people if they are discharged from Greystanes.
(8) What does Greystanes need to do in order to facilitate a decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Young adults at Greystanes could be more appropriately accommodated. The Minister for Community Services and Health and officers of his Department have acknowledged this in their correspondence with Greystanes on numerous occasions.
(2) Yes.

(3) The Minister and officers of his Department have made it clear that the Department will consider proposals from Greystanes for accommodation options for current residents for funding under the Disability Services Act.
Greystanes submitted a proposal dated 12 May 1989 to the Department for capital and recurrent funding for a 15/16 bed unit.

Discussions between officers of the Department and Greystanes culminated in a meeting on 18 October 1989 to discuss this proposal. Departmental officers expressed their concern that a 15/16 bed unit would not further the Principles and Objectives of the Disability Services Act and advised that the current proposal would not be funded.

In a letter of 1 February 1990 to the Department, the Executive Secretary of Greystanes acknowledged her recognition of the Department's reasons for not recommending funding for Greystanes' proposal of 12 May 1989.
(4) Yes. Greystanes has been advised that their proposal for a 15/16 bed unit would not be funded.
(5) The present proposal will not be funded.

The Department is committed to the development of new services to meet the demand in the Blue Mountains area. However, there is heavy competition for available funds. Each application is considered according to regional priorities, its merit in terms of furthering the Principles and Objectives of the Disability Services Act, and available funds.

(7) This question appears to imply that Grey-stanes would consider evicting 14 people, simply for becoming adults in their accommodation service. Although we all acknowledge that the adults could be more appropriately accommodated, such an action would cause the Minister concern about the level of commitment Greystanes has to these 14 people and to the Principles and Objectives of the Disability Services Act under which it receives Commonwealth funding.
(8) Greystanes has been advised that their proposal for a 15/16 bed unit would not be funded under the Disabilities Services Act.

If Greystanes wishes to provide alternative services for any of their existing adult residents, the Department is willing to discuss proposals which further the Principles and Objectives of the Disability Services Act. However, it needs to be recognised that the existing funding designated for these residents would be transferred with them in any new accommodation arrangement funded under the Disability Services Act.

If Greystanes then wished to expand their service by bringing in more children, they would be expected to make an application to the New South Wales State Government for funding, as State Governments have the primary responsibility for services for children with a disability.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, (Hansard L4452, 26 November 1990) whether the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation could publish at regular intervals in a public forum the sort of information which domestic aviation consumers need to know in order to make informed choices.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) produces reports on each accident and significant incident which it investigates. These reports are available on request to any member of the public.

The Bureau also produces a magazine called the BASI Journal. In addition to safety education material, each issue contains reports of occurrence investigations completed since the previous issue. Some 64,000 copies of the Journal are currently distributed throughout the aviation industry. This publication is also available to any member of the public.

In addition to accident and incident reports, the Bureau also publishes special reports on matters of safety significance. Recent reports have looked at helicopter operations over a 20 year period, and at problems involving pilots losing consciousness during aerobatic flying.
At the present time, the public may obtain copies of BASI reports and the Journal free of charge.
